												How can a game be terrible and awesome at the same time? I don't know, but that is the case here. Bugs, glitches, terrible voice acting and vanilla writing mask a large, enjoyable open world, a confusing but rewarding alchemy system, a ton of loot, and enjoyable exploration. I love this game, and when it's on sale it is an incredible value. If you like B movies and Oblivion, this is their ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ child.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												Okay, so I have to start my review by admitting I really enjoyed my time playing Two Worlds.  As others have said, the game is fairly glitchy, but as a long-time gamer, glitches don't ruin things for me as long as they are consistent.  In fact, learning to take advantage of those glitches used to be a big part of gaming, and I enjoyed the challenge in Two Worlds.The game is pretty standard fare with a male hero seeking to save the hapless female (yawn), and the hack-and-slash gameplay is good.  Go kill some stuff, collect stuff, and do some quests that consist of killing stuff and collecting stuff.  It's nothing special, but I enjoyed it all the same.The voice acting is so bad that I actually played with the game muted.  That was a new experience.I was having fun, exploring the land and doing side quests, and then I discovered something horrible.  Truly horrible.  This is the gamer's equivalent of Lovecraftian Old Ones rising from their slumber to slaughter the denizens of an innocent town...After about 90 hours of gameplay (mostly ignoring the main quest), I discovered that certain tasks in side quests MUST NOT be completed before certain other tasks in the main quest.  Or you break your entire experience.  And the game can't progress.  And there is NO way to fix it....Boo.

Posted: November 19, 2014
												Pros:      1. Great Open world to explore and discover stuff      2. One of those games that the more you play, the better your guy gets, no cap      3. Gameplay is fun      4. Quests aren't repetitiveCons:      1. Acting is TERRIBLE      2. Graphics are not the best, its a pretty old game after all      3. Quests are annoying at times, like i said, acting is really bad      4. Can get quite annoyingReason for recommendation:      While the acting is terrible and the quests can be annoying, I personally enjoyed it just cause you can go out and just level up endlessly and the gear has a fun upgrading system, you can get more of the same item and combine them to make it better, but it will still be the same item. So, say you take out a tower, and like every other guy had the same weapon. You can then take all the weapons and combine them together and get a weapon that may just be better than what you're using. Worst comes to worst you can always sell it and not worry about having to carry around 15+ weapons to get your gold. I have always enjoyed a game that has endless upgrading. This one is enjoyable too if you can get past the terrible acting and just do your own thing.

Posted: April 19, 2014
												I really like this game but it is super rough around the edges. Mouth sync is non existent, graphics are dated, quite a few glitches, and small mechanic issues. I won't lie and say you won't notice them, because you will. However, this is now the third time I have completed this game, and I still give it a good rating. I have more fun every time I run through it.I love this series so much, and it sucks that they have stopped adding to it. This game has a great charm to it. Everyone speaks in old English and it just sounds nice. The second one is all around better, but no other game has had that charm that this game has.This game honestly has a lot going for it. The experience system is nice and even. The skill building is cool. The mobs are varied. The armor upgrade system is awesome. The area looks good and is quite diverse. If you get past the problems, there is a real gem here.I am fully recommending this game. Love it!

content:
Posted: November 10, 2015
												Well, after playing quite a lot and still playing I decided to recommend this game, at least to rpg funs. I am saying this because with a ton of games available today and so many on sale offers, one may easily abandon a game and go for another.Why I like this game? It is addictive. It keeps you playing for its advantages regardless its flaws. I have a lot of games, games I go back playing like skyrim, games I do not stop until I complete them like shadow of Mordor and games I never start playing yet. Too many games, too few time. Still, two worlds is a game that I start and did not abandon nor I will anytime soon. This game has something strangely addictive. For example I abandon dark souls about mid game while been an excellent game but I am now mid-game at two worlds and I hardy spent this little time to write this, right now I prefer to enter the game and continue.To describe this game very briefly, it is like diablo on levelling and items, like oblivion on world environment feeling and like divinity 2 on movement and combat. It also has some unique gameplay elements on its own.What you need to know primarily is that tutorial is brief and very basic. This game needs your close attention to understand it. The first time I play I think there were major flaws and bad designs but with a second and third closer careful looks I understand that I was wrong. Once you understand how things work it is where you really get addicted. I am sure that most negative reviews comes from hasty gamers. I do not blame them, a modern game needs to have a proper tutorial, a complex game a large tutorial, this game most likely relies on the manual.Let’s get on details(the bad stuff at the end):The character: You only play a male human character, no females and no races. That’s it. Also your starting character is fixed, fixed attributes and fixed starting skills. You cannot start with point pool and boost what you like. However the starting skills are the basic ones and at level 1 of 10. You can level up and increase any you like. All starting skills are all you need to do all essential things and secondary actions. For example you have lock pick 1 and you can lock pick and also increase it for a better chance. You do not have alchemy skill but you can still use alchemy. Finally, playing the game and visit villages and towns will allow you to meet trainers that will teach you the level 1 of all skills eventually, so there is no skill point cost at all for level 1 skill. If for example you want to advance alchemy or water magic you do not start with, all you need is to find the appropriate trainers to get the 1st skill point by paying some money. While levelling you get 5 attribute points and one or two skill points, usually one. You may also get one skill point before you level up but I have not yet figure out when, the game has many good secrets. You can also permanently increase attributes using alchemy even without skill 1, if you find the proper ingredients. In other words the game is rewarding for the good and smart player offering more than the standard gain experience and fixed level up procedure. Two level 10 characters for example may be different, one may be even 40% stronger from extra attributes and skills alone.The gear and items: Items are much like diablo, leveled items and many auxiliary items, consumables and especially ingredients. The only disadvantage here if it is one is that there are too many items. Not just leveled, too many items. Perhaps the greatest variety on gear I have ever seen. Ready consumables are just what is needed. Ingredients are plenty and not only herbs but also parts from animals and various minerals. There are also gems as consumables to add different types of damage to weapons, traps to set, spell cards and spell boosters and few standard items like the teleport stone and quest items.One unique gameplay element here is that you can enhance any gear item, weapon or armor with another piece of item of the same type. Items have a special attribute called ‘class’ which is usually one. If you have a short sword for example and find another one you can drag and drop it one another and you will now have a class 2 short sword which of course is a little better, doing more damage in that case. This is a very good thing and very useful, as it allows you to use trivial equipment to avoid buying everything from the store at every couple of levels or so, or live and die by drop chance alone. For example I used a Grom Shield that happened to be a very common item groms carry and drop so I end up finding about 30 or so, effectively had a class 30 simple grom shield with a parry number high enough to keep me up to level 10 or so. Then there were better shields to buy and enemies no longer often carry that shield, so it was time to change. Spell cards also stack. Add a second and third and so on card of the same spell and the spell becomes stronger, requiring more mana however. Finally gems can be placed on a weapon for extra damage and you can put as many as you like as long as they are of the same type, e.g. rubies that add fire damage.Money and trading: Surprisingly money are always needed here, and the game offers a fair amount of money. The trading is active to this game. You always earn cash and you always have reasons to spent, and not on consumables exclusively. I’d rather say you may spent for making your hero more powerful. Enemies either drop inventory with a fair amount of gold and random items or a single standard automatic pickup, like the wolf drops a wolf heart which is an ingredient.  Anything may drop but specific items have better sources to be harvested and animals and beast always drop standard ingredient item instead of inventory. All except single pickups are level depended, chests, enemy inventories and shops. You are bored looking for ingredients that increase your stats permanently? No problem, pay some attention to mage shops and after a certain level you definitely come across to buy.Enemies: Good variety of enemies, large size enemies are really deadly and not level depended, leveled enemies are logical like bandits; they got stronger but not as much as you.Classes: The 3 archetypes work well, fighter, mage and archer/thief that is. Hybrids also work well. There is depth on each single archetype, fighting style and weapons for fighters, magic schools for mages and lots of choices to master for an archer/thief.The story is interesting, the world is very good at least. The soundtrack is almost perfect.Now the bad stuff: The back-jump. Honestly I hated that. In my opinion it ruins melee. I do not even assigned it to a button. The game is much better without. Again, my opinion.The dialogues. Not sure what English dialect that is but it is strange until you get used to it. Also some times are almost childish, some other times are very mature. Your hero speaks quite well though.The NPC characters. Quite average.The spells. They are lots and great and come in form of cards that stack and extra spell booster cards (more damage, less mana etch). However you may have 3 spells with booster cards (that also stack), the others need some special way to be placed on your custom hot bar, first on the spell amulet and then on the hot bar. No big deal but somewhat annoying.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
I can recommend this game. But to be honest...just barely! + Huge World to discover and it is open world from the start+ Very fast loading screens+ It definitely has a certain charm and overall I liked the game- There are so many areas you can just ignore because theres nothing to do there. In my personal experience I found the southern part of the map so unpleasant that I just rode my horse past all enemies to get to a certain place as fast as possible.+ Environments look nice, full of trees, vegetation, wild animals and other enemies. The water looked extremely good for a game that old.+ A lot of different enemy types!- The environments also look very round and generic, there are almost no rocks or cliffs in this game+ The cities and villages are filled with many many NPCs- All the NPCs look similar and it is hard to recognice those who actually advance the plot.- Most of them just say the same thing and are just there to fill the city...useless!+ Teleporters are scattered all over the map to make travelling faster. Without much loading time.- Most of the times the teleporters are also quite far away from where you want to go. I recommend planting a mobile teleporter next to some merchants in one of the cities so you can save some time because you will want to sell your stuff frequently.+ Merchants have no limited amount of gold, so you can sell them all the stuff you want.- Your Inventory has a limit. At some point your strength doesn't increase the carry weight any more.+ Some of the cities are huge and very impressive- They are also too big and you have to run through them to get to an important NPC or merchant- Also they lack verticality as there are no towers or walls to be climbed, the hero can also not climb any ladders, they are just for decoration+ Horses for longer journeys are very useful. They are much faster and you can find them in many places.- The controls for horses are very stiff. You will get stuck in trees, rocks and they wont go up or down any steep landslides. Horses do not teleport with you and the function to whistle for your horse is useless when being further than 10 meters away from it.+ The combat animations look great+ There are a lot of different ways to attack: Magic, Bows, Clubs, Staffs, Swords, Daggers, Axes... . Some two-handed and you can dual-wield.+ You can enchant your weapons with (an unlimited amount of?) gems of the same type making them more and more powerful. I have literally used all of my fire-gems on one weapon and it was extremely strong and I could add even more fire gems after that.+ It is very satisfying to kill an enemy with a two handed club because they will sometimes fly all over the place.- It also feels very stiff to fight. You will constantly miss enemies. There is no way of actively blocking an attack (at least I didnt find it).- I am sure I am not the only one to be very annoyed by the enemies with bow and arrow. It usually goes like this: Attack a group of enemies, the ones with swords will die first because they are in close combat. The archers are in the background shooting at you. You run at them to kill them. Before you can swing at them they already turned around and ran further away. You run at them to kill them. Before you can swi......x3 I've chased archers across the map like this so many times.-The framerate seems to go down during battles+ A huge amount of different armours and robes, rings and amulets. They can also be stacked when you find identical items. It is very motivating to be on the lookout for better equipment.- The high level armours wont allow you to swim, use your bow or dual wield. Why not?- There is a river flowing across the world. I wondered: I have an armour which doesn#t allow me to swim. So I ran towards the water and....the hero just walked to the other side of the river...under water! (which is also MUCH faster than swimming!)+ A large selection of skills to level up. And a lot of different spells.- Swimming skill is useless. Don't waste any points on it. There was no situation at all where I was required to swim anywhere.- Sneaking skill is useless too, as is pickpocket skill. You wont have any money problems in this game.- If you want to use the best armour in the game, don't level up your arching skills, because those armours can't be used with bow and arrow.- Horse riding skill is useless. The few times I did use horses I just used them to travel faster and get off them as soon as possible :)- There is a skill to de-horse enemies....I have not seen an enemy riding a horse.+ You can also stack your magic spells to make them more powerful.- Projectiles are very slow and will often miss their target when it isn't either standing still or moving towards you.+ Cool looking creatures can be summoned. They can distract enemies.- Summoned creatures are very slow and have no perception of depth. They will miss their swing 9 times out of 10.+ The music and sound effects are enjoyable.- The english sync is horrible! Try to play it in another language. I played it in german and it sounds a lot better.+The whole world is full of side quests!+ Levelling up is fun+ NPCs have a lot of dialogue and it's all voiced.+ A lot of small stories help to get involved in the world- Sometimes I skipped the dialogue because I didnt care.- Personally I didn't find the story interesting

number of helpful: 110 of 146 people (75%) found this review helpful18 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 6, 2015
												Two Worlds is an open world third person medieval fantasy role playing game that borders on a single player MMORPG. Its not just single player, there is a multi player function via network. Even if you want to just play single player, you need to setup a user name and password. I'd say that the game was designed for multi player. Its not just fighting one enemy, but packs of them and they were far too overpowered until I was 4 hours into the game. That's one of a number of bad first impressions I was given.I was forced to run away and let two packs of enemies kill one another and then I'd loot the corpses. It became part of the game for me. If you're not into combat, you can run by any enemy no matter how large or overpowering they are. Even if a dozen enemies are following you, they'll get bored eventually. You'll always be faster even if there's no run button. You can chose your level of difficulty at the start, but never in the game. I made the mistake of going medium.The game has a lot of dialog. In fact some banter between my character and a quest giver bordered on a novella's length. I'd watch the sun rise in the background only to have night fall during the conversation it was so long. The voice acting is stiff, slow and spoken in the old tongue. I can't call it bad voice acting, the voices are memorable, its just the speed, delivery and the "mayhap," "whenst" and archaic words that are no longer used. It was almost a point of comedy until I got used to it. With that being said, I'd rather listen to the dialog than read it. You can hit the space bar to skip each line.Another bad first impression was the fact that a lot of the time you're told to do something. Sometimes its marked on your map, other times its stuff like "find these two deserters and kill them." Well where did they go? If I knew that, I wouldn't need you. Even things that are marked on your map can have locked doors preventing you from entering or lock picking. Well where's the key? Oh you won't find that until you stumble upon some quest giver half way across the land. Then he'll give you the key after completing three quests with no sort of hint that he has the key.A lot of quests, you're given a choice to accept them and it boils down to well do I want to have something to do in the game or not? Yes of course I'll take the quest. In a game with such a giant land, it became a struggle to even find quests. The first town was brimming with quests. Each town does have a few quests, but sometimes they're relegated to one person giving all the quests. Other times you're in giant cities that you really need to go digging to find quests. The game makes it easy though to find who has a quest when you walk by them an icon appears that indicates if they're a typical background character, a quest giver, a merchant or a trainer.Gold felt worthless in the game. I never really bought anything. Everything that I had was from killing one of the hundreds of bandits or thousands of orcs. There was an occassional find at a merchant, but after a while I just stopped browsing their wares and just sold everything to them. A beautiful part about the game is they'll buy everything, they don't have limited funds and they're not picky. Its pretty streamlined. Even your inventory can carry a lot of stuff, and not that many things have a weight to them. I just wish there was a search function. You won't be over encumbered. You just can't pick up something when your inventory is full. It keeps the game moving. Another beautiful thing is you can merge the same weapons or armors to become stronger! It clears space and its interesting, even if it wouldn't happen in real life.Two Worlds is big on exploration. one of the biggest joys that I felt was exploring new areas either on foot or on horseback. There are lush forests, bright deserts with rolling dunes, bamboo forests inhabited by horrific arachnids, eerie graveyards and foggy wastelands with twisted trees. The only problem is that 99.9% of it is outdoors. There are still dungeons, but they're few and far between. Not only that, but they feel very sterile and empty. Too perfect and unnatural. Towns have interiors, but its relegated to single rooms and those too are rare. An entire village might have one room for you to enter.The land is so vast and large, with dozens of settlements. Everything from humble villages to grand cities you'll get lost in. There are two military camps, dozens of bandit camps, grom camps, mines, a dwarven quarry and gang hideouts. Oh but that's just the north half of the land. The south half is just as big, but instead of humans, every settlement, village and castle is full of orcs. The deserts have their own unique settlements, inhabitants and humanoid monster villages. Its just all so diverse. There's always something new and fresh. Necromancer towers, new enemies, new locales. It kept the game fresh and kept me exploring.Since the game is so massive, there are teleporters after you complete one of the first few quests. You'll need to find a teleporter to unlock it. Otherwise there are horses to travel faster, but a real problem is that you can't bring a horse into a teleporter. That might make a centaur. I'm very thankful to have the teleporters.The orc war is really the backdrop to the game. Its a pressing issue for the people of Two Worlds, but for you, your main goal is to rescue a woman who has been kidnapped. No no not a princess. Your sister. In fact she's one of the few women in the game. I'd say 99% of the game's population is male. More than half of the female populous dies by the end of the game if you fulfill the quests.Every dead enemy stays dead. Nothing will respawn. You can go through the entire game and become the only living thing. To shorten some silly long quests, I merely killed two entire villages full of people. They wouldn't let me into their settlement, so I killed the man with the key and everyone attacked me. Even though the game told me that the guards were notified, no one did anything. I was never arrested, nor fined. I could walk through an entire military camp and no one cared.Another way that it feels like a MMORPG is when you die, you simply respawn. You'll find several healing ankhs and mana replenishes. If you get low, just stand on them. There is no punishment for death. The only real punishment is wasting time traveling back to where you were. I managed to exploit dozens of big, tough enemies by dying, respawning, striking them twice then dying with one hit. Keep chipping away!Combat itself is easy and resorts to mouse clicking madness to attack. You've got a quick use toolbar that lets you use keys 0 - 9 to use things like spells and items. Even a quick mana or health recharge. Your three active spells are also in the toolbar. The right mouse button also uses whatever skill you've highlighted in the toolbar. Spells and arrows have lock on aim, which is nice, but you can turn it off if you'd like to miss 99% of the time. There are spell modifiers in the spell menu, things that reduce the cost of mana to doubling their effectiveness. Each spell is basically a card. The more of the same card you have equipped, the more damage it does. Spells felt very ineffective compared to physical melee.Leveling up gives you five attribute points to sink into health, attack, intelligence and dexterity. The dexterity felt useful, because it raises your attack and defense percentages, but it goes down over time making it feel wasted. You'll also get skill points to sink into several skills, most of which I never used. Skill points even seemed granted at odd times, making me think you get a point for every X amount of minutes played.While I got entertainment out of it for the exploration, I'm not sure that I can really recommend it to anyone else. I was surprised that I endured the first 4 hours. By the last 4 hours I was getting bored again. Its been $1 and free before...

content:
Posted: April 10, 2014
												Lets get the bad stuff out of the way first. BUGS. HOLY MOTHER OF GOD, THEY'RE EVERYWHERE. It's like an infestation of glitches of every kind: graphical (I'll talk about that later.), gameplay, combat and some are even game-breaking. Walk up stairs,  open a chest, and never walk down the stairs again due to the magical power of floating over noble gasses gained in the 11 seconds you spent raiding the poor farmer's pantry. Luckily, the game keeps a good list of autosaves to avoid these issues.Second biggest problem: the visuals are horrendous. I was walking through what I thought was a field of grass and happiness, when suddenly...bamboo. A whole forest of it, and I was walking through the center of the mighty wilds without even noticing. It took the game 10 minutes to process the enviroment fully. I could understand this if you were playing Mass Effect 3 on a Commodore 64, but with these extremely out-dated and pixely graphics, it should take less than 5 seconds on an average non-gaming computer.Oh, and don't bother talking to that drunk guy in Four Stones Village. His voice acting is even worse than the cook in the army camp named Bodlo, wh speaks in 3rd person and has the voice of a pig that was injected with both steriods and female hormones.With the bad parts aside, lets talk about why this game is actually worth the $10.00 asking price. Let's be posh and give you a list of blunt statements:- ALMOST 600 ARMOUR SETS, each with individual pieces: helmet, gauntlets, legs, torso, and boots.- 200 different weapons- Decent character customization (Though more hair options would be nice, other than just the 12 flavours of short available in 9 shades of brown.)- Very easy to pick up and play.- Puns of Damage. And lots of them. Some of them are even tolerable!- Large open world, with tons of shiny loot, though I wish more of it could be placed in your house...which you can't have.Over all, the hardcore gamer will find nothing of interest here. Fans of western RPG's will find an interesting mix of complete control over your character's destiny, and terrible, game breaking bugs such as randomly dying when you pick a lock to... A TENT? I can bloody see inside of it for the love of damn.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2013
												Really having a lot of fun with this 6 year old open world RPG (for the second time through), thanks to some great updates.Patches have made the game a lot more stable, bug free, and even better looking. Sure its not perfect, but neither is Skyrim if you really think about it (backwards flying dragons FTW). What TW does have is great visuals, deep player controlled character delopment, a lot of crafting/combining items into more powerful items,  tons of loot and a pretty good story thats fully voiced with a lot of optional side quests.Become any hero you want to be with no classes or weird♥♥♥♥♥leveling requirements.Theres 5 schools of magic with 25 spells (each) that all can be powered up and boosted, bows (with different ranges and different draw speeds) and 7 different melee type weapons (Axes 1h/2h, Pikes, Maces 1h/2h, Swords 1h/2h).As you level up  you'll get Paramater Points to spend on 4 attributes, Strength, Vitality, Willpower and Dexterity, but you'll also get a lot of points from finding rare items and making stat increasing potions. You start with everything at 5, but it might not be long until your skills are in the 100's, the sky is the limit (might actually be 1000, not sure).Also by gaining a level (or completing certain goals) you'll gain skill points to put into one of the games 38 skills. Like Beskering or Multiple Arrows, or sneaking and stabbing someone in the back.Walk around the huge map or fast travel via a teleportation system that you can set and move 3 points of, or  try horse riding with mounted combat.It's very much a complete game thats fun, and challenging, and something that YOU get to build your character in. Again, yes, it is rough around the edges... but the overall experience is definatly worth it.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												I would highly reccommend this game to anyone looking for RPG Adventure games similar to the Elder Scrolls Saga. Decent graphics considering it is from 2007. I greatly enjoy the open world format, although, sometimes inventory space is an issue, especially when hoarding materials for when you reach level 10 Alchemy (Skill initially learned from a trainer without enhancements you have ot be level 24 to max skill). So far I am 37 hours in and I think it has a Good Story line. The teleport side quest is exceedingly helpful in making sure you don't have to leave any loots behind. Slight lag when it autosaves but otherwise runs smoothly.  Biggest disappointment thus far has been the inability to pickpocket from the NPC's. Word of Advice to those interrested in this game, use caution and consult google before diving head on into using alchemy, permanent indregient aren't very easy to come by and the brewing system is not intuitive on how to best maximise thier use.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												Don't compare this game to Oblivion. Try Gothic 1, then compare games again... or try Arx Fatalis and come back.Two Worlds is a grand effort from a small team to try to make a game they'd want to play. A labor of love, so to speak. It's for that reason why I love the Gothic series (especially the third one).In Two Worlds, you don't get the feel and controls of a triple A game franchise. You get handcrafted, homecooked, delicious, awkward experimentation from gamers who love games.Remember Peter Jackson's first few movies? Would it surprise you to know that the guy who gave us all the Lord of the Rings movies started out just making random, insane films, like "Dead Alive" and "Meet the Feebles"? Innovation requires risk.Two Worlds does things a bit differently and that's what's worth taking notice of. Sure, horse controls are awkward, and your main character says "Mayhap" and "Perchance" enough times in the first hour to make you want to invent time travel and murder ancient languages... but keep playing.Keep playing and discover an absolutely massive world with very, very little loading time, and a Morrowind-esque combat system. I dislike the Oblivion comparison because that game was truly real-time and Two Worlds is more die-rolls and random chance based on skill percentages like Morrowind, Dungeons and Dragons, Shadowrun, and... well... 80% of CRPG's that have come out in the last 35 years.In summation:Voice acting: Bad to the point of comedic.Combat: Die rolls... not Oblivion.World: HOLY COW this thing is huge.Gameplay: Enough variation to keep me coming back.Horses: Not as good as Mount & Blade, but better than Ride to Hell Retribution.Replayability: Mayhap I should complete it once before I judge this.Two World's Epic Edition is of such quality that I can only compare it to Seth Rogen's "The Interview": A lot of people said a lot of things about it, but when I finally saw it for myself, I realized that people don't really know anything and I should just judge things for myself. It's not perfect, but I like it anyway.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												By far one of the most memorable and underrated RPGs ive ever played. This game recieved mostly all negative reviews on release and was hated by most critics. I didn't know any of this before I saw in an EB Games and picked it up for a cheap price on disk. Two Worlds is definitely a flawed game. The writing is♥♥♥♥♥♥ with everyone speaking in the old style english language that sounds ridiculous and out of place. On top of the writing is the atrocious voice acting (which is funny). The starting game cutscene even features writing where a character repeats a Monty Pyton quote word for word which is farcical. The devs also decided to use laughable names for certain things in the game, for example calling some sort of plague "The Taint". Two Worlds was also riddled with bugs on release (patched with expansions in Epic Edition) which didn't help at all in the way of reviews. Looking past those issues though, Two Worlds is an enjoyable experience. Reviews on Youtube do great in making this game look like a laughfest of asinine writing and technical flaws, but besides those issues, the game at its core is an ambitious underachiever which still succeeds in providing to the player for the most part. The main menu music was the first thing that stood out when I started the game, which complimented the pretty wonderful soundtrack. Two Worlds takes place in Antaloor, a mysterious and expansive setting that always kept me expecting more. I never felt like I was playing a walking simulator (even though the world is huge), nor did I feel like I was being attacked left and right. The game did nicely in striking a balance between a good amount of action and passive adventuring.  Two Worlds also includes a multiplayer component, with PvP and Co-op. I never really played it though because the population was mostly Eastern European, so English was pretty rare. The combination of the two leaves a lot for the player to do. Questing, exploring, looting, messing around, and kicking♥♥♥♥♥is always an option. The cities are big and populated, and felt very lively. I personally was in love with the variety of awesome armor and weapons, which is what I liked the most.You can also choose how you want to play, throughout the entirety of the game. There are no preset classes or anything, so you can play however you want to. You can play melee the whole game, or be a hybrid archer mage warrior. How you choose to fight is only limited by what you have in your inventory and your skill levels. The combat system is also one of the few ive experienced that actually works. The targeting system is automated which can be troublesome but rarely is it actually. You can't always button mash to win though, since you can easily die, but its satisfying and rewarding. The combat is nothing innovative nowadays, but it works and its fun. I always looked forward to what kind of loot I would find. I would be ecstatic when I would find a new piece of armor that made my character look lawesome. The graphics for it's time were decent at best. Far distance rendered poorly and the textures and effects were pretty basic but taking into account how expansive the world is, with all the different types of environments, it was justified. The armors and weapons did have pretty intricate details though. Even if you had to game maxed out and ran at 60fps plus, it still looked choppy thanks to the animations. Hours can easily be lost in this game when you realize all that there is to do in the game world. If you really choose to, you can hate this game. Two Worlds has quirky dialogs, a poor storyline, weird people, terrible voice acting, questionable sound choices (attacking someone with a sword plays punching sounds?) and ugly animations. To me, these issues were relatively unimportant, which is why I enjoyed the game as much as I did. Two Worlds always had something that allowed me to forgive it for its issues.So much in this game can be done in the way of customization and how you want to play. I still consider myself pretty lucky to have given this game a chance and I still remember experiences from 5+ years ago. To add, I can safely say I enjoyed this game just as much as any Elder Scrolls game, which seem to be the standard which any RPG is based on nowadays. Two Worlds lacks polish and is nowhere near perfect, but underneath all of the minor issues, is a gem. A gem of a game that is immensely underrated and misunderstood. Despite all you may read, this game is an immersive and rich experience that can leave you glued to your screen for hours. It's up to you to realize that not every game needs to be technically perfect, its how you appreciate it and your ability to see through the rough edges.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												Oh, where to begin? I could write a review equivalent in length to War and Peace if I wished to list fully everything that I wanted to say about this game, so I'll give two versions - one brief and one a bit more in-depth, take your pick. Here is the short version: Two Worlds EE is Skyrim with Oblivion graphics, there is as much to like about this game as there is to annoy, you need at least 3-4hrs in to start really enjoying it and remember, it's the first game from a small development team. That's the short version. For those who want a bit more info, read on. I went into this game, on the back of mixed reviews, not expecting a lot from it and was very pleasantly surprised by how much this game has going for it - yes, the graphics are a little outdated today, but it IS still a very pretty game overall  on max settings. Some of the scenery is beautifully breathtaking, but unfortunately pop-in and a fairly short draw distance does ruin it a little. And this is the story through the whole game. For every single thing I loved about this game, there was a downside - usually directly related to the thing I loved (such as the graphics example above). I loved the way the weapon/armour levelling system worked - downside, you never knew which items to keep (as there are literally hundreds  of both) and which to sell. I loved the diverse array of different environments on offer - downside, I spent 5-10mins exploring a new area and then half an hour putting stuff away to keep/save to sell in bulk, as you can build up your strength (helps with carrying), but once your inventory screen is full, you cannot carry anymore regardless of how much spare weight you can manage. I loved the large map, with virtually every environment you could think of in it - downside, there were parts where you wouldn't really have noticed if they weren't there (like empty stretches  of forest/grass/sand etc.) and mountain ranges devoid of everything and only 1 way up. I could go on and on, but you get the point.The best features of this game, in my humble opinion, are: Huge range of weapons/armour/enemies; lots of diverse environments (even the dungeons don't seem 'samey' after you've been in 4); Skyrim-like short main questline with lots of 'mini' npc quests; every time I started to feel invincible I encountered a new enemy (they level up with you) who either gave me a damn good fight or made me run off with my tail between my legs (to come back later with better weapons); the ability to play the game as a medieval Rambo, a wizard, an archer (sniper) type or indeed ANY combination of the three at any one time! The best thing loved was the fact that even at 100hrs in, with 90% of the (large) map covered and almost finished all the quests, I was not only not bored and looking at what to play next, but was STILL finding new places and enemies! And it's the ONLY game I've played where walking through snow actually sounds like walking through snow!!! There is more, I could also list a lot more downsides, but basically just (re-) read the short version above and if that appeals to you then this game is definately worth giving it some play time. I'm looking forward to playing Two Worlds II soon.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2016
												A decent role-playing game for those who enjoy exploration and looting.For some reason Two Worlds seemed to be mostly ignored by the gaming media. Perhaps because it did not have a very good marketing, hence it did not make a decent following before its release date. It was definitely not something it deserved. Two Worlds is an open-world RPG in a spirit of such games as Gothic and The Elder Scrolls. While it has many drawbacks, it certainly is a very enjoyable game at least for those players whom enjoy exploration and open-world games.The game has a very disappointing storyline that is boring and forgettable. It only serves as a background for a player to do stuff. NPCs are quite shallow and without characters too. In addition, dialogues are horrible, not only writing is unsatisfying, but also dubbing is horrid. Although it sometimes is quite entertaining, it’s so bad that it’s good as one might say. Nonetheless, it’s definitely not a reason to play this game.Two Worlds has some strong points though, and ultimately whether you will like the game or not depends how much you like exploration. If you love it as much as I do, then you will have a blast playing this game as it’s one of the better implemented exploration in RPGs. Not only locations are varied, but also there is no annoying level scaling of enemies or loot so prevalent in many modern RPGs and so annoyingly killing any challenge, joy and excitement out of discovering new lands. In Two Worlds you might encounter an enemy that is way above your level, however, if you are pertinacious enough, then you might kill them with use of some tricks anyway, but it might be a tough fight. Moreover, challenge is well worth it as loot that you might gain might make you more powerful. The game offers a huge gameworld and seems to be the first third person RPG that offers a decent horse riding and combat (Yes, you can fight while you are on a horse, unlike in Oblivion). Needless to say, that exploration is very satisfying, and so are combat encounters, although the combat itself is a bit too simple. However, in late game the player becomes too powerful and challenge perishes, unfortunately.To summarize, Two Worlds is an enjoyable exploration RPG, however, with some weaknesses. I recommend it to everyone who like open world role-playing games for wandering around and experiencing new discoveries. Do not expect a good story or interesting NPCs though, as these aspects are lousy and will fail to meet your expectations whatever they are.

Posted: May 29, 2015
												I know this game is far from perfect, but I really enjoyed playing through it (in 2012). I didn't like it much when I started playing, but after I got the hang of it I started to really like it. I sure never thought I'd get over 100 hrs out of it (not too bad for $5 I paid for it a few years ago). Two Worlds is an open world RPG with big open areas. It's like the Gothic/Risen games in the sense that when you kill an enemy it's dead for good, and that the world is sprinkled with some really tough enemies you'll have to level up, gear up and come back later to defeat it. The combat is mostly mindless button mashing, but it does a good enough job with it. One cool thing about this game is that you can combine weapons and armor that are the same, so eventually that weapon you first had turns out to be really good after some time. The story is alright with terrible-ish voice acting, but the game is setup good enough that I didn't pay a lot of attention to it. The graphics aren't great, but are good (for the year it came out) although the framerate was kind of choppy. This game was relaxing for the most part. It was good for zoning out and killing tons of enemies. I will admit that the last 10 hours I ran through quickly just so I could beat it and be done with it. My rating 7/10.

												I remember trying Two Worlds when it first came out years ago, and it was pretty horrible.  But I recently picked it up on sale and gave it a shot.  They really drop you in with absolutely no background, but you learn about the world very organically through conversations and quests.  These conversations are made through some of the most hilariously bad voiceovers I've heard, coupled with corny faux-fantasy writing.  But the style has kind of grown on me, and I am really enjoying the gameplay.  There's lots of loot, adventure, and exploration.  The character development is quite varied and interesting as well, with lots of playstyle options available.If you can get past the initial low-quality shock, there's a really fun RPG in here.  Be sure to install the Nvidia legacy Physx pack to be able to run it, it is not included in the install:  http://www.nvidia.com/object/physx-9.12.1031-legacy-driver.html

content:
Posted: April 23, 2014
												Two Worlds is a game that has the right intentions and was headed in the right direction – it just had a few stumbling blocks en route. If you can get past some of those obstacles, you will find a very solid and entertaining RPG that will eat up a lot of hours.Two Worlds is worth a play, but only if you've exhausted the competition. And invested in ear plugs for when the characters start talking.To its credit, Two Worlds dares to be less conventional than Oblivion, but it's not nearly as polished in any regard. The unbalanced difficulty makes for a frustrating first few hours, and there's little incentive to return to the game after completing the main story line.It's a solid effort that may not bring a lot of ingenuity to the fantasy RPG genre, but still provides many hours of entertainment.Two Worlds succeeds at what it sets out to provide – a poor man’s Oblivion and a simple, unrestrictive introduction to role playing games. Overall 7/10.

content:
Posted: February 14
												I liked Two Worlds. Mechanically, I'd even say there's not a single thing that Two Worlds does badly. But I can't recommend it."Raining again?"- Your nameless heroAs with all massive open-world aRPGs, your various playstyles play so differently while being the bulk of the gameplay that no two people can be said to be playing the game. So here's the game I played: major emphasis on two-handed weapons and heavy plate armour, used traps to disable large foes and projectile spells to stun archers to get in close. Looted every enemy to get them to despawn to avoid any memory leaks (somehow not an issue in this game but I wasn't taking any chances), explored all the landmarks and most road-based locations but didn't fully 100% the map. Played on Hard, which made the combat much more hectic and enjoyable.The core melee gameplay of crowd control, using the i-framed backstep and fishing for criticals, while using the tertiary skills like traps and spells, was legitimately fun. It more than carried the game, and even when taking on enemies and hordes who will happily stunlock or one-shot you on Hard, you're never really in over your head so long as you're quick on your feet and quicker on the hotbar. Skill resetting/regression isn't just there but encouraged (although not free), more than urging you to try out new builds and playstyles and recover from bad ones.Art-design wise, nobody really has a neck and the pauldrons are about 3 times the size over the legal limit, but apart from some truly ugly mid-tier armour it's fairly nice to look at. Soundtrack, likewise, is generic but not bad."Ugh, it's raining."- Your hero, who shall not be named.Where Two Worlds really shines, though, is in the superficial systems and aspects. Best presented through some examples:You have fast-travel, but it can only be unlocked through a questline and you can only fast-travel to places you've been before. The convenience is there, but earned, and is probably the best fast-travel in an RPG outside of Morrowind's infamous but lore-godly commutes.You can "stack" weapons and armour of exactly the same type to slightly upgrade its "class", granting you higher stats. This means that even lategame, when you've finally gotten a matching set of armour, there's more than enough incentive to continue spending money on matching items to upgrade the stats. Inherent boosts like strength or HP upgrades are carried over too, resulting in some endgame outfits that will happily double your stats. "Stacking" applies to spells too - from the spells themselves to spell boosters. This works in exactly the same way and is just as incentivized, although getting endgame viable spell combos is an uphill battle.The map design is godly. Although not quite as much terrain variety as one might like, the precise use of verticality sees you frequently seeing certain or even every other major city and landmark in the game, something that never gets old and really grounds the entire world. Quest design, though conventional, is never lazy or boring and the voice-acting - especially with your miscast villian of a main character with his Christopher Walken-tier ham - is incredible to listen to.These are just examples, and the list of examples goes on (without touching on the indepth alchemy or the enemy spawn system). It is with sincere regret that I look back at the dozens of hours spent playing this game, with its many high points, just to be brought right down low by a single low one."It's rainiiiiiiiing."- Hero Schmero Gero LeroIt runs badly.This is a core performance issue. Regardless of whether internal or external tools tell you it's running smoothly at 60+ FPS, there's a subtle "stuttering" that continuously happens wherever you walk (and is greatly exacerbated by horse travel). I've looked up gameplay of other users playing the game, tried every fix that's come to mind, this is core and universal and kneecaps any thought of recommending the game.Certainly not helped by the animations running at low framerates independent of the game, all this combines to make Two Worlds nauseating to play for any length of time. The whole game. And it is beyond sad that a game that does so much right, does so much that's interesting, is brought to its knees by this single, fatal, Achille's heel of a flaw.To further damn the game, I got some frequent crash to desktops that the saving system made easy to deal with, and the ending FMVs failed to trigger at all, just booting me back to the desktop after I beat that joke of a final boss.I looked them up on Youtube afterwards, they were pretty bad but you do get to see how the models in the FMVs look substantially worse than the ones in the game proper, which is always fun."Hmm. Looks like it's raining."- McHeroes the ZeroesSo that's Two Worlds. A tragic hero of a game. To be mourned but not necessarily played. If you have the grit and immunity to every form of motion-sickness, eye-strain and aversion to giant pauldrons there is, there's a gem of an aRPG here that might've ranked with some of my favourites in a different world. If you don't, and don't have the dogged determination to see a sickening gem to the very end to write a cool review about it, then sorry to say, but you should just move on.And certainly don't play it while hungover, that's just a mistake.If anyone has a fix for that stuttering please comment with it and I'll gladly just delete this review. Or at least majorly edit it to be a big ol' thumbs up. I sincerely, sincerely want to recommend this game. But as is, I just can't.Temp Edit:Someone posted that forcing v-sync will amend the stuttering. Will confirm myself, had problems first time through.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2014
												Regarded as one of the worst games ever created by many, I found this game to be highly enjoyable. The combat system has its faults, but the ability to become a mage-warrior had an appeal to me, and it was fun to play through the map in that role. Pros:Diverse landscapes including; snow, desert, meadows, mountains, hellish regions, beaches, forests.Extremely intricate skill system. Enormous map to explore, with many dungeons each of which different from the last. Hundreds of different armor sets and weapon choices make customizing your character easy to suit your needs. Hundreds of quests ranging from the classic fetch quest, to more detailed ones where your choices will play a role down the line.Great combat system for warriors, mages, and archers alike.Great variety of enemies to fight; humans, orcs, dragons, wyverns, raptors, wolves, and many more created just for the game that can be found in the bamboo forests, deserts, and beaches to name a few. Cons:Terrible voice acting. Same battles over and over.At a certain level combat just becomes too easy, especially with the "Restore Health" spell that fully heals you at the cost of barely any Mana.Overall, while I probably wouldn't purchase this game for its retail price, I would buy it if it was under $5. I have about 30 hours at the time of this review, and while I've been done with the main story line for a while I feel I definitely got my money out of it.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												First impressions were not good; the game doesn't look all the great (faces are terrible), sounds worse (nice soundtrack though), plays poorly at times (especially on horseback), and doesn't have much of a tutorial beyond "use WASD to move, click to attack, okay, off you go!".Despite all that though, I just can't stop playing. The world is vast, varied and full of different things to slay and quests to do, and the best part is that you learn everything organically rather than having all the lore shoved down your throat. Combat is a little underwhelming, but there are lots of spells, abilities and tons and tons of equipment to help add flavour.The only gripe I have with the game is that despite this being a ROLE PLAYING game, you don't really get the chance to play any role in the side quests beyond "mercenary only motived by gold" which is disappointing because it diminishes the replay value of the game and makes you feel like you don't really have an impact on the world besides checking off a list.Overall, its great game if you can look pass some of its rough edges and well worth your time and money. If you find yourself hating the game in the first half an hour like I did, just give it some more time; you don't want to miss out on this experience.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2015
Good game, couple of flawsThis is a well made game. It's a bit linear as you have to do certain story parts to open up new areas. It does have replayability however, as you will pick one path and then try another path the second, third time. It's great to be a caster and attack a horde of orcs or a dragon with 8 conjured minions. I have primarily played a mage in this game up to a pretty high level. I did archer for quite some time as well, but it gets repetitive and is actually tougher than the mage. Thief is useless. The game doesn't force you into one of these archetypes, you are free to mix / match skills, but a hybrid in this game is weaker than a pure character. The game is good enough that I bother to write a review so that others will try this game.Flaws: 1) Magic card system is weak. During combat, a caster is opening the magic window every few seconds to swap spell cards or enhancement cards. That said, the magic in this game is well thought out and looks great. I love my summoning demon bud!2) Item collection becomes tedious and at higher levels you just give up on it. Early in the game you almost obsess over it. Later, you ignore all but the most intriguing items.3) AI is weak. Mostly get bushwacked and charged. But, combat is interesting and looks great.4) Sneaking is useless.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												In some ways, this game is better than Oblivion, the main competitor in the open-world fantasy genre, but there are quite a few issues and a real lack of polish that prevents the game from reaching its full potential.The main gripe is combat. At later levels, the game becomes severely punishing. Now I don't mind difficulty, but this game likes  to suddenly throw overpowered monsters at you without warning. High level monster scale rediculously well. They will have a few times your health and do a couple times your damage. If you want to be able to take on high level challenges, you either have to grind out a lot of levels, which is done by killing monsters MMO style or through quests, or invest in the severely flawed magic system.One can understand why the monster are so strong when one takes a look at what spells are available to the player. While finding the exact spell you want is nearly impossible, getting hands on any higher level spells makes your power level spike like crazy. I was able to get my hands on a reflect aura in the earth magic school. By abusing the magic system, I was able to get my reflect spell to reflect 70% of all damage. You heard that right, 70%. It seems the game will assume your use of of magic. By throwing out rediculous monsters, it forces you to be a sort of mage-warrior no matter what.The leveling system in this game is actually more interesting than that of Oblivion's. There are a myriad of skills that can be learned, and the aforementioned magic system provides a bunch of really cool spells. Unfortunately, in terms of melee combat the game seems to favor two-handed weapons. The advantage of dual-wielding or using a sword and shield is the ability to parry attacks (done automatically). But one quickly realizes that isn't not worth it. It's far better to abuse the two-handed weapon's long range and simply physically avoid the ennemy blows, rather than nibling away at the enemy with the extremely short ranged one-handed weapons and relying on the dice to block strikes. It doesn't help that two-handed weapons all seem to deal double the damage of one handed weapons. In a role-playing game, the player should never be forced to do something. All roles should be equally valid. Whether that be a mighty barbarian or a graceful duelist. But the game funnels you down a single path. With some more polish and a better balanced combat and magic system, I might have really enjoyed this game. But these gaping issues ruined it for me.

content:
Posted: April 2, 2016
												two worlds has become one of my favorite games ever, and noone is more surprised than me. first of all, I didn't start playing fantasy rpgs until a few years ago, they always looked too generic and boring, plus I really hated everything, and I mean everything, about the two worlds demo. but thankfully I gave it another shot and had a ton of fun playing it.it's not a perfect game by any means, but also very far from the trainwreck a lot of reviews make it out to be. the graphics still hold up, the viewing distance is really amazing, you can see stuff in the distance from really far away (yet grass seems to grow under your feet, which is one of the very few complaints I have). the music's great too and the voice acting falls into the so-bad-it's-hilarious category. it was grating at first but became entertaining soon, the over the top usage of 'olde english', the protagonist's sarcastic remarks and taunts like 'say hello to death!' or 'they look like my in-laws'.some of the mechanics are pretty interesting too: you can use a bunch of active skills during combat (after you learned them from trainers) and there's a jump back button, which is essential against bigger but slower enemies. there are horses, but I found them only useful as inventory extentions, just park them next to a teleport and you're good. riding on the road is actually fine, but as soon as you go off-road, it's hell. you can probably get the hang of it eventually, but with a generous amount of static teleports and your personal teleport stones you don't really need a mount to get around. sprinting would've been nice though, even if you run faster with your weapons put away.speaking of weapons and gear, you can combine multiple copies of the same items to make them more powerful, which is great, and also makes inventory management easier. there's a crazy amount of loot in the game though, with a lot of variety in everything, so multiple trips to merchants will be necessary to grab and sell everything. I wouldn't have minded a third inventory screen, actually.there's also magic and bows (no need to worry about arrows) and I'd say combat is good enough, you can mix things up, though it can get a bit hectic because aggroing an enemy usually mobilizes their friends as well. but most importantly (for me anyway), the game doesn't have respawning enemies (there's a ghost mechanic though that's explained in the game, but it's only troublesome in the beginning) nor level scaling, which can make for one-hit deaths early on if you run into something far above your level.the alchemy system is pretty good too, you can make temporary and permanent potions and gems from almost everything, plants, monster drops, minerals, and they really make a difference. if you're into exploring and hoarding, you can become so powerful that almost everything will die in a few hits. this might be a problem for some, but you don't have to make potions, obviously, and you don't have to kill every wolf you run into for even more xp. that's what I did though: I can't remember the last game where I wanted to explore absolutely everything and where exploration was so relaxing even with literally thousands of enemies around. I'm not one for farming and grinding, but I killed them all (more than 10.000) while I was at it. I wouldn't say the game world is especially unique, though later on you'll run into some weird creatures and unsettling environments.there are a lot of quests, some of them are pretty basic, some are more involved, and sometimes you have to make a decision, you can't complete everything (though it's possible to have max reputation with all the factions at the same time until you anger them). the main story is nothing to write home about, your sister's missing, go find her, oh, and save the world in the meantime, will you? the game shines in the sidequest department though. there are a few funny ones, some are touching, and they can have unforeseen consequences. you think you're done and did the right thing, but when you go back to the village or npc later, you'll find you actually made things worse. I loved these.I could go on for days about the game but I'm sure these reviews have a character limit, so I'll stop before I get too much into it. long story short, if you're looking for an open-world fantasy rpg you probably haven't played, check this one out. if you want to do everything, it'll keep you busy for more than 100 hours (or you can just concentrate on questing and be done a lot faster).

												Two Worlds is a tough game. The voice acting, horse-riding and combat at times, is all very♥♥♥♥♥♥ Sometimes they have their moments but most of the time they struggke to reach average. But if you can somehow get past the inital crap then you find a gem.Two Worlds is surprisingly deep, with a intriguing, large  and beautiful world.The armor and weapons that you find start off looking rather dumb but soon you start finding very epic looking swords and axes, awesome spiked plate armor, damn i really liked one set of armor that i kept it for far longer then i should of, making the game harder then it should of been.The crafting system in Two Worlds is very simple, just drag and drop, but i felt it went very well with the style of game and allowd even weaker waepons to stay strong with a little extra effort.Alchemy is done well in the game as well, with you being able to craft many different potions of different effects out of many different ingrediants.And the world, i really enjoyed just exploring the massive world and slaughtering the all bandits and helpless animals i came across.I reccomend Two Worlds but know that many people will not be able to get over its flaws.If realty pump only had a little extra funding or more time or whatever, they could of made a truely epic game.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												This is quite possibly my all time favorite game.  I've now bought it for myself 3 different times (Once on xbox, once in disk form for the PC, and once on steam), and even gifted several copies on Reddit.  It is astoundingly deep, and has some neat stacking mechanics that I thoroughly enjoyed.  However, since I don't want someone reading this review, getting the game and going in blind, I don't want to sugarcoat it.  The first 30 minutes are miserable.  Maybe even the first couple hours.  It has possibly the worst first impression of any game I've ever played.  The animations aren't particularly smooth, giving it a pretty cheap feeling, the graphics aren't great, even for 2009 (though the scale is huge), the voice acting is atrocious, and there are parts of the game that they get incredibly wrong that seem like simple mechanics (Horse Riding and Archery) - and yet, if you give it a few hours, I think it's brilliance shines through, and would hook anyone that likes the genre.There are tons of different environments - You've got your standard medieval knights, forests, swamps, caves and dungeons.  There's a Samurai land with giant starship troopers like bugs.  Creepy cults and necromancy.  Desert nomad lands, and dune like worms.  Cities are massive, and you can go in almost every house, with worthwhile loot in most of them.  You can create permanent stat gain potions to a ridiculous degree allowing anyone that wants to become a demigod to do so.  Finding extra copies of the same spell don't just become useless inventory items, each new copy you find stacks on previous ones making them stronger, in fact you can do the same with items in the game.  You could go around killing the easiest enemies in the game, stacking hundreds of their clubs, and have a decent weapon for a while just from that.  Speaking of items, the sheer amount of them is crazy.  Where there might be 20 unique weapons in Skyrim there are hundreds in this game, and hundreds of armor items as well.  You can look like a samurai warrior, a monk, an evil wizard or a menacing black knight.   I have never found a game like this (even the sequel in my opinion, while fun, pales in comparison), it is really incredible, you just have to struggle through a bit of muck before it will shine, but I can guarantee if you wade through it, it's a game you wont forget.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												One could say that for every two things  Two Worlds  did right, there's one thing it did wrong.  In my opinion, it still deserves a positive rating (especially since you can now get it for free on DLH.net), but let's talk about some of the aspects.The in-game world is beautiful; full of interesting locations to visit and a variety of things to do. There is also a simple ("simple" doesn't equal "bad", mind you!) skill tree, so you can choose your play style: an elemental wizard, a Necromancer, a warrior, an archer or even sort of a stealthy "bandit"... or a mix of them all, just like it should be in every decent RPG.Sadly, there are basically no "flavor" dialogue options to go along with your character. You can accept or refuse a quest, you can even choose whom you want to side with on multiple occasions, but you can only do it one way. The developers were reasonable enough to give the Hero a neutral attitude, but the "role-playing" part suffers from this. Even if it wouldn't affect the actuall outcome in any way, it'd be good if they gave us more dialogue choices.The questing is fun at first, but as you are nearing the end of the storyline, it becomes a bit dull. There are still many places to explore, but you sort of don't care anymore. The side quests aren't bad, they're just missing that little something, the twist that would keep you interested. As a part of your questing, you can gain or lose reputation with multiple factions. The only real benefit of having the max reputation with the factions, though, is to be able to do their quests and advance in the story (their merchants also give you more money for the things you sell them, but earning money is incredibly easy in the game anyway).Then there's the combat system. You grab a weapon of your choice, distribute some talent points (which you get for doing various stuff thorough the game) and start slaying whomever and whatever needs to be slain. As you eventually grow stronger, you'll start noticing that fighting is terribly repetitive. There are monsters that require absolutely no effort whatsoever to slay, and there are monsters that are still fairly easy to defeat, but can kill you in one or two hits, so you have to kite them. And then there are archers who are insanely annoying to fight if you don't have any range weapon. Luckily, there aren't many of those.The character models,  animations and the voice acting get criticised by almost everyone, but I had no big issues with those.On occasions, the NPCs do sound a bit funny, but it happens even in modern games. It's not as horrendous as people claim it to be.What I did have a big problem with, however, was the lack of any sort of ending. After you have dealt with the bad guy in either of the two possible ways, the game just returns you to the main menu. Just like that. No epilogue, no final cutscene, no further info on the in-game events, not even a glimpse of the Big Bad's (dis)graceful demise... nothing. Huge disappointment!All in all, it feels as if the developers implemented a whole lot of great ideas, but none of them got enough attention to fulfil its potential.  Two Worlds  is still a pretty fine game, really worth your time  if you enjoy RPGs. It's just not as great as it could have been.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2016
												After having this game back in the heady days of the Xbox 360 I spotted it on sale and thought I would give it another whirl.I'll start with the bad points:- Combat becomes quickly repetitive- Insane difficulty curve in new areas, but strangely coupled with a resurrection mechanic which removes challenge from the game- Graphics are poor, even for the time period it was produced, gameplay is actually better than the cutscenes!- You will often see several of the same character model in an area- Voice acting is terrible, filled with medieval words such as "Mayhap, perchance, T'would" etc, with about 10 different voice actors ("Oblivionitis")- Main plot is a non-starter for me, I had completely forgotten what it even was after a few hours- Multiplayer is completely broken, don't even bother- Many buildings are just *there* as artwork on the landscapes- Horse combat is lauded up in this game, but riding a horse is about as easy as flying a helicopter when its attempting to lift a merry-go-round with an elephant on one side Phew.Okay, onto the good stuff:- The game world is HUGE- Many towns/settlements in the game, and they actually feel populated with lots of NPCs milling around- There are hundreds of side quests to complete, not just simple fetch or kill quests but lots of different types, including assassinations in which you can double cross the original quest giver- Multiple clans/houses to gain respect with (or gain a bad reputation with)- Probably thousands of armour/clothing combinations- The weapon/armour upgrade system makes alot of sense and is easy to use- Magic system is simple to use yet deep, with power up cards and multiple schools of magic available- The soundtrack isnt half bad either- THE VOICE ACTING IS SO BAD ITS HYSTERICALLY FUNNYI personally really liked TW, as it provides at its heart a good RPG experience and it is trying hard. It does however have a lot of issues, so if you can get it on sale - go for it.

number of helpful: 8 of 8 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
												This game really is a Diamond in the rough or perhaps it's a rough surrounded by Diamonds, at any rate this game is great fun and a giant step away from your typical RPG experience. It wreaks of originality and has a style of it's own and isn't afraid to flaunt it.  This game caught a lot of flak due to how it strives for originality in it's own obscure way. People complained about the voice acting, but really, I feel these people just struggled to digest an approach totally foreign and new to the genre and this conflicted with their usual expectations of what an RPG should be, but Two worlds broke the mold and I can appreciate that. The style, characters and atmosphere in Antaloor gives you an immediate feeling of a strange yet authentic medieval culture. People talk strangely to one another, but the more time you spend in Antaloor, the less strange it becomes and begins to feel genuine and relatable. Sure there are some awkward dialogues and the VA can be a little hit-and-miss, but overall it's laden with intrinsic value and thoroughly enjoyable.  Even the combat is strange, strangely enjoyable though. Combat feels impactful and organic, albeit a little clunky. There's a good balance of combat techniques you can use, with a good mix of Archery, Melee and magic. Archery mechanics are done quite well and you'll often find yourself trying to snipe tough enemies or pull them towards you in a more orchestrated attack.  But one of the more interesting aspects of Two worlds, at least to me, is how gear actually stacks! Essentially, instead of finding one rare or unique armor or weapon, you are able to find multiples of the same type and combine it into your original piece making it's stats ever more powerful Muahahahahah! So once you've found something nice, it quickly becomes an obsession to track down more items of the same type- but don't be fooled! It must be the exact same "breed" of item. You will find many different versions of items but to "stack" they need to be of the same family, i think this is reflected by a number as well as the aesthetic of the item.  Lastly, this game is a loot-♥♥♥♥♥'s wet dream. You'll be constantly on the hunt for more items to help you grow in power, but as discussed above. not in the traditional way and you'll also be on the hunt for a Steed capable of hauling your massive collection of weapons and armors around and spend countless hours deciding which stuff to keep and which to sell. Speaking of selling, this game is also a Merchants wet dream and I surprised myself at how much time I spent traveling to strange new towns with a glimmer of hope in my eye that the traders there would have yet another piece I could stack together. There's probably a lot more I could say about this game, but that could take all day and I want to play games! It also probably goes without saying that my Steam hours played does not represent my actual play time in this game. Two worlds is a bit rough around the edges, but there's more than enough goodness to compensate. Good for at least a few hundred hours, I recommend it!

number of helpful: 11 of 14 people (79%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												I once asked an online forum whether Two Worlds was any good.  Among the sea of negative responses was a single positive vote for the game.  I asked that one person why he or she liked the game and the response was, "I don't know, I just love the open-worldiness of the game."Open-worldiness is an apt description of Two World's major strength.  After a quick and painless tutorial you are given a couple quests and off you go.  The world is yours to explore.  If you like games like this, then you may like Two Worlds too.The major negative about this game is, in spite of the huge world, there just isn't a lot to explore.  Compared to a game like Elder Scrolls Oblivion with quests and dungeons around every corner, Two Worlds feels like Oblivion on a stringent budget.  You'll often run into the same creatures and bandits.  These creatures are challenging at first, but terribly easy to beat in later levels.  By the time you cross a certain place in the map to face more challenging creatures, you've already progressed to the point where those are easy to beat.Dungeons are few and not very memorable.  Worse yet, there doesn't seem to be a point to them.  The joy you get from getting to the end of a long dungeon and getting that memorable item you wanted is not present in this game.  They seem more like an afterthought.  A couple of corridors filled with the same enemies who mostly run straight at you swinging once  you are spotted.Combat in general is lackluster, your most used ability is jumping backwards to dodge swings.  Once you've learned this skill, melee combat becomes a breeze and your only difficulty comes from the occasional archers and mages.  I once took down a Cyclops, one of the largest and toughest enemies in the game, simply by jumping backwards and getting a hit or two in before he could swing again.  A single hit would have killed me but I was still able to defeat it.  If you come to Two Worlds looking for tough combat, you're not going to find it.I do enjoy the armor "crafting" and upgrading.  Simply find an identical piece of armor, drop it over your existing armor and you have a stronger piece or armor.  The same can be done with weapons.  Skill upgrades are plenty with skills ranging from five classes of magic (earth, air, fire, water, necromancy) to specialize in to multiple weapons, armor, and archery skills and buffs.  You are not forced into any one class so you may mix and match as you choose, a nice feature of the game.  Tip: Lockpicking is a must as nearly every valuable item is hidden away in a locked chest.Alchemy, on the other hand, is a complete mess and does not work they way it is instructed in the manual.  For all the plants and minerals you collect in your travels, each labeled with a specific buff or permanent upgrade, they don't provide much use unless you have maxed the alchemy skill.  Personally, I kept the items that gave permanent upgrades and never used the rest.  Tip:  You MUST include a health or mana potion when combining minerals or you will not get the upgrades you want.In short, this may be a game you'll enjoy if you like the freedom to explore and upgrade your skills to suit the fighting style you enjoy.  Just expect to get bored of the combat and the limited content before the story ends. - - -Edit:  A warning.  This game requires registration of a CD key Steam provides you in order to work.  Fortunately, the servers are still online and they provide you with a nice piece of gear for doing so.  Not bad for a seven year old game.  (Hear that EA?!?!)  Also, this game uses an old version of PhysX drivers that the latest drivers do not support.  Nvidia card users need to download and install the old drivers from this website in order to get the game to work: http://www.nvidia.com/object/physx-9.12.1031-legacy-driver.html
