content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												I've been playing Two Worlds for the better part of 40 hours and I am loving it!  It's not Skyrim, DragonAge, or The Witcher, but I'm finding it to be a deeply interesting and fun RPG to play.  It has a well developed world full of warring factions, magic, skills, and horse back riding.  I actually like the horse back riding better in Two Worlds than in Skyrim (IMHO).  The questing in my mind is what is the most fun in this game.  Two Worlds is loaded with cities, caves, dungeons, and quests to complete.  This is not an expensive game and I've seen it goes as low as 1.49.  This game has issues and some very quirky dialogue, but I still recommend it.  I could have finished the main quest 15 hours ago, but I'm having too much fun with the side quests.  I've seen a lot of bad reviews for this game and I can understand some of the complaints, but I find this game so much fun and the quirks and bugs just simply don't bother me.  "Lovely weather" said the hero as he stormed through the rain shower that just popped up.  Love It!

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												The game is a classic. Absolute trash, but a classic.If you're even looking into acquiring this game, then you already know what you're getting yourself into. It's glitchy. It's ugly. It's bogged down, and unrefined, and somehow perfect. It is NOT a good game -- not by any measure -- but it is a supremely unique, memorable experience.Everything is so poorly crafted that not a single moment is dull. You will never cease to be surprised by all the little bits of awfulness tucked throughout the world of "Antaloor". Everything from the clownish bear animations to the random-guy-off-the-street voice acting will keep you grinning from beginning to whenever you get bored and shut it off.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
												Two worlds is unique game because you'll hate it and love it the same time but after first hour you would't dare to stop before finishing it. Two worlds has many problems from unstable frame rate and game not launching to horrible horse riding and even worse mounted combat. There are not nearly enough tutorials and you'll end up checking forums every now and then. Combat can be bit difficult at first but after you'll get used to it and learn to use "Q" button to dodge at the right time it will be almost too easy, almost. Alchemy is extremely well done and magic is better than some games, but offers 5 schools of magic whit each unique spells, but still each having similar basic spells so you don't have to learn everyone to get attack, defense and summoning spells but should if you're playing as a mage.What makes fighting difficult sometimes is that two worlds allows a lot of enemies at once, for instance in the orc capital you might have to face 50+ enemies at once, while they're fighting each other too. Story is not the best but the quests are unique and not repetitive as well as bountiful. Enemies offer wide range of fighting styles and some variation between same enemy types, for instance wolf will fight differently than zombie and bandit archer will fight differently than bandit mage. Overall I'll recommend Two Worlds as it will give you 30+ hours of gameplay, but only if you like open world games and are a fan of RPGs and can look over some unpolished bits in favor of overall experience.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
												A great game, very underrated. In many respects similar to an Elder Scrolls game with the same freedom of movement, collecting alchemy ingredients, running around doing quests, and the same sense towards the end of the game that you can destroy everything with ease.Enemies tend to be in either groups of average strength or single or pairs of overwhelming strong enemies. They have to be managed differently, and archery is actually very usefull especialy when facing large number of archers who can disarm you and do decent levels of damage.The first 30 minutes of the game is a grind but get past that and the game becomes very enjoyable.One of the really enjoyable things about the game is that the guards of towns are no stronger than they should be. So if you are able to take down a cyclops or slay a dragon you don't get the sillyness of guards being able to bash you up. In fact if you want you can rampage through the world slaying everyone and reserecting people afterwards. It's slightly over the top but it really adds to the enjoyment.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2015
												Back in 2006, Elder Scrolls: Oblivion was the most popular open-world RPG, but a year later, Two Worlds was released, and the RPG fans wonder how much batter it would be.Well, 8 years have passed and Two Worlds remains forever in Oblivion’s shadow. Above all negative towers this Reality Pump release, the story-line gets the worst part. Not-so-epic, and somehow basic, we take the role of a traveller searching for his sister who is mysteriously kidnaped. After being approached by a strange man who leads us to the main quest, we start our journey only to realise the side-quests are actually more interesting. Despise all the shortness, the main-quest encourages the player to explorer the kingdom, complete site-quests, gain reputation among the several available factions, choose a side among the war against the orcs, and discover new areas.Much like Gothic series, this action RPG gives you the freedom to explore the world as you want, with an amazing combat system that puts you to the test by fighting bandits, goblins, wild animals, Cyclops, and many other creatures we are used to encounter in this genres. Getting yourself in the wrong side of the map might lead you to difficult enemies, but with great rewards worth the trouble.Two Worlds offers a simple and interesting system where the player can create new items by cooking all sort of organic and magic objects. Mixing up till 5, the result may be different each time you tweak with the items, but you get to keep all the recipes for future use. New potions with a lot of different results are the most common, this will certainly make the game a lot easier, since harvesting items can be done pretty much everywhere. You can’t craft new weapons, but you can upgrade them, and that’s good enough. There’s plenty to choose from the vast variety of armour-sets, swords, staffs, and many more powerful objects to kill all those evil Golems!The player also relies on magic, and for that the levelling up is great, choose among the 5 elements, and advance your combat skills and how well you manoeuvre your weapons.Although the gameplay is flawless and the graphics try to keep with it, the major problem falls upon the text-dialogue. NPC are just repetitive, in both appearance and dialogues, and that’s really a shame, because some actually tell you interesting things about the world of Two Worlds. It’s a big map, but very repetitive, even with snow, desert and deep forests, the game lacks on dungeons with only a handful of them to complete and loot. Small huts and villages with hidden secrets might be your salvation after a long walk throughout the world. With great emphasis on side-quests, your journey won’t be a waste of time, and in time you may learn to enjoy it.One of those games where you love it or hate it. Can’t go medium with this one, it’s made for RPG fans. Unless you are one, stay way.Could be batter, but could be a lot worst considering all things! 6/10.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2016
												The first hour of playing this game leaves you with a poor sensation of what it is. When you have gone beyond that point, it's actually really enjoyable.The old-fashioned graphics, the dozens of exploits and odd characters gives the game a nice atmosphere.The crafting and magic aspect is great once you get into it.You can freely choose how the story will unfold and often you get the choice to continue helping certain NPC's or kill/betray them to help others instead.The item and loot system is decent, but the ability to stack armor and weapons to improve the gear and save space is really brilliant. The fights can be somewhat clunky at times with certain skills/weapon combinations, although it can easily be avoided.The horse-mechanics are annoying, but they have other uses besides transportation.Quest can sometimes be rather vague in describtion, but compared to how easy they usually are these days, it can be a nice change of pace for some.*Watch out for the random spider spawns in Cathalon, they are terrifying.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2016
												This is like the video game version of a B-movie.  Is it a good game?  No.  Did I still have fun with it?  Yes.  It’s a classic case of “so bad it’s good”.This game gets almost everything wrong.  From the horribly written dialogue, to the terrible voice acting, and even the almost unplayable combat, this game is hard to love.  It can also be unclear what you have to do sometimes, but luckily there’s a good number of guides for this game online.  Really the only thing I thought this game did well was the magic system.  There’s plenty of spells and they’re all really diverse.  Between shooting projectiles, giving yourself buffs and the enemy debuffs, and summoning creatures to help you fight, magic is definitely the funniest combat system to play with.Considering I bought this game for about $1 USD, I would say that it was well worth the price.  If you can wait for a sale and pick this up, and forgive its flaws, you can absolutely have some fun with this game.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
												I'll probably complete this review when I'll complete it, but since I noticed it's on sale at 90% off (0.99€ here) and I just started playing it, I just wanted to give it my thumbs up with a quick review after about 23 hours of game time.I was very dubious if to waste my time on this since the mixed reviews, but I'm happy that I didn't listen.You're not always ready for some game that will take your life away for months or years to come, so if you still want to play a relatively modern and open-world RPG without the need to take weeks to learn how things work and how to craft stuff, this might just be the game for you.There's plenty of items in this game, and you can choose your own path into anything (warrior, mage and so on) upgrade after upgrade, to shape your character into what you want without having to decide that at the start of the game, but without becoming too complicated. Sure, the game don't tell you basically anything about how anything works, but you can always read the pdf manual that Steam gives you and find all the details there, but anyway, after just 1.5 hours I already was going through the menus without problems and without ever reading the manual.There's stuff you'll learn with practice or by trial and error, but if you don't want to read that pdf you can consider it like an adventure in the adventure :)One very useful thing that the game don't tell you (or I didn't notice) is that you can merge 2 identical items into a better one by just drag and dropping one onto the other one, while in your inventory. That way you can improve your current equipment for free, without the need to buy a better one.Now I just hope I won't hit that quest bug that another user experienced, that seem to happen because some side-quests can break the main quest if done before it, but I'm trying to not let the main quest behind too much and I hope that'll be enough.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2, 2015
												This game is an underrated gem, I recommend it highly to any fan of open-world RPGs. It's biggest hurdle is just its first impression. The character creation is a joke, the cut-scenes & voice-acting are hammy, the controls and menu navigation a bit unintuitive, initially.However, give this game an hour or two to grow on you, and you will find a vastly underrated, very free, open-world fantasy RPG that will give you hundreds of hours of enjoyment. The loot is vast and randomly generated (and items are stackable, which means looting never gets entirely old); the levelling is well-paced and addictive; the scope of abilities interesting to experiment with (archery, traps, magic, various combat techniques, etc.)  The alchemy/crystal system is very interesting as well, though you might want to download a strategy guide to get the most out of it.Combat and enemy AI are weak and relatively easy to exploit, but that didn't bother me much -- I just view the game as more of a Diablo-esque, loot-driven kind of experience, vs. a game built around challenging/nuanced combat. And although the story and voice-acting initially seem awful, the cheesiness of it becomes a part of the charm, and the protagonist is often actually very funny. He becomes strangely good company as you go roaming the world by yourself. Visually, the game holds up exceptionally well, if you have a good graphics card. I don't know if the graphics were revamped for the epic edition, but at times the game looks on a par with a high-end Skyrim, and the world can be quite beautiful. There is also a ton of detail in the armor, weapons, etc. I've also had no problems with bugs/crashes or anything like that, with the Epic Edition. Also a plus: the world is absolutely *huge*. I am certain it is much bigger than any recent Bethesda games by far, and the environments are quite varied once you get out a bit.In short, this is a game that got -- to my mind -- unfairly passed over when it was released. It does have its quirks and doesn't make a great first impression when you start up, but I can honestly say I've had as much fun with this game as any other open-world RPG you can name, and like it as well -- if not better -- than Skyrim. They're just different. At anything <$20 -- let alone the 2.99 or so you often see it for -- it is an absolute steal. Highly recommended.

												A solid RPG with many features. Very playable. Even re-playable. Especially like:- Seamless nature of the world. Very few load-screens. Even entering towns and homes is seamless. This is how it should be!- Variety of quests and goals, mostly optional.- Engaging skill choices.Quibbles. Not really "dislike" but "somewhat annoying"- Times when the merchants are wandering around randomly. Finding the same merchant again is a pain.- Horses steer like they're brain-damaged. Sometimes will veeer off to one side and suddenly you can't steer anymore.- Horses again. You can't ride down a hill, but you can get off the horse and call it down the hill. WTF?- Some of the quests are incredibly obtuse, relying more on luck and happenstance than on deliberate planning.Major bugs:- The crashing. Especially after saving a few times, it'll just crash on my system. No response from either Steam or the "official" game support.- The dialog. Only looking at some videos did I realize there was supposed to be dialog! Totally not working on my system. I only get the text, but everyone is silent.Definitely worth the buy. Now if I could just convince Steam to let me have the Strategy Guide I paid for. It's DLC, but it refuses to install. I'm guessing it's a Steam issue, but they keep passing the buck to the publisher, who has no control over Steam.

number of helpful: 16 of 29 people (55%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 2, 2016
												I remember when this game first came out, the box had a splash art announcing Two Worlds as the "Oblivion Killer." If by that the devs meant make the player never want to play a fantasy rpg again, then they succeeded. the cons far outweigh the pros for this too ambitious title.Pros:1: Neat lore elements that obviously had at least some creative thought put into them.2: Fully voiced.3: Some humorous side characters.4: Large explorable map.5: Fully illustrated strategy guide, should you make the extra purchase.Cons:1: Strange registration setup that requires exiting the game upon starting the game.2: Unimaginative and uniteresting storyline.3: All of the voices are terrible. Like really, really bad.4: Bland and annoying main character. Most of the supporting characters are this way as well.5: The map barely resembles the actual terrain, and a vast portion of the landscape is nearly impossible to traverse.6: Many areas of the game look unfinshed, with random invisible walls, inescapable holes in the ground, etc.7: Stupidly easy, if you are even the slightest bit versed in building characters or can do 3rd grade math. (Normally, I like easy games, but this was too much even for me.)8: The most repetative gameplay you will ever experience from a game that is not on mobile. Exploring, questing, fighting, all of it.9: One of the most atrocious set of game mechanics I have ever experienced. Fighting monsters was silmultaniously a bore and a chore.I could probably go on with the cons of this game, but I think I covered the main points. So if you are willing to push through hours of horrible gameplay for a semi-funny joke every now and then, by all means by this game. If not, do not. With 225 hours in this game, I am probably one of the leading authorities on Two Worlds now; and my recommendation is to never touch this game.

												It's actually a very good game unlike what people says about it.It does lacks in content, it doesn't have the biggest map ever, it doesn't have a lot of creatures, animals, spells and items.But it is a good game, the gameplay is all right, nothing great, nothing bad, it is really, really easy though, you can dodge every attacks so easily but it's good anyway, when it comes to blocking, it's the same as in Morrowind.If you love either The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion or even Gothic, you'll probably like this game, it's not as great, but it's good, the World is pretty similar, without the Hellish stuff that Oblivion has though.Note that Gothic is way more challenging than this game, this one is actually pretty easy but it's a fun game anyway.It's also cheaper, so there's that.Hopefully that we'll see Two Worlds III, which will be at least 4x bigger than the world map in Two Worlds II, with many new creatures and items, and a way better gameplay.Honestly, I don't think this game deserves 65, but at the same time, it's coming from Metacritic, a bunch of good at nothing who knows nothing so their opinion doesn't really matters, the same could be said about IGN and many more, anyway, it's better to make an opinion of something by yourself than by someone else.In my opinion it deserves 7.5/10, It's far away to be perfect, but it's a really great game considering its low price.

content:
Posted: January 14
												This turned out to be a surprisingly modern and well designed game and I though I haven't yet played it for as long as some others, I've had a lot of fun exploring and discovering what this game has to offer. In today's MMORPG landscape, particularly post-WoW, most of these types of games tend to be very similar and it's easy to forget that there are MMORPGs like Two Worlds II, The Secret World etc, which, while not as flashy and refined as the mainstream games, offer their own flavour and ultimately a fuller experience.Two Worlds II has a far more lively world than other games I've played and excels at building an interactive world, particularly after the slow early introduction story, and despite a less than perfect spell system and less shiny graphics, it's a fun game to experience that makes you feel a part of the world, something that's often amiss from modern titles.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2014
												Two Worlds doesn't have the amount of exploration and interesting content as the Elder Scrolls: Oblivion does, but it certainly has its own unique charm. Two Worlds captures that old RPG feel that seems lost in the games of our current generation, it felt very akin to playing the original Ever Quest. From the start of multiplayer mode, you'll be getting your♥♥♥♥♥♥handed to you on a silver platter over and over and over again, and the enemies will promptly give you more beatings. There's challenge to be had here, but it doesn't add much to the genre overall. I've heard that through the later levels you have a lot more freedom to customize your character, but I didn't see much through the miniscule time that I played. It was just basic kill X target or gather X item, not much innovation. The lower level multiplayer enviroments don't look very interesting, and I imagine it would be a bore to trudge through without a friend by your side. Within the multiplayer component, the quest rewards were very underwhelming. In the map that I played, all I gained from completing them was gold, gold, and more gold. Where are the unique items, you might ask? They're sold by NPCs, or sometimes found on corpses, or within treasure chests. If you bore easily, this isn't the game for you. I wouldn't recommend playing multiplayer without a friend, my friend and I only saw five other people playing at the same time. I can't speak for the singleplayer content as I haven't played it, but I imagine it's more or less the same. The story and voice acting are also terrible, so I wouldn't purchase the game if you're looking for that. You should also know that there are some nasty bugs that come along with this game, after several hours of playing multiplayer, I abruptly crashed and lost all of my progress. So be wary of the multiplayer aspect of the game, you could unexpectedly lose all of your progress, and there is no fix for this that I know of. tl;dr Two Worlds brings back the old school feel, but it doesn't measure up to other games released in its time period. If you're looking for a great RPG experience, I'd recommend Oblivion or Dragon Age: Origins. 4/10. It's an average and bland game, but that's part of its charm.

												I have played this game years ago. It was one of, if not THE first solid RPG experience I've had. I loved it from the first day, and to this day, I still love it. The world is immersive, and MASSIVE, you can never say you've explored it all. I remember challenging myself to explore EVERY SINGLE dungeon in the world, and I yet didn't finish that. Unfortunately, I lost the game CD, but now that I bought it again on Steam, it's time to play! Yes, the story, the dialogue may be cheesy, you might encounter funny bugs, although I know they've fixed most of them, but there are so many things that you can see and do that you can easily cast aside all the negative and just enjoy it. Now excuse me, I have quests to do, dungeons to explore and monsters to slay! I totally recommend this game to anyone willing to have fun!

content:
Posted: December 5, 2015
												TLDR: Two Worlds is The Room of RPGs. It's somehow both bad and fun at the same time.Lets get this out of the way: this is a trashy Eastern European RPG. The generic plot is written in bad ye olde englishe and spoken by the worst non-native speakers this side of House of the Dead. It will actively try to disuade you from paying attention to the plot, and yet IT WON'T SHUT UP. Hoods breath, does this game have diarrhea of the mouth. And yet, it's really enjoyable for the cheap RPG it is. Once you realize that all weapons attack at the same speed and dodging instantly makes you immune to damage, you can cheese the game like a boss. Oh, and when you die, you just respawn at the nearest health shrine, no xp loss or anything. Still not as great as other European RPGs like Gothic or Risen, but it's not the hellspawn that it has the reputation for. Then again, I really enjoy terrible movies, so I guess I just have trashy taste.

												Some people seem to genuinely enjoy this game.  That caught me off-guard.In 2007, I'd heard all the hype about this being the next great RPG.  Just coming off Oblivion (which I'd played obsessively), I was so excited for Two Worlds!Well, I played it about 30 minutes, was horrendously disappointed, laughed at it a bit, and gave up.  It's very pretty.  That's about all I have to say about it.Recently, seeing all the positive (??) reviews for the game, I grabbed it for $2.  Well, I wish I had my money back.  I gave it another try.  If there is redeeming value in this game, I can't find it.  The combat is awful, it's buggy, the dialog is laughable...Two Worlds II, on the other hand, is actually underrated.  It's a lot of fun.  That's another reason I gave this game a second shot.  The sequel is so much fun, despite not exactly being brilliant, so maybe I missed something in the original?Well, again, if I'm missing something, I can't find it.  I have a pretty high tolerance for crappy RPGs, but I can't tolerate this one.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 5, 2015
												Two Worlds is one of those games that is so bad that it ends up being a little good. Although it is impossible to take seriously, the game can actually be quite absorbing once you get into the swing of it. The game has aged quite poorly, and even getting it to run properly can be a nightmare. One you get it to run properly, you may be faced with constant crashes, although I have not had these issues. That being said, the game actually runs somewhat well on the PC, which is a nice contrast to the 360 port, where the game runs under 30 FPS at almost all times. On both PC and 360, the game often lags hard when you kill someone or when you level up as you kill someone. This sometimes makes a very damaging blow quite satisifying, but most of the time it's just annoying.Moving on from the technical side of this game, we need to take a quick stop to look at the story and voice acting. The story is quite generic. Some evil dudes kidnap your sister and you need to get her back. The voice acting, on the other hand, is anything but generic. This game has the worst voice acting I have ever heard in a major title. Even the protagonist's voice acting is terrible, with laughably bad writing to boot. The voice acting and story go hand-in-hand to make a hilariously bad story experience that you can't help but laugh at when playing the game.Before we take a look at gameplay, I want to touch on graphics. The graphics, specifically the face rendering, are simply bad for the time that this game was produced. By contrast, many of the environments look quite nice. It feels like the artists really put some effort into this part of the game. Graphics almost never make or break a game, but I wanted to touch on it.Now for the gameplay and replayability. The gameplay in the game is quite repetitive, but something about it is addictive. You often adopt the same strategies to kill many enemies, but actually figuring out what those strategies are can be quite fun. For example, I found that a mixture of critical strike, defensive combat, and traps allowed me to easily tackle any enemy. However, experimenting with other paths can be quite fun as well, which is where the game's replayability comes in. Although I found that the critical strike build was simply the best build, I did have fun experimenting with an amplification nuke mage for a bit. Sadly, the mana costs were too prohibitive, but experimentation like this is what helps keep the game fresh.Although some have complained about the game's difficulty curve rising too quickly, it is likely that those same people missed many of the essential side quests that allow you to level your character and tackle larger enemies.  For example, if you skip the first major city (Tharbakin), you will fall behind drastically in levels. Just like in other RPGs, if you tackle the main quest first, you will pay dearly. The general rule for gameplay difficulty in this game is as follows: the further south you go, the harder the game gets, and when you cross the river, the game gets significantly harder.The gameplay is where the game redeems itself and comes into its own. Somehow, this gimmicky gameplay where you find the best way to abuse the game's skill and combat system is quite addicting, and you often find yourself playing for hours at a time to see just how badly you can abuse the game. Through my strategy of mixing critical chance, critical strike, and defensive combat, I was able to build a character that would crit on virtually every attack for 250% damage, quickly disposing of my foes. For any bigger characters, I would abuse the game's traps and bad enemy pathing and walk the enemies into the traps before I unleashed on them with critical strikes. Attempting to abuse the game in different ways allows for many hours of replayabilty.Before wrapping up the review, I want to quickly address the Xbox 360 port of this game. When I first played this game, I played it on an Xbox 360, and that experience shaped my opinion of the game quite negatively. The game lags quite extensively, and the combat system is significantly worse because the controls are just horendous. Lastly, for some inexplicable reason, critical strikes are broken on console. You cannot crit people. This means that killing even modest enemies requires you to have many traps and bombs and patiently kill them. This drawback is very large and detracts heavily from the gameplay experience on console. I would recommend at least looking at the PC port if you played the 360 version and did not enjoy it.This game, despite its big flaws, actually ends up being a mediocre but very addictive fantasy RPG. I would never even pretend that it could compete with games like Oblivion, but something about it is quite addictive and can leave you playing it for hours on end as you try to find the best way to cheese the game and abuse the combat systems. I would never dream of paying $60 for this game, but I would recommend it at $5 or below. It is worth it just for the hilariously bad story and voice acting at $5, and if you enjoy it, you will actually get quite a bit of value out of it as you can easily end up sinking 50+ hours into this game.

content:
Posted: January 8
												Do you like the thrill of the chase?  Searching forests for rare animals, such as The Dodo, and then, when you finally find your prey; Notching an arrow and killing it with a feat of skillful dexterity, Or perhaps stealthily sneaking up to kill it with a single thrust of a dagger; in order to get a . . . solitary feather?  Ok, what about skipping along a beach in full armour, ocassionally whistling for a horse?  You could do that instead if you like.Fight a bear, an orc, an ogre, a cyclops, sometimes all at the same time. (To be honest I've never fought a bear, an orc, an ogre and a cyclops at the same time. Though I have fought a lot of orcs, several ogres, a few stone golems, at the same time; I'm pretty sure there was a cyclops there too) Dragons, they're about too.T'is a good game. Worth a go if you're into large world RPGs.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												Ah, the original Two Worlds. Often considered a flop and a bad game, I can safely say this is one of my favourite games and it will always have a place in my top 100 video games of all time. Why?I don't think it's worth my time or anyone else's time to start arguing about the quality of the game itself. As many others have pointed out, this game does have its flaws. Plenty of things could have been done better and it does indeed fall short in many aspects. However, the whole package is simply amazing for multiple reasons.I've always had a soft spot for a simple and barren world in a video game. It's not barren in the same sense as Fallout 3's world: actually quite the opposite. In Fallout 3, the world is simply "dead" but it has a lot of things going on. In this game, the world is actually quite beautiful but it lacks, well, the meat. There's not much in it.For some reason Two Worlds feels like it's actually a much better game than most people think it is. I have my problems with the voice acting and a lot of other things but the experience is something you can't get out of any other game. Maybe it's because the game reminds me of an MMO of days past but something in this game just draws me back in again and again. I've beaten it before Steam as well.

												I reviewed this a while back with as a joke but today i came onto steam only to it as the newest released game, I have no idea why this is considered new but what the hell it gives me the chance to review this horrible mess again.Two Worlds is a western rpg that plays, sounds and looks like crap. It is perhaps the worst game i have ever completed and i have no intention to ever play it again. The story is about a man who has lost his sister, shes kidnapped or something and it is your quest to glitch your way through twenty plus hours of running past things. I created a melee fighter as i couldn't be arsed figuring out the magic system and as a melee guy i blessed with the good button of Q, a back-step. You see to fight in this game you hit then you jab Q. If you fail to jab Q you are probably dead as pretty much everything from a wolf to a demon-lord guy will one hit you. Now this may have been my own fault as around half way through i got extremely bored and stopped doing the side quests; they where boring.There are a few moments in the game that really shine like the bit where you glitch your horse onto a teleporter and jab enter so you can take it with you in this massive boring landscape (Seriously the first horse teleport i manged to do was extremely satisfying). Or the bit where you take the final boss(apparently someone who everyone is afraid of) half way across the map in the hopes that you can find a bear to kill him cause you cant be arsed to spend another thirty minutes trying to get another quarter of his health down .Overall, its a boring massive world with terrible dialogue and voice acting. The horrible combat system that is frustrating yet simple and the confusing and drawn out storyline make Two Worlds an experience that should only be touched when free and not really then.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2014
												Two Worlds is an exciting and story-rich RPG. You play as a mercenary who will do anything to save his sister, Kira. There are many enemies you must face: blood-thirsty orcs, golems, ogers, dragons, necromancers, you name it. I'm just going to say it straight-forward. This game is hard. When you first start out, you are extremely weak; you struggle to slay a couple bandits without using a health potion or spell. As you progress things only become harder. You may be able to slay 12 bandits with your mighty greatsword with no problem at all. But how will you fare against an oger? Or 5 necromancers? It is satisfying, being able to kill something you once struggled to even hit. But know that there will always be an enemy that will utterly destroy you. When you die, you respawn at the last shrine you visited (there are A LOT of shrines around the world). You don't have to go back to your last save or anything like that. Which can be both good and bad. The game play is great, the graphics are good enough to keep your immersion, and the voice acting is mediocre at best. There are flaws, but there is a lot of fun gameplay here. Unfortunately, after you complete the game, there's virtually no replay value. I haven't picked it up since I beat it. So, if you're looking for a game you can beat multiple times consecutively, then this isn't the game for you. I had fun playing it, and I do recommend it if you're looking for a good open world RPG. 8/10

content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												NOTE: This review only touches upon the single-player aspects of the game. I've not touched the multiplayer, as I assume it's dead.This game is overhated. There. I said it. Sure, it's not the "Oblivion killer" that it was advertised to be, and it's not the best-looking game ever, but holy damn is it fun. What you have here is an open-world action-RPG [closer to Gothic, barely, than The Elder Scrolls] with a cheesy (almost as much so as Fable 1) storyline, a hell of a lot of loot, and a very customizable class system. The voice acting is absolute♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ but that's okay because it fits the cheesy-fun mood of the game (again, like Fable 1). Overall, the journey, if you can get used to the uneven difficulty, is well worth it. Just... Turn down the voice acting slider, and pretend the game has no voice acting.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												I played Two Worlds a lot in 2010 on the disc version of this, amassing around 150 hours in it. The acting is rubbish to be quite honest, and the story isn't that exciting(when you finish it, the game simply ends - I didn't actually feel inspired to finish it until I was nearly done with the sidequests). The main reason I had such a long playtime for it was because of the weapon upgrade system which had me running around randomly searching for weapons to combine with what I already owned(and usually find something better), the sidequests which sometimes had an interesting bit of backstory to them and the NPCs(in cities especially) who were remarkably fun to kill or scare with different types of spells(Guards will instakill you at first though).Two Worlds is also still fairly nice looking for the age it is - don't expect groundbreaking graphics, but the green environments especially still look quite nice.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2015
												Good to pass some time away, but overall not recommended.   Visuals are passable considering its age, combat is again passable with the ability to "dodge" (a feature missing from TW2) - Two Worlds is hugely unbalanced in every department, magic is massively underwhelming requiring massive spell upgrades before it becomes 'useful' Alchemy is extremely overpowered with the ability to create potions giving you thousands of permanent hit points, magic or stats.  Mounts are buggy, with horses having pathing issues constantly.   Item fusion is also overpowered giving the player the ability to fuse together the same items and have the stats cross-over, allowing for some extremely overpowered godly items.  Another major issue is frame rate and stuttering which happens constantly, and gets fairly annoying. The game contains plenty of side quests but since the 'quest' tracker is confusing, most of the time you can't really figure out where your supposed to go, or to talk too.   The main story quests are extremely convoluted with plenty of pointless running around just to open simple doors so you can continue your quests.  Balance in every department is poor and its very noticable - once you complete the main quest line, the ending is exceptionally bad....I'm talking 'Mass Effect 3 bad'Overall, I cannot recommend Two Worlds but for people looking for a quick open world rpg to pass some time, and if you can find this game for 'cheap' or free, then its worth maybe checking out if your a fan of the genre.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												Underneath this somewhat unpolished game, marred by huge expectations (pre-release hype expected this game to be the next Oblvion open-world game), and a horrible buggy release, lies an enjoyable, often unique open-world RPG game, a game that I can recommend to open-minded gamers.It's amazing I can say that because on release, when I first got the Xbox 360 version, it looked like I had made a mistake. Tons of framerate issues, game-breaking bugs, and moreover a very unimpressive intro and beginner newbie area. The game eventually got patched, and I enjoyed it enough to later buy the PC version, and for my friends and I, Two Worlds 1 has become a guilty pleasure. I actually bought this twice on the PC, directly from publisher and later via Steam, so my hours don't reflect all of my accumulated playing time.I have to stress, though, that you have to weather the horrible beginning of the game. The game cinematic intro is uninspiring, then it drops you into a forest area, eventually giving you a barebones tutorial that doesn't show you the cool features of the game. On top of that, you have to make your way to your first town which sports some of the worst voice acting I've heard heard in a game. Fortunately, the voice acting improves a bit as you get further into the game, however the dialogue is still pretty bad, but you get used to it.On your way to the town, you may get mauled by wolves, which travel in packs, which until you learn the agro system of the game, you may die repeatedly.  So often, gamers will just quit at this point, several hours into the game, which is a shame, and I believe why most people didn't give this game a fair shake.  Lots to learn -- how to use the magic system, how to collect ingredients, how to handle night time creatures in the game (you won't be able to kill them initially so run away from them), etc.I really liked the weapon-combining system which I wish more games would implement.  You can combine similar weapons to upgrade your main weapon, so alleviates inventory issues, just keep combing that generic sword over and over. It also solves the moan-and-groan of finding junk loot, because in this game, you can make an uber weapon out of crappy weapons. Of course, eventually you'll want to combine higher-level weapons, but it's a great way to lessen inventory issues.I also loved the co-op feature, able to the play the entire game again with a friend. Not sure if you can still do this, though, because I don't remember if it needed access to original Two Worlds servers.Character models may look a bit dated, but the world still looks pretty good, and it has a lot of variety. Lots of side-quest and secrets to explore and enough variety to replay the game with different classes, which is also a strength, Classes aren't set in stone, but you can develop your character however way you want. Some people have issues with the mounting system, getting aggravated with the horse mount, but I found the PC version is far improved over the 360 version.Two Worlds 2, the sequel,  is by far, a more polished game, but TW1 sports a larger world, and doesn't have the weapon combining feature. If you can do some reading of the game mechanics, and not give up right away, you may find yourself enjoying this game.

number of helpful: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21, 2016
												Two Worlds is a game I had originally heard of, but never played until about a year ago. I didn't keep up with the hype and the marketing for this game, and it was because of a YouTuber called ProJared and his review of this game that I bought it, mainly to see if it was as bad as he said it was. And - surprise, surprise - he was right.Two Worlds, according to ProJared's Review (be prepared to see ProJared's name come up a LOT in this "review"), was going to put another game - The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion - to shame. Needless to say, it didn't even come close to matching Oblivion in anything. And I'm going to prove it.The game starts off with the Main Character and his twin sister, Kira, riding through the rain. Kira is injured, and falls off the horse. Here is where one of the many problems of Two Worlds starts to show. First off, the voice acting. It's God-awful. Every single voice actor - well, with an exception or two - is bad. Every line of speech is forced, no emotion is in the dialogue and even worse, the text in the game looks like it was written by someone trying to emulate Shakespeare.The story for this game is simple. As the Main Character goes to look for a shelter that he and Kira can stay in for the night to keep out of the rain, Kira gets kidnapped. About six months later, in the first village you're in (I don't remember what it was called, just more proof of how bad this game is) you recieve a letter telling you that your sister is alive. After reading the letter, the village elder gives you your first quest, the traditional cliché quest at the beginning of most RPGs out there: clear a cave of monsters. You do that, you come out of the cave which is really a temple, and when you're through with that task, some guy from the first village tells you that some "hard warriors" have come looking for you. After that, you find the man who kidnapped your sister - Gandohar - and he tells you to go and meet his master Reist in the Goat's Cave. You meet Reist, and he tells you to go and talk to Gandohar. Refresh my memory, why did I need to go in there again? Anyways, speaking with Gandohar reveals that he "claims" that he wants to help Kira, and to do that, he needs you to go and collect four treasures representing the four elements: Fire, Wind, Water, and Earth. There's also a fifth piece that binds them together just like that ring from Lord of the Rings. And apparently, only the Main Character and Kira can touch the key and nobody else can, similar to the Vampire Killer whip from the Castlevania franchise. That's really all I can say about the story, because I pretty much quit playing after that.Gameplay: The gameplay is somewhat similar to Oblivion, but they somehow managed to screw that up. When you're fighting anything in this game, and I mean anything, it all basically amounts to a button masher swinging wildly at everything around you, and I mean everything. There's no surefire way to be sure that you're hitting something other than the blood that shoots out of enemies, and the punch sound that accompanies trying to hit something with a steel blade that clearly is there to cause bruises rather than draw blood, but whatever.The graphics here are a mixed bag. The character models and everything look awful, to the point where they would barely pass as PS2 graphics, and they're animated so poorly. The lip-synching is also terrible, which makes Godzilla movies look masterful. However, and this is what I mean by the graphics being a mixed bag, is that not everything looks terrible, the enviroments are kind of nice. I can admit that.The music sounds like your typical midieval sword & sorcery-style RPG, with light tunes when exploring, heavy tunes when in danger, things like that.All in all, I have to say that it's a damn shame this game didn't quite live up to the hype, because it shows great potential that could have easily put The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion to shame, but they let their ambitions and a clichéd story along with awful gameplay get in the way of it all. Also, the voice acting was really disappointing as well. Still, hopefully they learned their lesson with this game and made Two Worlds II MUCH better, but I'll be going into it expecting the worst.

Posted: April 13, 2015
												This game is extremely clumsy, a bit buggy, but it definitely has charm. The dialog is obnoxiously stiff, but it has character. The combat and physics are kinda wonky, but it means you never know quite what's going to happen. The environment is decent, for a game of this age, but the main plot is pretty boring. The hero is so damn macho. All in all, enjoyable for a few dollars.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												It's a very good game but just doesn't quite make it to great or legendary due to a series of small items that take away from the overall experience.   Overall I still give it a thumbs up.  There are many ways to play your character - I did "two handed weapon Tank".   Due to the negatives (specifically being overpowered due to alchemy I just can't see myself doing a second play thru and that's why I rate it good and not great.  You'll play 80-100 hours and if you like these types of games, you'll enjoy it but won't be wowed by it and likely won't want to play it thru a second time.  Other games of its ilk (Titan Quest comes to mind as something close I've played thru multiple times with variety of builds).  This one - I don't think it'd make a difference.   When you have 50000 HP with 1500 HP heal spell and monsters do 100 points of damage and it takes one/two hit to kill them, the juice just goes out the window for combat related aspects of the game.  What I liked -        Large open world to explore.  While some areas are harder to navigate before you get strong, for the most part you can go anywhere at any time.          Alchemy skill was extremely fun (albeit it does make you overpowered)       merging items to craft a better item of same type - really liked this.         U.I good, easy to pick up       Side quests were enjoyable.       The atmosphere was very good.         Unlike others, I found the storyline reasonable and I didn't mind the graphics.        Due to alchemy and the lavishness of resources that add to your stats "permanently", you become very overpowered very quickly.   At about level 20 or so I had a "Spear of Destiny" which is a one-hit kill for most monsters and was a three hit kill for Dragons, all Golems, and all Boss Monsters (final battle was a one-hit).  I also had 50000 hit points and 20000 in physical resistence and 8000 in resistence to Elements (most monsters do hundreds of points of damage).  At no juncture did I feel threatened in any battle.  This one main aspect to me keeps this game from being great.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2015
												Personal terms: worth purchase (i got on sale with 80% of discount)Impartial traditional terms: 5/10Personal sentimental judgment (Just for the record): 7/10I like this game, a lot. To me is a great game, really got me absorbed, and I probably will play a hundred more hours. This game need to be remembered with some honors. But you can't take my personal judgment as guarantee you gone like. To me is a great game, as i said.There is a lot issues in this game, but a lot of good thing too.Good characteristics:*Real Open World *Nonlinear campaign progress.*Smooth loot and inventory system.*Interesting lore*Extremely big variety of enemies*Hundreds types of armor and weapons*Very deep and easy magic systemBad characteristics:*Horrible voice acting*You won't feel connected to the game*The way the quest are display on your map can be confused.*Combat can be boring.*Lack of lapidation.*Open areas can be empty, because the enemies don't respawn.*There is no books or anything like to read in the game, what would make the story and mythology more complete and interesting to understand.*No crafting system.I didn't understand why but the autosave system has a facility to put you into a death loop, and the game only keep a history of three autosaves, what is a flaw in a Open World game. Once two of my three autosave got into a death loop and I almost lose all my campaign progress. But fortunately you can manually create an unlimited number of manual saves.Personally this game really is a hidden preciosity, for some RPG fan only, and I can't recommend to everybody. If you're not a great RPG fan will be some kinda difficult to you like this particular game. If you are a casual is almost certain you'll not gonna like it. Is a good RPG, with some interesting lore, but has also to many problems. Two Words also doesn't have a good replayability, everyone who beat the game is almost certain that he wil never play this game again. Is extremely inferior compared to others RPG Open World in the time was release, but in my personal experience this franchise became a remarkable experience in one of my favorite types of games. What I can say is: 5/10. Is just a normal game, have just enough to be average, nothing realy attractive, is just a game that dont sucks (considering the PC version only, stay away from the console version). Being a "normal game", as I said, you can't feel connected with the lore, the world and the characters (this last because of the extremely horrible voice acting), and this is a important thing for a RPG. You're hardcore RPG fan like me? If yes give a try, you will like this game, although much more the franchise as a whole package.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												I've only really started playing this game today, and I have to say, for it being quite an old game it is still fun to play, and worth a try if you are looking for a rpg to play. I really like the alchemy system, you have 4 slots I believe if i can remember, and you get ingredients from plants or wildlife that give you buffs. The skill system makes sense and I honestly have no problem with it, it has a sense of progression. For instance you have to be a certain level before you can put more points into a skill. This way you don't find yourself leveling one skill the entire time. I also like the fact that there is reputation with the factions in the game. It runs on a scale of 1-10, 1 being not important and 10 being very important. The more quests you do for a faction the more rep you gain. The questing is fun and the voice acting isn't really all that bad, It's better than reading quests (Morrowind). At the beginning it is sort of rough, but once you can get some gear from crushing some Grom skulls you'll be fine :)

content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												TL;DR: This game is demonstrably bad, yet has a charm that lets it hold it's own against other rpg's of those days.I will start this review with a warning: I'm biased in favor of this game. It was the first open world RPG I ever owned and so when I saw this game on steam the nostalgia hit like a thrown brick.This is a game that you have to laugh at to play. If you are a fan of open world RPGs like me and are willing to keep a sense of humor, this is an excellent game despite the constant speed bumps.The gameplay elements that work in this game's favor are the skills, crafting, and combat. The raw number of different skills allow the player to create a Robin Hood-esque ranger, a steel-clad one man-army warrior, or a mighty mage who owns an entire town (a bug I will explain later on).  The crafting system is simple, find two of the same items and you can combine them to make a single more powerful item.  The alchemy of Two Worlds is also the best type of potion-crafting I've ever experienced for a single reason: permanent effect potions and trap-making.  The combat is as varied as the classless skills, making any path viable. Using a wide variety of re-useable traps (from poisoned spikes to hammers and fire-coated blades) allows players who prefer ranged magic or bows to kill much more powerful creatures without the worry of being forced into melee. Magic and potions can keep a warrior alive in even the thickest melee.While I do love this game, the experience fails in just as many ways as it succeeds. The game's skill system, combat, and crafting could all use some work.I sound like I'm contradicting myself, but it is the truth. The way the player unlocks skills is by finding a trainer and purchasing the skill, which then allows the player to use and allocate points towards that skill. This is not a huge problem except for the alchemy skill. The alchemy skill is useable from the start of the game but the player must find the alchemy trainer (located far to the south and hidden among end-game monsters) in order to increase the skill, which is vital in wringing out every last stat point from permanent-effect potion ingredients. With the most useful early-game skill unlocked in the late/end-game, the other major skill dissapointments are the useless and annoying skills. You can learn a skill to unhorse a mounted enemy, but no one except the player can ride a horse. The swimming skill is useful for crossing rivers, which the player only really needs to do once or twice meaning the skill is a waste and swim-speed makes every river crossing a five-minute ordeal.The combat, while the options are varried, can easily become stale.  Once you find a style that works, you will abuse it. For example: what should be an epic battle of ranger vs dragon becomes a chore as you trick the dumb-as-rock AI into alternating between stacks of traps as you fill it with arrows. The crafting system requires two of the same item to create a single more powerful version. However, if the two items are too different in their enchantments, you can't combine them. The only way to tell if an item is too different from your gear is to have them both in your inventory, making purchasing equipment a gamble at the best of times. The game has a few qualities that are neither inherently good or bad, as long as you keep a sense of humor. Perfect examples being the dialogue and the bugs.The dialogue is comedic. It would be difficult for anyone to write funnier dialogue becuase between the merciless abuse of old-english and the uninspired voice acting, every single conversation will have you either cringing or laughing. The best bug I've ever experienced was in this game. *SPOILER ALERT*  During the course of the main questline, a city is overrun by orcs. By killing all the orcs and using the resurrect spell on everyone (including the orcs), the player can create a city where guards do not attack them and the humans and orcs co-exist peacefully (the orcs even sweep the streets) *SPOILER OVER*While there are countless speed-bumps to enjoying this game (including the terrible activation), it is an experience worth having.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												Get this game if you aren't afraid of warriors, hard ones. You're the kind of hero who prefers to narrate everything you do, all the while sounding like the last guy who told your drunk♥♥♥♥♥to get in the trunk. The kind of hero with the air of a repeat sex offender who eats nails for breakfast, but possesses a warm gooey center and extremely mixed feelings about their scantily clad sister who looks nothing like them 99.9% of the time. If you feel like chasing the big bad hard warrior known as Gandohar and is sensible but stylish  master named Reist across the damn continent to save your sister prepare yourself for a twist that would probably make M. Night Shablabdingdong proud. Note that it will cause everyone else to indifferently stare at the screen while fiddling with their genitalia. Oh yeah you kill a lot of things and get progressively shinier armor to protect you from (or attract) Gandohars firm hands, its all fun and games till the bad guy starts caressing you like  you're his pillow. Also this game is a fantastic substitute for Blender Simulator 2013, I'd like to see those sim punks make an even better identical sword by throwing 20 of them in a blender together!Seriously though Two Worlds has...Symbol Key--------------------++= very good+= good- = bad--------------------- Hilarious voice acting (yes its bad but in a good way) + - Exploration! ++- Some Forgettable quests -- Plenty of quests +- Plentiful factions but no real consequences for reputation other than more or less quests =The combat is somewhat difficult but unlike other games you can't permanently die, you'll just get ressurected at a nearbly Maliel Shrine and continue your journey back to that damn Cyclops that used your helmet as a bongo. No item loss, no nothing, just rinse and repeat till you win (quicksaving in other RPG's is kind of the same thing though). Did I mention the map is huge and full of diverse and fairly interesting environments complete with some fairly standard but servicable guilds/factions to be a part of? Whether you're slaying Jackals and Dragons in the desert, killing Polar Bears and Orcs up in the glacier, being chased through the ruins of the deadlands surrounding a destroyed city with appropriate amounts of demons, undead, and more. Maybe you'll just slaughter entire cities and towns for fun once you become powerful enough? Just don't beat the main quest right away as once its over so is the game, its a lot more fun to explore the exotic landscapes of Antaloor and though they may lack much lore to give them added signifigance, its always the journey that beats the destination. Good thing the journey is so damn fun.Yes the voice acting is THAT bad and you will love it! Its part of the games charm.7.7/10

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												My experience with Two Worlds is that it is COMPLETE, unplayable feces. I don't know what it is about my computer, but this game refuses to play on it under any circumstances. I believe I got it to work once, right after I got it, and when I got the game, the controls were absolutely atrocious and unintuitive on the xbox 360 gamepad.Now though, I can't even get this game to run without crashing to desktop with a 'Two Worlds is not responding' message, and I know what the common issues with this game are, I've tried all of the 1 fix I've ever seen for this game crashing, which is installing the proper nvidia Physx legacy driver. I've done that exact thing, installing and uninstalling the drivers multiple times, verifying game caches, uninstalling and reinstalling the game, running a command line parameter that allows me to finally launch the game in a tiny window only for it to crash while loading. This game doesn't know how to function. The programmers must have been complete idiots when they made this.The only positive thing to come away from this game with is that at least the developers learned from this and made Two Worlds II a much more competent, smoother, and overall better experience. If you wanna check out Two Worlds, don't bother, get the sequel.----------Edit:Alright. I finally got this thing to work, and here was the problem, files in OTHER GAMES I OWNED were keeping this game from running. I have no clue how ANYONE can fail at programming a game so hard that having another file in another location on your computer for another game keeps this other, ENTIRELY DIFFERENT GAME from FUNCTIONING. The solution, to people who had the same problem as me is, check your games for lgvid.ax files and delete them. These files are most common in Looking Glass's Dark Engine games (System Shock 2, Thief Gold, and Thief 2: The Metal Age are the most likely culprits). While I could also use that as an opportunity to lay the blame on those games, the fact of the matter is, I have over 200 games in my library and not ONE besides this game ceased to function just because of a file it shouldn't even be referencing that exists in my other games.That said, if you can fix it and get it working, Two Worlds is worth trying. Getting past the technical issues, I have been playing the game quite regularly in the past week or so, putting in over 20 hours already, and most of that was just me exploring, killing monsters and bandits and groms and animals, then looting, equipping, improving, and selling their stuff without doing any quests. So I'd say it makes for a fairly enjoyable sandbox Action-RPG that I would recommend, but again, ONLY if you have no issues getting it to run. The technical issues should be a big red flag if you plan on getting this game at anything other than a considerable discount.

Just don't beat the main quest right away as once its over so is the game, its a lot more fun to explore the exotic landscapes of Antaloor and though they may lack much lore to give them added signifigance, its always the journey that beats the destination. Good thing the journey is so damn fun.Yes the voice acting is THAT bad and you will love it! Its part of the games charm.7.7/10

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												My experience with Two Worlds is that it is COMPLETE, unplayable feces. I don't know what it is about my computer, but this game refuses to play on it under any circumstances. I believe I got it to work once, right after I got it, and when I got the game, the controls were absolutely atrocious and unintuitive on the xbox 360 gamepad.Now though, I can't even get this game to run without crashing to desktop with a 'Two Worlds is not responding' message, and I know what the common issues with this game are, I've tried all of the 1 fix I've ever seen for this game crashing, which is installing the proper nvidia Physx legacy driver. I've done that exact thing, installing and uninstalling the drivers multiple times, verifying game caches, uninstalling and reinstalling the game, running a command line parameter that allows me to finally launch the game in a tiny window only for it to crash while loading. This game doesn't know how to function. The programmers must have been complete idiots when they made this.The only positive thing to come away from this game with is that at least the developers learned from this and made Two Worlds II a much more competent, smoother, and overall better experience. If you wanna check out Two Worlds, don't bother, get the sequel.----------Edit:Alright. I finally got this thing to work, and here was the problem, files in OTHER GAMES I OWNED were keeping this game from running. I have no clue how ANYONE can fail at programming a game so hard that having another file in another location on your computer for another game keeps this other, ENTIRELY DIFFERENT GAME from FUNCTIONING. The solution, to people who had the same problem as me is, check your games for lgvid.ax files and delete them. These files are most common in Looking Glass's Dark Engine games (System Shock 2, Thief Gold, and Thief 2: The Metal Age are the most likely culprits). While I could also use that as an opportunity to lay the blame on those games, the fact of the matter is, I have over 200 games in my library and not ONE besides this game ceased to function just because of a file it shouldn't even be referencing that exists in my other games.That said, if you can fix it and get it working, Two Worlds is worth trying. Getting past the technical issues, I have been playing the game quite regularly in the past week or so, putting in over 20 hours already, and most of that was just me exploring, killing monsters and bandits and groms and animals, then looting, equipping, improving, and selling their stuff without doing any quests. So I'd say it makes for a fairly enjoyable sandbox Action-RPG that I would recommend, but again, ONLY if you have no issues getting it to run. The technical issues should be a big red flag if you plan on getting this game at anything other than a considerable discount.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
												I really would recommend this game, I have invested about 25 hours in total into this game and I picked this up at 69p on a weekly sale. I'll list the pros and cons; Pros  It has a large world to explore and there is fast travel for those who wish to use it. There are a lot of quests and sidequests. A system of combining identical equipment you find to improve it, this makes it hard to choose what to use i.e. should i use this really good sword or keep my old one and keep improving since it's more common? There are a lot of different weapons and equipment to find/loot. Things like archery and chemistry are actually things you need to improve and learn rather than just knowing straight away. Each city has noticeable differences in culture which I really liked. Cities are quite large, compared to Skyrim where the cities are more like towns this actually does have large cities, it comes at a price of sacrificing the size of indoors however.  I am not saying it's better than Skyrim  Cons  It has some of the worst voice acting I've ever seen in a game, get used to hearing mayhaps, aye, and perchance just thrown into conversation with a slow talking drone. When an enemy is dead, they're dead, any random bandit encounters won't happen again once you kill them. Nothing respawns. It is very challenging to start, it starts you off with very poor equipment and launches you straight into what seems like at the time level 1000 enemies, you can still beat them it just requires a lot of determination. The main story is very boring so if you like story based games, probably want to avoid this. It seems a bit expensive given the experience playing it, don't get me wrong I loved playing it but that is mainly due to me buying it at 69p. Money pretty much has no value, countless times I would buy a 5000 gold sword and be broke and jump straight back up to 5000 within a few minutes just from selling loot and finding gold, this is good in some ways but not very challenging.There are many more things to say about this game but I cannot think of more at the minute. If i was to offer a comparison as to what Two Worlds is like then I would say it's something like what Oblivion would have been like if Bethesda would've had a fraction of it's budget.

content:
Posted: September 21, 2015
												I thought I'd give this game a try even though plenty seem to find it terrible and unfortunately I have to agree.This game is very outdated with ugly graphics and atrocious voice acting. Nothing managed to grab me and want to keep playing, story seems boring and cliche.I normally try to play a game for at least 10 hours before writing a review, but the voice acting immediately put me off, sounds very robotic with no emotion behind the words, sounds like someone is bored and just reading the lines half heartedly straight off the bat.The default controls are horrible as well, space for action and e for jump.At least you can change it. Though I could not map shift to anything at all and trying to map the tilde key just resulted in opening a dialogue function.Character creation is extremely limited, you can only play as a male and change his hair and features a tiny bit.I do not need to play much at all to decide that I really hate playing this game. It's terrible in every way. Talking to NPC's is like a form of torture, listening to dialogue that sounds like someone is very bored makes me want to mute the sound. A waste of time to play such a bad game when there are heaps better games I can spend my time playing. I only have playtime more than an hour as I was trying to get all the card drops.But if you feel the need to give it a try maybe get it on a sale. But to me this game is not worth playing even if it was free. I'd rate it 4/10 as it is not a joy for me  to play at all.

												I would recommend this game only to those people, whose attitude to RPG became a kind of "fondness". And i am one of them. This game became just a "+1" to my game list, though i like role-play games very much, but i'm not sorry for buying it. As usual, i will start from "minuses":- The sound. Who was synchronizing it? I suppose it was a computer with plain intonation. No emotions at all.- The plot. Just see - from the very beginning the main hero behaves a bit indifferent to his companion (leaves her alone) and that leads to her loss. 50/50 apprehension.- The hero's skill of sward flutter. It looked a bit strange, as if his knees and elbows were aching.- A lot of personal information is to be filled in into the form. Am i going to be a deputy or am i to cast a vote? :DAnd pluses:+ An open world. Always liked that, and this game isn't an exclusion.+ A skill-tree. Making level-ups brings you not only stats, but also an ability to choose your specialization. That's just a part of RPG.+ Graphics. Though it's not acute, but it also doesn't disturb your eyes. Never the less, it could have been MUCH better.I don't know, whether you are to buy this game or not. So it's up to you. I can't say something towards its "defence", as towards its "prosecution".

number of helpful: 16 of 33 people (48%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
												Recommendation: Play the game with the sound turned off, or at least the voice acting. If you can manage, maybe even turn off subtitles, too.This game has a lot going for it, but it's the small things that kill it, and there are so many of them. The voice acting and writing are horrible. The horse riding is a janky pile of garbage. I think the horse only has 5 frames of animation, and it has a (somewhat deficient) mind of its own, often deciding to veer in the opposite direction you indicated. The graphics are pretty bad. I'm all for taking into account the age of the game, but there are plenty of games this old that don't look this bad. It's surprising, because some of the assets look pretty good, while others look terrible. It's like they just lumped together a bunch of assets they had sitting around. The quests are also confusing and not very descriptive. I had to look up several of them in online guides.There are plenty more, but I stopped playing mostly because of those. It was just, plain silly. Pity, because I actually enjoyed a lot about this game. I still need to try TW2 to see if it's any better.

number of helpful: 13 of 27 people (48%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
												For its price point the game is decent but honestly it's pretty terrible overall. Enemies come in packs of 3-6 which is difficult/tedious to defeat early on, so your best strategy is to stand by a revive shrine and fight with rapidly regenerating health. Later on you're broken because alchemy is overpowered in that it lets you make permanent stat potions from easily obtainable materials. That and you can stack gems on a weapon and make its damage obscene.The real problem is the lack of quest markers. You know how you've probably played a game and thought "wow it's really lame this marker leads me right to the objective" Well, if you want to see why developers do that, try this game!!!!!! While there are quest markers most of them are to the person giving the quest and you get to wander around most of the time lost. Most of the directions are vague like "near" or "east of" and then not really either.There's also really draconic DRM too which apparently only allows three installs. The game's playable I guess... I mean it held my attention longer than Morrowind in this day and age, but really it's quite poor quality unfortunately.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful7 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												Probably the best game on Steam. No, I'm serious.This game is simply amazing. It's one of the best I've ever have played. To start off the story is astounding. Never have I played a game with such a massively in depth and rememberable tale such as this. You start off in the immensely fascinating world of Thalmont. The hero is on a quest to discover the mysteries of an ancient orcish curse left behind by the late Azrael who is the son of the executioner of Hell and a mortal woman. The hero is traveling with his sister, Kira, who holds the key to the knowledge about resurrecting Azrael. Gandohar, a powerful wizard that seeks to harness the power of Azrael for himself learns of this and then sets out to kidnap Kira. Throughout the game the hero is trying to find where the scoundrel Gandohar has taken his sister. Along the way he is forced to work with Gandohar as well as Reist Tungard, a shadow of a man who turns out to be a demon sent from hell. The hero battles his way through countless obsticles to try to save his sister. At the very end he is forced to make a choice that will inpact the destiny of the entire world. As for the game itself it's an amazing action RPG that rivals games like Skyrim and Dark Souls. The combat is extremely well balanced and always put you on the edge of your seat. The voice acting is phenomenal and makes you feel as though you are really in a dark medieval fantasy world. Almost every character has a unique voice actor and a interesting character model to go along with it. You can also customize your character much like the elder scrolls games. I find the customization to be better than the default elder scrolls process. You can increase every little detail from the height of the character to the arm legth and even small things such as the eye size. I personally made my character look like Steve Stifler from the American Pie movies. Overall I'd give this game a 11/10. It is truly one of the best games of this century. If you haven't played it then BUY IT NOW. It's only $0.99 which is a steal for such an amazing game.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												6/10 I will start with my dislikes to likes.I have to start off by saying, if you get this, you got a 99% chance it will crash on start up.. To fix, get the legacy drivers or whatever its called in the forums.Will work then.I had issues where sometimes the voices would stutter, and I didn't even get to see a entire cutscene because it wigged out and suddenly skipped the entire thing. :/The voice acting for most the characters is god awful and have no feeling in them. Where someone should be upset, they sound as upset as when your leg falls asleep.________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________As for the good stuff, I played a lot of skyrim, and some morrowind, and gotta say, the fighting animation is pretty cool. It isn't just swing your weapon around like a madman. So I did enjoy that.Also liked the skill tree. Was simple and clear.Despite the terrible voice acting, the story wasn't bad. I enjoyed it, even if it wasn't the most clear sometimes of where to go.Like this. (Go south to Goat Cave.) When the correct direction is SouthEast, and is a small dot that says Active Underground as its name.Now liking the story only got me so far, not spoiling anything but the ending was not worth the last few battles.. Not even close.. Not to mention unlike TES games, once you beat main story, thats it. You can't continue the adventure with the insane sword you got from the boss.. noooo, cutscene, end. Can reload a old file before the bossfight, or start a new character.Combat was fun, was a basic evade button (Q) to jump back. With enemies that need different thing. Like undead monsters are really only good to hurt with magic or enchanted weapons. Normal weapons will take very long to kill.I also like, which they do not explain, how you strengthen your weapon and armor. EX. Say you kill some bandits, and they all drop the same sword, you pick them up, drag them to your sword to add more strength to it. Helpful with basic, but the more rare and powerful make take longer to increase.All in all, great gameplay, good story, decent challenge, bad ending.Some bugs but I only seen a few. Replaying now as a archer.

												I finished the Epic Edition on DVD, then rebought it on Steam. I'm not a huge fan, but when a game is as universally panned as this one, I guess I need to make a point and reaffirm that some people will enjoy it.Yes, it's a low-budget game, yes it has bugs (what open world RPG doesn't?), but it also has one of my best memories as a gamer: I discovered by myself that I could accumulate weapon merges, and ended up a kill machine that could one-shot everything in its path -- all within the constraints of the game, rather than through the use of cheating.Abusing a game's mechanics is usually reserved to good, hardcore gamers. It's nice for once that a game could be abused by a more casual gamer.(Also, an Eastern 'area' in a serious med-fan setting? It's so messed up it's hilarious. You just can't hate that game.)
