number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												Two  Worlds is a third person medieval RPG with outdated, ugly graphics. The voice acting is atrocious and the music forgetable. Your character can only be male, with very little customization. Its unbalanced and glitchy, with the horses having pathing issues constantly. The quest tracker is confusing, with no clear path to take or who to talk to, to progress in the story. That said, the story seemed boring, pointless and cliche'. The clunky controls are horrible, not the regular space for jump its 'e' and space is for action O.o. with the exception of the mouse in the easy, unrewarding battles. Spells in the game feel weak and unaffective. Its obviously geared more towards being an MMORPG. It has Reality Pump DRM and you have to input a key and activate before you can play the game. They want your name, address, telephone number and e-mail address. It seemed extremely over the top intrusive considering its on Steam and I'm not going to play the multiplayer part. I would recommend playing Skyrim instead.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												I wanted so badly to like this game. and I do. Though just slightly. It can be an enjoyable game. But there are many many many flaws. The biggest ones, are that the voice acting is abysmal. by far the worst ive ever heard in a game. The missions = go here talk to this person, then go here and talk to him, then go here and talk to her, and kill the same enemies every 20 feet or so. and its hard to figure out what youre supposed to do too. And the combat is bad. Not the worst mind you, but very bad. it consists of mashing the LMCB over and over and over while he spins the sword in front of you. It only flat out sucks when you try to kill an archer cause they run from you and chasing them is annoying as ♥♥♥♥. I wont list anything positive about this game. ill simply say this: There are better simillar games out there. some for the same price. Get dragon age, the witcher, dark souls, dragons dogma, or even fable over this game. unless you get it on sale for like $1.25 like i did. Unlike every other steam reviewer, i wont say that this game sucks. its simply inferior and falls into the shadow of much better open world RPGs. Rest assured that it isnt the worst open world RPG. that honor goes to risen 3. Cant decide between giving this game a 5/10 or a 5.5/10, But what i can decide on is that even though i got *some* enjoyment, i doubt many other gamers would, so i cant recommend this game to the general gaming public. Pick this up if its on sale for less than $2 or if youre just an RPG junkie like me.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												Awesome roleplaying game great graphics and epic story. The beginning is very hard you have to take your time and build up be patient, dont dive into combat or you die. learn the jump back system for defense. The horse riding is better than any rpg ive played for realism, you can shoot your bow while riding horses. The combat system is very fun once you get comfortable with the way your character moves. THere is an ingenious way to stack equipment so nothing gets wasted and items lvl as they are stacked into eachother. There are hours and hours of content and side stories. The magic system is fantastic. This was due to buggyness rated as one of the worst RPGs but infact i find its one of the best RPGS now with the patching. I prefer this game over oblivion 10 to 1. The characters are more robust. Some people complain about the voice acting but its appropriate for the setting the old english. Also its nice to hear your character talk instead of read what he says as a mute as in most games.  There is plenty of element of exploration. This is a recommended must buy for anyone who likes skyrim,oblivion, gothic or any open world RPG 3rd person games. Also this game has some of the best looking armor sets ive ever seen in a game and the most veriety of weapons and items in any game to date.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
												Listen everyone. I had this game on xbox 360 and even though it is much more stable than the PC equivalent it is every bit as fun. Here is everything you need to knowMany first time players may experience crashing when starting the game, this is a common error and there are tons of people who have solved this problem within the discussion section. Game crashes were frequent in multiplayer when I started playing but I ironed them out over time and soon enough the game was fully playable. If this does not put you off then stick with meThe game mechanics and controls are not taught at any point in this game, there are times when you will either remap or try to learn the controls. When you just don't understand how the game works just keep trying and stick with it because it gets better.This game is like Dark souls, you will die, a lot. If you expect to be a double sword wielding, big♥♥♥♥♥♥bad♥♥♥♥♥then you should play another title because this game will not forgive you. You will come across enemy's who are a million times better than you and they will destroy you every time until you get to at least level 40-50.The enemies themselves look like walking cartoon characters, their animations choppy and faces incredibly goofy (especially the spider, the spider is my favorite). More times than not they are incredibly overpowered or come in large packs, it is at this point you realise the "Q" button is your best friend. You will kill that enemy eventually, it will just take a bit of time.Now onto the best bit, the voice acting. This is the single best part of the game, I challenge you not to laugh at a Germany company putting together an English script using words such as "Tis" and "Twould". The actors try their best to get around this but it is still the funniest thing, you will cringe often but damn these people are so quotable, especially your main character.In all the years I've played games I have never come across such a sloppy AAA title but my god is it fun. It is one of those so bad it's really good games. The combat is flawed but there are so many different weapon and Armour sets it's hard not to get a bit of a thrill when taking a hit that would previously have been fatal (all because of your new full plate hauberk) or the fact you killed the wolf with 4 hits instead of 5 with your shiny new Eye of Aziiral sword. The amount of customising in this game is astounding. There are hundreds of different armours, weapons and spells to choose from as well as hundreds of different monsters to kill. There is something so satisfying about killing a giant trachidis after dying 20 times and looting it's body for those sweet vitality boosting eggs, small victories lead to huge amounts of fun. It's a frustrating game, it's a hard game, but once you power through the hard parts the game gets so much better. I have one huge problem with this game however. Horse Riding. I didn't realise horses came on rollercoaster tracks because that's what it feels like. You tell your horse to turn left and he will go right as to avoid that tiny pebble in the road as apposed to jumping or walking over it like any other horse would do. You know it's bad when your horse driving completely sober is worse than your car driving 10 drinks in.In summery this game is bad, some might even call it terrible, but my god is it fun. I have never been more excited to play this game online with friends than any other game out there. It's buggy, it's glitchy, but killing that Cyclops after the 15th attempt and using the money from his corpse to buy a new sword is nothing short of satisfying.I love this game and I really urge everyone else to give it a try. Play about 7-8 hours before you make a decision because that gives you time to level up and get a better understanding of the game

content:

												Don't play this game,its a waste of time.+Open World+Good soundtrack overall+Dialogues are pretty good even with secondary characters+System combat can be fun+Horses+No class,you can do what ever you want+multiples cities(impressive for such a old game+a pure freedom of action from the start of the game+I kinda like these kind of graphics+the ambience toonow for the bad-the difficulty is crazy and not understandable,let me just say that the final boss don't damage you if you have a end game stuff but a random knight can one shot you,you probably see what i mean.-Artistic direction is random af-Lore too-Story is awfully bad and really short(its like 10 quests i think?)-Melee weapons are really bad in this game-A LOT of useless and not fun side stuff,like random dungeons with extremely difficult monsters to fight,orc camps,etc-EXTREMELY repetitive,don't expect things to append you will do the same things from the start to the end and like me probably's gonna get really annoyed after a dozen of hours-Really,really really bugged,lot of quest i couldn't finish because of that-The females character have the worst modelization i've ever seen in a game before.-Stealth and lockpicking skill are bugged,even if pnj are not around you'll get spotted,don't ask me why...-Melee fighting skills are bugged too and really useless when fighting.-The last cinematic of the game is probably the most random thing you will ever see(+no credits)There's probably things i forgot but that should be enough.I enjoyed the game at first and hated it at the end,please pass your way.

That being said , there are some things I want to mention.Starting with the cons , since they are more (not necessarily outweigh but are more) than the prosActivation is broken , and might even require you to use an unlegitemate keygen to activate the gameVoice acting is pretty bad.Character and NPC animations are choppy. I have no idea if the character movement is animated with 30 fps in mind , but it looks weird on anything above that.Story can be really cheesy at times.Pros:The game world is well crafted. Soundtrack is nice.Story , although filled with cliches, can be interesting enough to keep you playing.Im giving it a negative just because of the technical issues. The bad voice acting I can get over , but the hassle to get the game actually running and the immersion-breaking character movement are really annoying.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2014
												This game... Either you love it, or you hate it. In many ways it is one of the worst games i have ever played, However, despite it's numerous flaws, terrible voice acting, and cumbersome menu layout, it is still one of my favorite oepn world rpg games. As to why I enjoy it, I can't really say. It could be some kind of stockholm syndrome since it was the only game i had access too for a few months when I first played it on the xbox 360, or it could be that underneath the bugs it has a number of good gameplay qualities. (it has fairly good replay value, A few neat game mechanics, a lot of quests, etc) I'd reccomend it if you liked any of the games in the elder scrolls series, but be warned it is a bit of an aquired taste, so maybe you should wait for the next steam sale to buy it just in case it's not your cup of tea.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												This game is one of the best RPG games I have played. The Map is huge and access is free around the map. There is no loss of scenery and no annoying gaps where you get stuck. I am not an expert gamer so I like a game to be reasonably easy without being killed constantly. I stopped playing Dungeon Siege III for that reason. The character development is similar to Gothic III. Creation of upgrade potions require experimentation but, once discovered, gives a new dimension to the game. I played this for many hours over Christmas and found the tasks and roleplay to be challenging and very enjoyable. There is no excess gore in fighting and the horse riding control is the best I've come across allowing for good combat on horseback with upgrade skills. Magic is easy to use and spells are upgradeable as you increase in levels and controls are easy considering the many options available. If you liked the Gothic series and Risen, I can recommend this game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18
												I legitimately tried giving this game a chance. I heard there was a lot of initial backlash, but I also heard from multiple sources, be it reviews or from this community hub for the game, that it had some charm and it was otherwise a very solid RPG Experience. So going in to it with a tinge of anticipation and an open mind, I attempted to play Two Worlds hoping that I'd find exactly what people said it was: A solid RPG Experience with bad voice acting. Sadly, all I found was a tedious, boring sandbox-ish RPG with such a dry assortment of spells, traits, and characters wtih abysmal voice acting.Archery feels lackluster, spells, until very VERY late in to the game, feel irrelevant, and melee combat is reduced to a simple four hit combo where in some situations, you get the occasional crushing blow/critical hit that does a tremendous amount of damage. At first, I thought the combat was simple, but worked quite well for the game. As time went on, gaining levels and using my skill points accordingly, the game boiled down to abusing the invincibility frames in the back step whilst swinging very selectively for critical hits. Combat eventually felt bland, lackluster, dry, all these words and then some more that I'm not at liberty to say.I really, REALLY tried to give this game a chance, playing it all the way from start to finish with a game-file that says my total play time was approximately 11 hours. In those 11 hours, only the first two, maybe three felt like the game delivered what fans promised it did. Afterwards, the game otherwise falls short of whatever it was meant to provide, and I felt more frustrated than anything else by the end.All in all folks, the game kinda sucks. I mean, there's really not much else for me to say.

												Just no.Got it a really good discount hoping that it would help kill a few hours exploring a new world? And was I in for a disappointment? It's just bad. I could barely go through an hour before I found out how to get out of the game, enter my Steam library and choose the delete option.Strangest of all is that now, I can place a single thing that turned me off from this game. There is just this overwhelming distaste hanging around it that is the result of so many things and issues. To name a few - the combat system, the dialogs, the atmosphere of the world, the menus, the in-game HUD, the combat! Well you get the idea.If you are placed with the choice between spending a couple of pounds for this "thing" and buying a cheeseburger - go for the burger, at least it will leave a better, albeit brief, impression.

												First, there's the DRM and registration nonsense to slog through, then once you've registered, the game presents with wretched graphics, clunky interface, two-dimensional combat mechanics, and some of the worst voice acting ever perpetrated upon a helpless player. "But it's an old game, you shouldn't expect glorious graphics and great acting," some might say-  This game was made in the same year as Dragon Age: Origin and Fallout 3. It has no excuse. It's not worth the time it took to DL, let alone the purchase price, even on sale. Your 10 bucks has thousands of better ways to be spent.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 12, 2015
												I picked this game up in an RPG bundle on Bundle Stars for 5 bucks (As I'm writing this, that bundle is still  available.) I actually bought the bundle for Two Worlds II, but I figured if I played that one first, I would never go back and play this one, so I decided to play TW first. 	Perhaps it is because of this that through the whole game I had a feeling of wanting to just get it over with. At the beginning of the game I was getting killed by everything, and I just wanted to get it over with, then I got a little stronger and acquired some better gear, but I really just wanted to get it over with. Then I finally did get it over with, and I looked back on the 20 hours I spent on the game and thought “well, I’m glad that’s over.” I did miss out on the finer parts of the story due to skipping a LOT of dialogue because the voice acting is laughable and the on screen text is an odd “period appropriate” font which is hard to read.(This obviously was before the world realized that fantasy RPGs don’t need to have period-appropriate gothic fonts and HUDs with ornamental metal decorations around the mini-map and bars, and where the menus look like scrolls/notebooks)But what the main storyline boils down to is basically a series of fetch quests, to acquire the different parts of an artifact which will help something something the tomb of an orc god something something the main characters sister something something bring the god back something something. It's not very interesting, but it's not horridly boring. 	As I said, the main story is just some fetch quests. For me this just meant running past a bunch of enemies, grabbing the artifact piece, and running like hell to the nearest exit. Do this a few times, bring them all together, fight the bosses, game over. 	BUT there are also a slew of side missions to enjoy and different factions to be a part of. I chose to help out the necromancers and the merchants guild, but there are other groups. The combat is alright with me, but it’s nothing special. For me it was equal parts slashing away with a weapon and pausing to switch spells. Not as stiff as, say, an Elder Scrolls game, with Two Worlds featuring automatic aiming and quick access bar which I never actually learned to customize except for the spells. Though the system was certainly not as entertaining as, say, the first Witcher. As for the enemies on which you will be employing your combat, I thought there was a good diversity!  Though the RPG staple, “giant rat”, did not seem to appear (or I just didn’t notice) there are some quite cool enemies to do battle with. You have your standard wolves, skeletons, orcs, and bears, but also ghouls, zombies, dead knights and a  slew of others, all of which fight in different ways. There are creatures unique to different terrain, which is cool, and there are massively overpowered beings such as golems and hell lords (yes, HELL LORDS) walking around like they own the place. Overall, I was happy with the diversity of enemies. However, the minor boss battle at the end was an hour of me spamming the mouse button, and I hate that, though that may have something to do with me rushing though the game and getting to the boss before being properly leveled. I’m not going to talk about the magic or leveling system because I didn’t put a lot of time into it, seeing as I was breezing through the game. But, of course, average mechanics can be made up for with a good story and atmosphere right? Well let’s talk about both of those. Story: It’s fine. It was underwhelming for me because, as is the case with these RPGs, the fate of the world was at stake, but I didn’t really care what happened to the characters in this world, because none of them were interesting or endearing. There’s something close to characterization in the relationship between the hero (you) and his sister, but it’s not really that engaging. Atmosphere: The world looks quite good. When you pop into first person view and look around, there are a lot of pretty landscapes to behold. All types of environments are represented here (Glaciers, fields, deserts, bamboo forests, lava-pits, big cities, small villages), and they all look pretty great, but they are sometimes inexplicable. A desert will abruptly turn into a field, and other things of the like. But though these landscapes are pretty, they are also quite empty. There are many expanses of wilderness which don’t have any interesting features, NPC’s or enemies. Overall, the atmosphere is of a world which is interesting, but it does not make me want to BE there, which is what I look for in an RPG world.	 Anyway, though my review is negative, I wouldn’t say that this is a horrible game. If you can get it in a bundle, as I did, it’s probably worth a play through, but only if you’re into the genre.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												I bought this game when it went on sale for $2 and I gotta say it was worth it. I was a bit worried after hearing all the negitive reviews but soon realized that most of the negitivity was coming from the xbox version. The PC version has better frames and better controls over the xbox. Pros: Great combat system, Tons of magic and abilities, Good monster variety, So many armor and weapon sets, Huge world filled with bandits and monsters roaming around, A lot of quests.Cons: Bad voice acting, Some frame drops here and there, Mediocre story, Some character animations look a bit weird.Overall its a great game. 8/10

content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												Simple list for you guys if your looking to buy the game, So here it goes:-PC controls are better then Console, as i played both,-Plot is O-kay, -Combat system is VERY good, more of a personal refrence, Early game is hard, however as you go further into the game, you get better items, etc. So wait for the game to pick up a bit.-Content isent repetitve nor junk, It is actually quiet fun. The world is very open and you should explore every cervice and crack of it.-CREATURES DO NOT RESPAWN, I actually dont mind this, However, many do, So take this into account for your Purchase, I personally dont need them because i spend my skill-points and stats very wisely, and i Search for good items, Thus i dont need to farm creatures, just do quests and clear a region. Also, to mention, Randomly at night, ghosts will appear where slayed enemies or NPC's are, you need magic to hurt them. (They do grant XP!)-ENDING IS BAD, and you cannot continue after it, If you want to however, Save before you do the boss fight, common sense.-Game rating is 8/10 for me, For others though, i would say 7/10So what are you doing?! BUY IT NOW!!!!!!!!!!!!

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25
												You know... It saddens me to have to say this, but I really didn't like this game very much, and I love open-world games like this.Here's a tip for the programmers: If you want a game that is to go toe to toe with the Elder Scrolls franchise, it would be wise to actually make a game with gender selection in your character creation and have combat that actually... I don't know.... is good.The first problem I have that I will list is a small nitpick, but still a problem in my eyes. The character creation. I understand the hero of the story is canonically male, but so is the Champion of Cyrodiil from Oblivion, but Oblivion still lets you play a character that is female. I don't know if this was just a design choice or if Two Worlds was just TopWare/Reality Pump's first RPG, but.... Why can I only have a male character? That completely limits your role-playing. Why do the siblings HAVE to be brother and sister? Why can't it be two sisters? If you want to make a game that is about playing the way you want like a Bethesda RPG, then allowing the player to have a male OR female character would be a good start.Second is the combat. Particularly the archery part of combat. WHY CAN I NOT STRAFE WHEN USING A BOW? It makes archery almost completely useless and pointless. Hell, I've died multiple times on easy enemies because I tried to strafe like in any Elder Scrolls game to establish distance, but instead ran away, cancelling my bow attack. Melee combat unless you get a good enough weapon is pointless. The only thing that isn't barely functional in this game when it comes to combat is magic. When I buit the hero as a mage, the dude was nearly untouchable.Third, the atrocious animation, dialogue exchanges and the awful voice acting. "The.Orcs.Having.Religion? ...Bah...!" Why does it sound like the voice actors were having an off-day and why use King James English so awkwardly? There is a fine art to using the language of medieval speech. The lip-synching is very much off, making the first Godzilla look like Star Wars in terms of mouth movement to the sound of the actor's voice. It also is like the game can't decide if the protagonist is fully voiced or a silent protagonist. When you choose a dialogue option for speech, he doesn't say anything. Yet any other time, he's chatting. Hell, he even gives some bad one-liners when in combat. "Pathetic." Or when you come back after dying. "I live again." (Or... sorry, that should be,) "I.Live.Again."Fourth, for an open-world RPG meant to put Oblivion to shame, the world is actually rather small comparatively.Five, the fact that the game just.... expects you to know all this stuff and who this Aziraal or Aazhizha or whoever, without the slightest hint of an explanation, leaving me like, "Okay, and I should care about any of this.... why....?" A bit of depth into the lore of the game's universe would have been nice. Or the game also could have told you that the woman you're off to save was your sister earlier than when you get the note telling you that your sister is alive and well.Six, the story barely makes any sense and feels like a knock-off of the Final Fantasy franchise.On the plus side, the game looks.... pretty good and the armor designs at times are pretty cool. The soundtrack is decent from time to time.My point being.... If you're a fan of games like the Elder Scrolls, there are better games out there than Two Worlds. and the sad part is, the game's not absolutely horrible, it's just..... Mediocre.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												I didn't even get past the main menu. Firstly, the game would CTD on startup until I got an old PhysX driver from the Nvidia website.Then the in-game cursor was stuck in place, but I could (extremely inconsistently) move an invisible one around. I tried looking for solutions on forums, but none of them worked. The one which would likely have helped (disabling hardware cursor in the options menu, it helped in the sequel) was unusable, because even after about 3 minutes of trying, I wasn't able to click the interface tab with the erratic invisible cursor.Open world RPGs are notorious for being buggy, but I don't recall ever playing one where even the main menu was completely broken.Combined with a registration DRM, which pretty much asks you to fill out a resume, I have decided this game wasn't worth the hassle. Fortunately, I got it in a bundle, otherwise I would have been really mad. Buy this game at your own risk.

/*
 * Enjoy this game in five fun steps!
 *
 * 1. Start game, receive welcome message -
 * "Application stopped responding". Reinstall
 * Nvidia PhysX to proceed.
 *
 * 2. Enter product key. Start typing and play
 * a minigame: enter 4 digits/letters while cursor
 * jumps to next input field after two. Endless fun.
 * Want to press Shift-Tab to look at the key again?
 * That also counts as a valid input.
 *
 * 3. After you had your fun there, you need to register
 * this copy online, by entering your full name,
 * mail, address, phone, fax and other relevant
 * personal information because you want to play
 * this old game you got for free so badly.
 *
 * 4. Press "Activate later" -> "Start a new game"
 * -> "This option is not available unactivated".
 *
 * 5. Enjoy background song while you wait for all trading cards to drop.
 */

content:
Posted: April 14, 2014
												Utter Unplayable Garbage.Which is too bad, because it really does have potential. All the RPG elements are there, and the game tries to give you freedom in your choices, which is also great. There's a ton of armor sets, and the map is frigin' huge. That's all well and good, except it was all programmed by monkeys with keyboards. The combat...oh my lord the combat is horrendous. Seriously, if you're gonna make a dodge mechanic, can I please control the direction in which I dodge? Remember MOrrowind combat? Yeah even this is 10 times worse than that. The visuals are gross, pixel-y, and look like a bad photoshop filter. Horse combat!? Im my MMO, oh please tell me they at least got that right...Nope. The horse combat is ♥♥♥♥♥♥. The horse doesn't control well, and just makes you feel like an idiot charging into a group of enemies. I am gonna play Two Worlds 2 and hopefully find some redemption for this production team. If they were smart, they fired the old team and got a new one. I am really glad I only paid 4.00 USD for the whole package.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												Found this game on a Bundle website for $5. Thought to myself, "What a deal! I've always wanted to play this game it sounds so cool!", i was sorely mistaken after playing. The size of the download size had me worried, Not even 5 Gb. I woke up this morning stoked to play my new game. Open the game up, and what do you know, a ridiculous activation set up that you HAVE to do. it has the option to do it later, but tells you that you can only play the demo because you won't put in your personal information (I.E. Full name, address, gender,etc.) and is required. I still had my hopes high for the game, thinking that maybe it would be worth the activation hassel. Once again i was wrong. With no sort of tutorial, you are thrown into a place where you don't know the controls and don't even have some sort of direction to go. There is no marker or header telling you what do do. I finally figured out the controls enough to kill a couple guys with terribly choppy comabt and fluency.  Finally I find that the way out was where you started from...wait, what? Yep. Terrible design, no tutorial, no sense of direction, and choppy as balls combat. Maybe the open world will be waiting for me outside this tomb! got outside and was pleased with the evironment for a solid 3, maybe 4 seconds. Then i saw a bear. Well i think it was a bear, it kinda looked like a bear from a nintendo 64 game. Thinking, "Awh♥♥♥♥♥♥ gunna go kill a bear since it's in the starting area!", as it comes running at me with it's 4 frame motion run, it ones hits me. In the starting area. Back to the tomb. Played for an hour, unbelievabley disappointed with this game. I think the PS2 game "A Bard's Tale" was much better than this game. It definetly had better combat fluency, that's for sure.

												Great game. Had it on windows XP and it works great. Got it on steam now for my new PC, but it refuses to work on windows 8.1 pro. Honestly, I'm having a hard time recommending this game on Steam, since the problem seems to be the Reality Pump DRM system, which locks up the game BEFORE i have a chance to enter the game's serial. If this single problem can be solved, either by Valve or by Reality Pump, so their DRM actually WORKS instead of locking up the game, then i'll be more than happy to revise this recommendation.Please, do not be mistaken, the game is great, just this problem is stopping me from enjoying the game on my new PC.

number of helpful: 3 of 9 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												Originally got this game to play with a friend. Was able to start up the game with no problems. Registration to start the game was not such a big deal as many people have made it out to be. I can not mention anything of the singleplayer as I have not tried any of that. However with multiplayer out of the three available servers that are up, only one of them is working and its a EU server. From there the population of the server is near dead being at the most I have seen around being ten or less people. From there trying to connect with my friend to begin a game together became the problems. Both of us can start up and host a game but neither of us could ever join the other. We have tried every recommended step such as ports, dropping firewalls, bypassing routers, etc. Sadly I discovered that many others have had the same results with no solution.If your looking to enjoy this game with a friend, sadly its a complete risk if it is going to work or not for you. I do not recommend this game on its multiplayer fuctions.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												Ive been looking for a game to play with a couple friends so when I saw this had multiplayer yea I had no problem paying 5 bucks for it, especially after reading the reviews. I kinda just wasted 5 bucks. There really isnt a multiplayer if you look into it. But the game also kinda blows as well. All these reviews keep saying its on the level of Oblivion but for real Id rather play morrowind than this. Obliviona dn most other rpgs tear this game aprt. The combat is awful, the enemies are incredibly hard, the animations really throw me off, the camera sucks, the dialog kills me to hear, and so on. The game does have an awesome amount of weapons and armor though. But the game just feels dead when I play it. The world feels sooo empty for an rpg. It kinda seems like someone was working on a rpg and they had an good idea but were like" #@!% it I dont feel like touching up al the crappy stuff" I really wanna like this game and I feel like it has so much potential but I just cant. But for real dont believe all these reviews talking about it being like oblivion and gothic. Theres a reason you've heard all about The Elder Scrolls and you have no idea what Two worlds is besides the fact you saw it was 5 bucks on steam.

I've made a terrible mistake.While it is true that I never actually PLAYED the game, the amount of trouble this POS game gave me to get it to actually work was supremely frustrating.  But then the real kick in the jewels is that everything about the game is atrocious.  The graphics, the voice acting, the pacing, the introductory narrative that would have been written better by a prepubescent child completely improvising what's supposed to be the beginning of a riveting adventure story.  The world and the conflict feels cliche and boring.  There was no real character customization beyond an insultingly negligible character skin selection.I wouldn't recommend this game at all to anyone under any circumstances ever.  Unless you hate having fun.  In which case play up.

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												Not the greatest game, but a damn fine buy at $1.49.I bought this & like many before me, immediately experienced crashing. after checking the forum I quickly found a link to a legacy driver that fixed the issue. I had issues getting my gamepad to work with the game, but conquered that battle. And even after getting the gamepad to work, the game (especially the combat) handles like a monster truck with no power steering. Now don't get me wrong even after all the issues above & the occasional crash (after 20+ I experienced: 1 during gameplay & 1 lock up during exiting the game) this game is pretty friggen good.Combat is a bit clunky. I wish it was as polished as Amalur's, but I wasn't expecting a whole hell of a lot coming into this one. The best I can say for combat is it's passable.Storyline is above average. Not too cliche.Graphics are not horrible for a 2009 release.Audio is pretty damn good. I found my self impressed with the wildlife sounds Top Ware bothered to add.Two Worlds WILL fight with you. Knowing that, would I recommend it at full price? Probably not, there are better games out there more deserving of the $9.99. I would say grab this fast, if it's on sale & you enjoy 3rd person, open world RPGs..... Oh & if you have the patience.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
												The game itself feels like an old version of Skyrim. However there are so many small things in that game that totally ruin the game experience.For me it felt like the game didn't scale - like it was expecting you to throw  it away after an hour of gameplay.I was a level 65 mage in the end. I had the best possible staff at around lvl 15... Btw. you have 2x10 skill slots, but only 3 of them can contain spells. Most skills are pretty much useless. The AI could be tricked very easily. There were almost no items for high level characters - and the few which where there had the same stats as low level equipment.I could go on about this, but I read that the second part is much better - so I am off to that one :P

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												First of all, I must say I paid 1 dollar for this game and was aware of what it was (played it some years ago), so I'm not really mad at it and I consider I'm objective.The game isn't all that bad (it is bad, don't get me wrong). I start playing it in a Let's Play and it's fun to play, like a very bad movie is fun to watch.The biggest issue with it is that it's almost unplayable. I had to install nvidia legacy drivers and reboot my computer to launch it the first time. Made 3 episodes of my let's play... Today I want to launch it again, but it doesn't want to :/Also, when it's working, the game crashes a lot. For example I have to load my game while in window 800x600 mode (otherwise it crashes) and only when I'm in game I can go fullscreen with a higher resolution... The game made that easy since everytime I launch it, it's in window 800x600 mode again !Also there's a very intrusive DRM that ask you where you live and stuff like that to activate the game. Apparently you can only install it on 3 different computers before having to ask the game staff to give you more activations. Unacceptable.Concerning the game itself :- The gameplay is kinda fun with some minor issues that stacked together ruins the game : you have to stand still to shoot arrows, melee combat is a random mess- Horses are cluncky as ♥♥♥♥: it's like driving a big australian truck (you can almost hear the BIP... BIP... BIP when you move backward). You can use bows while riding but let's just say you don't want to do that :D- It's not really fluid, voice acting is a disaster (on a furnitures commercial level), the story isn't good, etc etc...Except if you plan to mock the game (and are okay to spend money for a game that will probably not run unless you spend 20-50 minutes on it), don't buy this piece of crap.The game could be good if it was more polished and actually playable (the actual game would be very limit as an early-access title). What a waste :/

content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												Alright, I'll start with saying this. I had fun with this game. So why do I not recommend it?  Because it is not for most people. I'm kind of weird, because I love a lot of games many people don't love, so I like this, but not many people will.Here's why...> There are a lot of bugs and glitches, and it is very unpolished. Plus, it is not optimized for newer hardware, and at 1080p, has a bunch of render issues, and is overall a drag to work.> Many quests seem very underwhelming and, while it offers a lot of loot and "rewards," it doesn't seem that satisfying.> This game is a beautiful open world tarnished by crappy writing, poor optimization, and broken gameplay.> Gameplay is confusing and sometimes is broken.> Voice acting is terrible. Don't even bother with it.Overall, it is very dissatisfying. Like I said, I still had fun, and I got this for $1 in an India Gala Bundle with a bunch of other, better games, so I don't have any buyer's regret, but I do not recommend paying full price for this. At least, most people will find themselves dissatisfied.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 18, 2015
												Why did I even play this game? 1) I hated the wonky controls-Usually in these kinds of games using the keyboard and mouse as a control scheme, the spacebar is jump, but not this one, it is the actioin button. 2) No direction-Seriously, no direction at all. The game starts in this temple place and you have no clue what is going on. Well, granted, I did skip the beginning cutscene, but still, it doesnt really explain much.3) Almost no character creation-Like, what's the point of this games character development? You can only change the hair style and color and facisl features of your character, but thats it, might as well be a predesigned character anyways.Lastly, I could only stomach 30 minutes of this game. There is no map button, there is no easy way to block, the bar at the bottom of the screen doewssnt really work all that well.Bonus-NO TUTORIAL!!!!!!! Do NOT buy or play this game!!

content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												Alright, I'll start with saying this. I had fun with this game. So why do I not recommend it?  Because it is not for most people. I'm kind of weird, because I love a lot of games many people don't love, so I like this, but not many people will.Here's why...> There are a lot of bugs and glitches, and it is very unpolished. Plus, it is not optimized for newer hardware, and at 1080p, has a bunch of render issues, and is overall a drag to work.> Many quests seem very underwhelming and, while it offers a lot of loot and "rewards," it doesn't seem that satisfying.> This game is a beautiful open world tarnished by crappy writing, poor optimization, and broken gameplay.> Gameplay is confusing and sometimes is broken.> Voice acting is terrible. Don't even bother with it.Overall, it is very dissatisfying. Like I said, I still had fun, and I got this for $1 in an India Gala Bundle with a bunch of other, better games, so I don't have any buyer's regret, but I do not recommend paying full price for this. At least, most people will find themselves dissatisfied.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												Finished it at Sunday (Hard difficulty), have some things to say.Cons:1) Turn the voice down ASAP. Horrible, despicable, disgusting VA.2) The script is so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ bad... I have no idea who tried to make it "medieval" with all these phrases like "pray tell me", "pithee" etc., I just stopped trying to read through these terrible, horrible, damnable lines and just skipped everything. Never lost a thing. 3) Plot is boring, subplots are boring and unrememberable. 4) Horse riding tends to be awkward. Like, AWKWARD round riding.5) Tons of useless NPC, boring names, overall "i try to be medieval and fail at it" feeling.6) Almost every encounter can be dealt with jumping around HP/MP shrines.7) Weird animations. Peasants axing the ground? Scything the trees? Pros:1) Really vast gameplay options. Magic? Pretty nifty. Summoning spells helped me a lot. Chaos Rage + Ressurection made lategame into somewhat long, but funny fights with your little armies killing their little armies. You can kill a guy, loot him and ressurect him into the fight (dont take his weapons though). Did not went for combat or archery, cuz i wont be going to play this again. Magic is really funny, honestly.2) Somewhat intriguing world. It is fun to explore it, thought the southern part and the desert are meh. 3) Funny upgrading system. Xzibit must have taken part in it with all this "I put a sword on the sword to hit them with the sword while i hit them with the sword".4) Nice alchemy with your own concotions. Overall:If you are all into gameplay - try it.If you are looking the "R" letter in this RPG - dont ever look at it.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2014
												This game is a disaster.  There are so many things about it that were executed poorly that I have trouble believing it's a finished product.  That said, there are a number of great seeds here, and if they fixed almost everything about the game, it could actually be enjoyable.The voice acting is heroicly awful, it is visually appalling (even for its age), and the dialogue and story appear to have been written by my 8-year-old nephew.  The combat is stiff and impossibly diffucult, and they make traveling on foot pointless within the first hour of the game.  The only reason you should buy this game is so  you can understand that no matter how hard you try, at least you will not have been responsible for releasing this game.It baffles me that it got a sequel, and baffles me more that the sequel might actually be good...

												Ehhhh. I can't recommend this one. Sure games that have the mobs leveling up with you, still at least try to make things fun and enjoyable, while making you feel like you are getting stronger. This game doesn't do that. The stronger you get, the stronger the enemies get, and its a never ending balance that cannot be broken. It becomes boring rather fast, as leveling in this Epic edition, is Epicly slow. Expect every fight to be a hard one.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 29, 2014
												Sadly, I cannot say this game was good. It has a lot of good going for it, and at one time during development it may have even been a great game, but it simply has too many bugs, is too glitchy, and has really weird commentary by the characters like saying "What do we have here?" every ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ time you pick a plant. It gets annoying as fast as the small enemy target areas which seem impossible to hit sometimes so it's a lot of button mashing. I bought it on the sale for $1.50 and that was all that made it worth it. Great graphics for its age, and it has some good ideas, but stay as far away from it as possible. Once you're in, you'll be mad at it for life. Oh, did I mention the half hour it takes for the initial start-up of the game, plus giving all your personal information to the developers so they can "keep you up to date with the latest content"? Yea, major no no.

number of helpful: 3 of 11 people (27%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 24, 2014
												I cannot recommend this game. I want to, very badly, but I cannot. Yes, even for $2.50, not worth it. The Last Remnant is cheaper and a better challenge, no lie. Anyway, this is why this classic should be laid to rest.Before I could even play the game I ha to download a special driver update because my Windows 7 cannot outwardly play this game. This is despite it being RECOMMENDED as a OS by STEAM. Fail. After the first fifteen minutes was scouring the internet for information I fnally got into the game. Two Worlds was made in 2007, so I forgave the awkward character creation system and lackluster options in hair styles and colors. Even the "great for its time" graphic rendering. For me, however, the big let down came when we got to gameplay.Anyone else take notice that it uses Diablo I font type? Like to the "T", I wonder if they paid for that font? Anyway, the voice acting began to remind me of a bad early 90's dubbed anime. The actors kept missing inflections of words and botching their lines 'emotionally' and it was just the opening scene! I get to my first objective, kill a few baddies and gain xp and again bad things happen. Three of them come at me, I fire a fireball at the first one then go to swap targets to attack the encroaching second baddie. Wait, how do you change targets? I almost die trying to figure this out and use the awkward "Q: jump forward, E: jump backward" dynamic to slay and burn my enemies to proper pulps and ashes.  Afterwards I take a quick moment to alt-tab to Google to find my answer. The answer? You cannot swap targets. Wait, what? Excuse me? A game that requires me to focus attacks and fight multiple monsters not only hasn't figured out how to "jump and direct" at the same time but doesn't have a simple TARGETING feature?I'm sure this game was great in 2007, the original Final Fantasy was groundbreaking. Now a days, however, there's so much more that could be and should have been done to this game. The dynamic of spell making and reputation systems are great, but it's really hard to get to that part of this game when it fumbles over every other step. I have Two Worlds II GOTY on my PS3 and a lot of these issues WERE handled. This is why, 2007 was a great year for TW, but not 2014 and not even for $2.50.

number of helpful: 0 of 5 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												A relatively old game, finished it for the second time now, and enjoeyed it more than the first time.What I like+ good graphics for the main character ( the armor & weapons look awasome )+ pretty good graphics for the environment+ action oriented rpg, you don't get to just walk around, you find stronger monsters everywhere + motivational AI: you find monsters that kill you in one shot at first! So you grow stronger, until, in the end you feel like a god ( you fight the same monster, 5 - 10 in number )+ no puzzles ( i don't like them )+ simple but fun combat and spells+ stacking armors/weapons of the same type ( if you find armors/weapons of same kind you can just combine it for something stronger )What I didn't like+ if you use a horse, quick save because you could get stuck in some textures ( rarely but happens )+ awkward control with the horse+ some animations could have been better+ real doge ( you have a back dodge ), but a dodge controlled with arrrow keys makes the fight more dynamic+ end game too easy. I was a god in the end, pre-boss took 5 max hits, and boss 2  hits. + game crashes ( very rarely but happens ). I suggest to use quick save.I recommend the game if:+ you are an action RPG lover ( dislike rpgs with quests where you get 3 flowers, etc )+ can make a compromise with some elements of graphics/animations+ don't like puzzles, because there are none in this gameOtherwise, go and get it, you'll have a lot of funCheers

number of helpful: 0 of 5 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												Very poor game. Hardware-wise it stutters on 9 out of 10 machines you play it on. In terms of gameplay. the world is very open, yet you still feel boxed-in. Horse riding is a total pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ they seem to have their own agenda and don't all-in-all, it doesn't work very well. They bump into invisible walls and take themselves up weird routes. Combat feels completely devoid of consideration, you just repeatedly LClick. You're stunlocked while attacking, so attack once more than you want to (which is way too easy to do) and you'll take hefty punishments from the thousands of mobs you pull just walking through the wilderness. It feels way more like an MMO that only you are playing rather than an RPG - there are far too many mob encounters, meaning it takes forever to get anywhere if you're not the kind to just pull a trail of creeps around with you. The voice acting is ridiculously bad, and the dialogue is cringeworthy. I've played some bad RPGs, but this one takes the cake. I hear the second one's better, though.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												Game crashes on start-up, so you have to go to another website and downlaod a driver. After that you have to manually enter your keycode, then they want you to register it (name, address, phone #, birth date, etc.... yeah right, I'm going to give them all that). And to top things off, it won't acivate. Games like this just ruin your day.After another 5 attempt to get it to activate, I come to find out that you can only play multiplayer on European servers, American ones are shut down. I may have seen at any one time up to a whole 3 other people playing it. It suffers from terrible lag.When playing multiplayer, you have to finish all the quests in one sitting, otherwise it restarts all over again.'Oh your connection timed out, too bad, time to start over from the beginning again.' But on the plus side you keep everything you got from the previous session.Co-op is pretty much non-existant, all you share is exp and gold. And all monsters are always in groups of 3.No penalty for dying and I died alot.And to think I bought this game just for the multiplayer portion of it.

												I could talk for hours about how terrible this game is (the awful enemy AI, the horrible horse riding mechanics, the overly large mostly dead world, the terrible combat, the atrocious writing which barely makes sense....I could go on), but instead I'm just going to describe one quest to you. It pretty much sums up what's wrong with this game in a nutshell and might be the single worst designed RPG quest I've ever encountered.So, some guy in a random village wants a curse of  fish monsters eliminated so he tells you to go speak to a Wizard---who sends you to a villager, who sends you to a lady, who sends you back to the villager, who sends you to the Wizard, who sends you to the villager, who sends you to the Lady, who sends you to the Wizard, who sends you back to the lady, who then kills herself for some reason, then you have to go back to the Wizard to finish. Yeah, so basically 20+ minutes of running back and forth listening to♥♥♥♥♥♥dialog. And there are more quests like this!

content:
Posted: July 24, 2015
												Don't even know where to begin with this game... It was my childhood favourite game and i loved every single aspect of it, and i had the game from day 1 so to all the people saying there's glitches well you shoulda played back then!:DThis game doesn't need an amazing set of voice actors or incredible HD graphics because it does what all old school games do.. blows your mind with amazing combat and immersion.Not to mention it has so many elements to it:-You're walking down the road and stumble across a bandit camp.-They block your path and demand gold.- (low level character) tells them they should leave before they get hurt and they laugh before charging you-(High level character) doesn't even need to tell them to leave as they're already fleeing for their lives- after scaring or killing the bandits you pillage their camp and find a master locked chest- spends 5 lockpicks trying to open but to no avail- gets rewarded for reaching a lockpicking goal and receives 1 skill point- uses said skill point to level up lockpicking skill- Attempts lock with last lockpick and opens chest first time- about to loot chest and gets chased away by bounty hunters that have been set upon you by a regions guard- get's one shot because hunters are OP- respawns close by and runs for the hills where you find the bandits camped that you scared earlier- befriends the bandits and returns to that master locked chest- your bandit friends help you take out the bounty hunters smoothly- you are accepted by your new bandit friends and live out your days drinking ale and pillaging10/10 still a better RPG than skyrim

												My Grandfather smoked his whole life. I was about 10 years old when my mother said to him, 'If you ever want to see your grandchildren graduate, you have to stop immediately.'. Tears welled up in his eyes when he realized what exactly was at stake. He gave it up immediately. Three years later he died of lung cancer. It was really sad and destroyed me. My mother said to me- 'Don't ever smoke. Please don't put your family through what your Grandfather put us through." I agreed. At 28, I have never touched a cigarette. I must say, I feel a very slight sense of regret for never having done it, because this game gave me cancer anyway.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 10, 2011
												This is one game I regret not playing earlier. My first impressions were not good. The game seemed shallow and lacking polish for an RPG by current standards. I convinced myself to give it more of a chance, and proceeded to play beyond my initial dissatisfactions. However, if I were to depict my appreciation for this game on a graph vs. time, it'd look like an exponential curve in the positive "y" direction. In other words, I now realize how wrong my first impressions were. The combat looks and feels awkward at first because the character hasn't yet developed any combat skills. In the beginning, the world feels empty and uninspiring because of the sheer scope of it and the fact that the various methods of fast travel haven't yet been realized. The amount of content this game offers is quite possibly more substantial than any RPG I've ever played (even more than Oblivion and Gothic 3). I highly recommend this game. It already has me looking forward to Two Worlds II (the sequel).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 22, 2014
												Own it on disc and played it for ages but didn't mind paying the £1.50 sale price rather than look for it in the cupboard to give it another go. The animations might be a bit ropey but the visuals aren't too bad. The combat could have been done better and feels a bit dated, using the bow is pretty poor, but if you can look beyond it's faults there is a huge game for the tiny price. Always liked the way you can combine matching items to boost them up (mouse over them in the inventory and if they match they turn green, then just drag 'n' drop). I would suggest using the 'jump-back' key to avoid enemy attacks and survive combat for longer though, especially at the start, and carry a mix of slashing, piercing and bashing weapons with different elemental upgrades. Horses have their own inventory, just stand next to them and get the panel up, use these to solve your storage problems by gathering a few around a teleport site. Doing this and having different ones for different item types makes it easier to collect armour sets etc and to keep matching items to combine them.   Huge world, loads of locations to discover, tons of loot, vast number of quests, hacking down creatures while on horseback, if you want an epic rpg experience and give it the chance it deserves you'll soon find yourself ignoring it's failings and find a good game, get it at sale price and you can't go wrong.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 22, 2014
												It's a very underrated title, often looked down upon because it was somewhat similar to "Oblivion" back in the day. Personally I think of it like a separate series of game, and I like it. It's a big and solid game with lots and lots of content, and many hours of enjoyment. Doesn't look half bad either to be honest, even though it's slightly dated. There's also community patches to fix certain aspects of the game I believe, since the developer has most likely stopped patching the game all together. I like it, and if you like 3rd person action RPG's with a huge open world packed with stuff to do, you will too. 8/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 10, 2014
												Two Worlds Epic Edition (Two worlds 1) is a hidden gem. It is Well worth the sticker price of US $9.99 . Two Worlds Epic Edition plays allot like the Elder scrolls or the Torchlight games. In play style, Two worlds feels like a simplified mix of the two styles. The voice acting is quite good as is the writing and quests. Gold is plentiful, Alchemy is fairly easy, and "crafting" is fairly easy. Inventory management is fairly easy suffering only from a few glitches common to most games - there never enough room and this detracts from gameplay. TW1 however makes it easy to teleport around to shops and sell your goods and get back to game play. Two worlds 1 has its own small mod community over at www.insidetwoworlds.com/forumdisplay.php?f=3 IF you want to download one of the mods, I suggest using the Two world control panel - http://www.insidetwoworlds.com/showthread.php?t=26659 . TW also has a mod sdk and nice tools. TW1 really has not seen much mod authoring since about 2007-2008 and the forum while not deserted, lacks the excitement you find in Torchlight or the Elder scrolls games. Using mods is optional in TW1 - its really a nice game on its own.TW1 has a multiplayer mode I did not try.So if you like adventure games, pick it up, as part of the US$5 bundle and don’t feel badly if you pay full price since TW1 is well worth the US$9.99 sticker price!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
												(NOTE) This review is dependant on having friends for multiplayer- it might not change your past experiences but give you an insight into how to get good new ones. This game is... Bad.So bad that the single player is entirely not worth it and beyond saving- there's no point to playing it, and as many has said before the voice acting is awful and characters not at all memorable.But that has somehow not made this game a terrible purchase for me. You see, I bought three copies of it while on sale for ♥♥♥♥♥ and giggles once I saw the multiplayer tag, expecting a few hours of cheap laughter and something to bash on.I got exactly that and more. The combat is -just barely- engaging enough to drag you in, but broken enough to be completely conquered by several players together, at low levels. I've related all the dragging and running from monsters and the fact that melee combat is awful at lower levels to being rather realistic. It's like some strange dark comedy where you run from hordes of wolves, bears, undead, grom, and ghost bears to take to the towns people who of course mob upon it and destroy it in seconds. But while doing this, you'll of course start to grow and gain more and more experience, levelling up in a sort of Dark Souls manner. In fact, the combat of the game sort of reminds me of the souls games, like a simplified version without repostes or other mechanics- but a dodge and parry button can be used, and it can be used well enough that there's a skill cap to melee combat. And you can mold your character however you want past the beginning much like in Dark Souls as well- you want to be an ice mage wearing huge armor? Sure. Sneaky necromancer who stabs people with a spear? Absolutely. It might not hold your hand and it certainly won't be fair at times but that can be forgiven with the strangely mesmeric depth of character possibilities and gameplay on several open world maps, even if you can't change their appearance to begin with past a few sliders that make no sense. For the sake of difficulty, I'd recommend starting as a magic class and then change into whatever you like later on- equipment has no restrictions except for stats and many spells just need a few points into their respective fields of magic. And somehow the game keeps things refreshing even if you lose all progress on a map when you exit the multiplayer session (you can, of course, unlock many maps through progression of the multiplayer and pick up on those irregardless) by having the enemy spawns and loot be interchangeable. One time a encampment of orcs happened to have a sand dragon instead of its usual, far over levelled and idiotic to fight. But we killed it and took its mediocre loot with a sense of accomplishment. Dying means nothing in this game as spawn points are everywhere and they heal you- but it still has managed to be fun? The setting is easily laughable and the characters forgettable but this is a game I can find myself recommending to play with multiplayer and a few friends. It's just enough of a clone to many well known games that you can find yourself having fun while breaking and bending it to your whim. As an example, animals are afraid of many fields of fire magic and you can also easily stun lock enemies with the water magic's AOE capabilities forever, even if when they take damage they unfreeze. Me and my friend has somehow made this challenging in unexpected ways and still had fun seeking adversity. Don't take yourself seriously while playing this game- imagine it like some poorly made table top game that your little sibling/relative made to impress you but somehow manages to entertain you at the same time despite its broken aspects. All in all, the singleplayer is worthless but the multiplayer is a surprising gem with qualities of Dark Souls, Diablo stye looting, and Oblivion small open world maps with quests to deal with. I can't recommend the full price but you absolutely should pick it up on sale for five bucks a copy- it's like a cheesy movie you'll find yourself enamored with.Also, it charmingly included alchemy into a multiplayer game and that seems rather cool to me. TLDR: Buy it on sale for five bucks or less to play with your friends who all have hamachi. You'll get some time of entertainment.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
												(I know I haven't got a lot of time at all on this game but I played it for a god awful amount of time on Xbox)"Oblivion on Steroids" - More like Oblivion after being on Meth for a long time, after all its teeth have fallen out. To me this game is so bad that it's great; the terrible dialog, the silly combat animations, the horribly hard to follow plot, they all make this so much fun. And even with all those bad points the game isn't actually too bad when you look at it little by little, it has a large variety of weapons and armour, some of which even look kind of cool. The environment of the game its self is actually a bit pretty on max settings and the map is quite large with a lot of places to explore, there are a lot of side quest separate from the main plot, and the magic system is interesting (Although it's way better on Two Worlds 2)If you're a serious player then this game probably isn't for you, if you like to play for the entertainment value of a game then I wholeheartedly recommend this. I also recommend trying out the sequel, which is of much higher quality than this and it closer to a genuine serious game than this is.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												...no doubt worthy of being called "a modern-retro classic," if such a term may be applied to something other than 2D pixels...Regarding multiplayer: Only one server based in Europe is active. Textures are prone to spazzing, Creatures will float if near an edge (i.e. cave walls/stairs up a tower), The horrible connection (am using Hamachi, have done all I know to do) reduces melee combat to "I can't even 'Jump Back' (dodge) since it never registers proper (get hit before or right after having done so - as in, enemies warp to you because of the lag, so it's futile to try), just rush, respawn, keep rushing." TO BE SURE, it seems the longer you stay in-game, the stronger the connection becomes. Not sure of how much sense that makes but both my friend and I have noticed it; patience is necessary.Despite all that, I feel this game does not deserve the terrible reviews it has garnered; perhaps I'm a dope for being satisfied with it, perhaps others expected too much of it. This game is reminiscent of the Souls games + Oblivion; the gear and progression is apparently like in the Souls games (so says my buddy, I've not played them much) - the environments are straight out of Tamriel. There is a bare minimum of hand-holding; every time I play the game, I learn something new. If the combat/connection was tweaked a little tighter, I would no doubt be playing the game constant. There is a sequel though, and it is seriously mind-blowing how much better it is (though some of the tweaks are for the worse).You can combine gear of the same type to strengthen it; you can learn any skill you want to - can respec your character - though it might just be better to pay the 500 gold (not so steep after a few levels) to make a new one. ALSO, BE SURE, after your first character, TO GO BUY EVERY SKILL YOU WANT WHEN YOUR NEW CHARACTER IS LEVEL 0 - each skill costs 100 gold from the beginning, but after a few levels, it goes from 1,000 to 10,000... so yeah.For what it is, and the discounted price of $1 - if you have great patience and the ability to find fun in a game's faults (none quite so game-breaking, have crashed only once, because of Steam, not the game), Two Worlds is worth consideration.Should you get it, addressing your choice of Class:Recall what I said about melee, if you want to be a Knight/Barbarian - be patient and bear in mind it is an old game (if nothing else, go to single player, I had zero issues in the short time I tried it); You must spend ALL your points in Archery should you wish to be a Thief/Archer  (otherwise you will literally connect one out of a hundred arrows, if that many) - Dexterity is required to use some of the better shields; Wizards are, as always, badass - I don't think you need a robe or a staff to cast, so up your magic appropriately then get strength so you can use armor.Really, unless you are going as a wizard, Strength and Dexterity (of course Vitality every couple levels or so) deserve the most attention; though the Wizards are overpowered, it seems much of the gear is inclined to melee, or at least STRONG, characters.EDIT:

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												Two Worlds is not the horrible game I was led to believe it to be. It's also not a good game in any respect. The game has some decent ideas, but in the end it fails on every front.The graphics are a mixed bag; environments look decent considering the year the game was released (it looks very similar to the environments found in Oblivion, to the point where it almost looks plagiarized), the character models and effects however are disastrous, looking like upcaled 5th gen models running at 10 fps. The sound fails in all respects. I can't think of a single track from the game. The only thing I can recall just a day after beating the game is the annoying low health sound.The story premise starts interesting enough, but plays out extremely tediously and dull. The ending is the most uneventful I've ever seen in a game.If you're a die-hard RPG player that has run out of other games to play during a dry spell, give this a try. Otherwise, stay far away and play another game for your RPG fix.

Posted: January 12, 2015
												Great game ! Right up there with elder scrolls. I like Two Worlds  better than oblivion and equal with morrowind. The graphics are a bit dated but not that bad - like xbox 360 era graphics. Its a little slow getting started but you level fast so the talent tree will have you growing more powerful in no time. im level 29 at the moment and there are still areas in the game i will not survive. I think the main story is good and i enjoy the side quests/stories as well. lots of reviews are complaining about the voice acting....its not that bad at all. ive definitely heard worse !   I highly recommend this game i got in in a package deal " Two Worlds collection" im glad i played this first before jumping right into the more modern Two Worlds 2. its really a great adventure worth playing. if you like elder scrolls type games you wont want to miss this. The only thing that had me frustrated at first is the registration.  If you have a PC that has onboard graphics and hgh powered video card it will probably auto run the game to the onboard if its decent ( i have HD 4600 which is impressive for onboard ) anyway when i tried to force my high powered video card to run the game, the game thought i was trying to register the same game code on a different computer and wouldnt allow me to log in. so make sure you force the correct video card to run the game before you register,

content:
Posted: February 10, 2014
												Two Worlds Epic Edition (Two worlds 1) is a hidden gem. It is Well worth the sticker price of US $9.99 . Two Worlds Epic Edition plays allot like the Elder scrolls or the Torchlight games. In play style, Two worlds feels like a simplified mix of the two styles. The voice acting is quite good as is the writing and quests. Gold is plentiful, Alchemy is fairly easy, and "crafting" is fairly easy. Inventory management is fairly easy suffering only from a few glitches common to most games - there never enough room and this detracts from gameplay. TW1 however makes it easy to teleport around to shops and sell your goods and get back to game play. Two worlds 1 has its own small mod community over at www.insidetwoworlds.com/forumdisplay.php?f=3 IF you want to download one of the mods, I suggest using the Two world control panel - http://www.insidetwoworlds.com/showthread.php?t=26659 . TW also has a mod sdk and nice tools. TW1 really has not seen much mod authoring since about 2007-2008 and the forum while not deserted, lacks the excitement you find in Torchlight or the Elder scrolls games. Using mods is optional in TW1 - its really a nice game on its own.TW1 has a multiplayer mode I did not try.So if you like adventure games, pick it up, as part of the US$5 bundle and don’t feel badly if you pay full price since TW1 is well worth the US$9.99 sticker price!

content:
Posted: October 5, 2015
												I first came across this game in a website article about the worst RPG games of all time.  Being a conniseur of the truly awful and noble defender of that which is unjustly labeled so, I must say that this is indeed a good game.  It is not an Elder Scrolls game, nor does it try to be.  It is however a fun game.  the unique item upgrade system whereby stacking an item on top of an identical item makes a stronger item.  This made looting more fun and strategic, do you lose the weaker sword in favor of the better sword? or do you keep the weaker sword because you know it's more common and could be upgraded to be more powerful than the better sword?  Weapons have slashing, bashing, or pearsing damage.  And enemies have different resistances to each, and not mild resistances either, it's a case of 'look it's a skeleton, should I use (A) a sword and half a dozen health potions and kill it in about 15-30 hits, or, (B) a club no potions and kill it in 2-3 hits.If anything, the game reminds me of an open world titan quest with 3rd person view and WASD movement.Tons of side quests and one of the only games where being the brave hero type can screw over innocent people.This game is often on special and it only cost me $1 something.Buy it, relax and have fun.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												This game has lots of visible potential that I really like about it, but it does not come without flaws. The environments look really good, especially for the time this game was made, and the music is pretty good as well. The story is a joke though; it doesn't make much sense at all, and things just kind of happen.The gameplay is simple enough to get used to, and you'll probably find yourself invested in it at some point. There's a cool sense of progression because of your ability to constantly find good weapons and armor not just from the stores, but as enemy drops and treasure. The voice acting and animations in general are really bad, but this becomes VERY entertaining.Overall, it feels like a somewhat hackneyed cash-in on the things that the Elder Scrolls series was pulling that didn't quite work out for Reality Pump, especially due to the amount of hype it had generated prior to its release. But all of that is past, and we can now appreciate it for what it is, rather than what it should have been. And for what this game does well, I believe it deserves a second look. Don't know if I would pay the standard $10 for it, but if you can get it for a good price, you might be surprised.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 22, 2014
												Own it on disc and played it for ages but didn't mind paying the £1.50 sale price rather than look for it in the cupboard to give it another go. The animations might be a bit ropey but the visuals aren't too bad. The combat could have been done better and feels a bit dated, using the bow is pretty poor, but if you can look beyond it's faults there is a huge game for the tiny price. Always liked the way you can combine matching items to boost them up (mouse over them in the inventory and if they match they turn green, then just drag 'n' drop). I would suggest using the 'jump-back' key to avoid enemy attacks and survive combat for longer though, especially at the start, and carry a mix of slashing, piercing and bashing weapons with different elemental upgrades. Horses have their own inventory, just stand next to them and get the panel up, use these to solve your storage problems by gathering a few around a teleport site. Doing this and having different ones for different item types makes it easier to collect armour sets etc and to keep matching items to combine them.   Huge world, loads of locations to discover, tons of loot, vast number of quests, hacking down creatures while on horseback, if you want an epic rpg experience and give it the chance it deserves you'll soon find yourself ignoring it's failings and find a good game, get it at sale price and you can't go wrong.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												This game has lots of visible potential that I really like about it, but it does not come without flaws. The environments look really good, especially for the time this game was made, and the music is pretty good as well. The story is a joke though; it doesn't make much sense at all, and things just kind of happen.The gameplay is simple enough to get used to, and you'll probably find yourself invested in it at some point. There's a cool sense of progression because of your ability to constantly find good weapons and armor not just from the stores, but as enemy drops and treasure. The voice acting and animations in general are really bad, but this becomes VERY entertaining.Overall, it feels like a somewhat hackneyed cash-in on the things that the Elder Scrolls series was pulling that didn't quite work out for Reality Pump, especially due to the amount of hype it had generated prior to its release. But all of that is past, and we can now appreciate it for what it is, rather than what it should have been. And for what this game does well, I believe it deserves a second look. Don't know if I would pay the standard $10 for it, but if you can get it for a good price, you might be surprised.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												The games rather retro, the voice acting/script is horrid - not so much the voices as the script they are forced to follow. Ugh. But it distracts only a little. The controls are a bit odd, but thankfully you can customize some. There's a hotbar, but the F7 one is set, use one of the others to customize your own way. The storyline is playable, there's plenty of freedom to roam about. But make sure that you can deal with the wildlife... they tend to see you as something to kos if you are anywhere near them. Take the time to get the feel of fighting, it's not just a stand there and hit type of game. You need to move or you'll go down will little effort on the attacker's part. Upgrade your items as often as you can, grab what you can brew and make sure to be careful what you put together when your experimenting. There's all sorts of things you can make...All in all, it's not a bad game, rough sure... but not bad. There's no comparing it to today's games, since it was made some time ago. But I don't think it got the attention it should have when it came out. There are lots of forgotten gems like this one out there. The new one Two Worlds 2 picks up some time after this one ends... I started playing it, but I wanted to find out the backstory to it. That's why I'm playing this one. Hope that you'll give both of the games a chance. I'm glad I did... even though I'm not really one for retro games.
