												Great game ! Right up there with elder scrolls. I like Two Worlds  better than oblivion and equal with morrowind. The graphics are a bit dated but not that bad - like xbox 360 era graphics. Its a little slow getting started but you level fast so the talent tree will have you growing more powerful in no time. im level 29 at the moment and there are still areas in the game i will not survive. I think the main story is good and i enjoy the side quests/stories as well. lots of reviews are complaining about the voice acting....its not that bad at all. ive definitely heard worse !   I highly recommend this game i got in in a package deal " Two Worlds collection" im glad i played this first before jumping right into the more modern Two Worlds 2. its really a great adventure worth playing. if you like elder scrolls type games you wont want to miss this. The only thing that had me frustrated at first is the registration.  If you have a PC that has onboard graphics and hgh powered video card it will probably auto run the game to the onboard if its decent ( i have HD 4600 which is impressive for onboard ) anyway when i tried to force my high powered video card to run the game, the game thought i was trying to register the same game code on a different computer and wouldnt allow me to log in. so make sure you force the correct video card to run the game before you register,

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 6, 2015
												Non-serious review:You can just ressurect whoever you want when your air magic skill is full and you own the resurrection spell.Even your resurrected enemies go friendly and help you in combat.I murdered an entire village for necromancers... I resurrected all of them. They don't care that I killed them, or even acknowledged that I resurrected them...Went back to the necromancers and killed all of the necromancers except for one, who for some reason chose not to fight me. Even though he witnessed me murder all of his brethren, he still welcomed me... Killed him... Resurrected them all... Pretty much all of them are scared s**tless of me now...10/10Would resurrect everything (and betray people) again.Serious review:To start of, this game is amazing. But, unfortunately, the cons mask the actual game. However, if you can get past those cons and ignore it, the game is actually one of the best RPGs I have played in a long time, and if the series was to come back with much better features and a more developed lore (the lore is pretty good though), it could actually rival the Elder Scrolls series. No joke.Note: The game starts of rather slowly and you're quite weak, but if you put the time and effort in you can become a tank. The best part is that even as a tank, you'll still find certain parts of the game difficult.Plot and basic story neccessary gameplay:The plot's quite simple. It's a lets save a damsel in distress kind of story, except the damsel is actually your kidnapped sister and you go on some crappy wild goose chase to find her. Despite it being crappy and starts with some rather unneccessary bits, it's still actually quite good. One thing I like about this game is the fact that you can't just go and hammer the main quest straight through right away. You will be forced to do side quests and kill some more basic enemies to become strong enough to fight the enemies you will encounter on your adventures (Tip: Save when fighting hard enemies (At the start and mid-fight when you've taken a substantial amount of the enemy's/enemies' health down) and use the jump back ability to avoid the enemies swings. Powerful enemies can kill you with just one damn hit). Anyway, so your sister's been kidnapped by some weird mysterious cult like group and you try to track her down. You then get sent on quests by this cult to obtain items they want in return for your sister. Your character also comes off as quite an ignorant fool to the cult as he does not believe in the legend of his ancestors and his family legacy. The two endings are quite anti-climatic, but still fairly interesting. Oh, by the way, there is 100% no problem with this unless your somebody who gives a damn about being able to change your characters gender, but you have to be a man unless playing multi-player. There's no problem with that for me as I don't care about my character's gender in a game.Gameplay:The game features a fairly basic combat system but I still found it fun. I can't really go into much detail, but sometimes, fights do seem quite action packed. There is also a basic but interesting skill system, a developed alchemy system, and a simple but helpful weapon and armour upgrade system. The roleplaying system is quite basic but fun as well. There is also a faction relations system which is too easy to earn trust with but is a nice touch nonetheless. The multiplayer mode is basically just parts of the map from the single-player game (there are several to choose from) but with different quests and characters and it's playable with friends. It's essentially a free MMO thrown in with the single-player game. Or you can choose an arena mode which is much different and much like any other arena deathmatch game. Magic is also featured as a key point of the game. Quite a few bugs are bundled in with this game to give you the "man-we-must-have-rushed-this-on-a-cheap-budget-but-hey-it's-still-quite-good" feeling. And as mentioned above in the non-serious review... You can resurrect everyone... Like literally everyone... That's god damn fun!Graphics:Well, it's very mixed. The graphics are certainly dated but do sometimes look fairly attractive. Rarely, but they can. The render distance is horrible though. Just ewww, devs. I feel incredibly short-sighted and by that I mean the short-sighted kind that can only see objects randomly appear when close enough. Y'know, the kind which doesn't exist. *shivers* Er... Just thinking about it gives me the chills!Music:Actually really suprisingly interesting and engaging. It usually fits the atmosphere but can sometimes take a while to fit in (for example, I may have peaceful music on when fighting an enemy as I had just been adventuring peacefully for a while). The main theme (the name escapes me, unfortunately) really matches the game and it's plot. It actually feels like the depth of the song goes quite deep. Look it up on YouTube. It's really good. The finale music at the end of the game is really quite thrilling and action packed.Voice Acting and voice related content:So this is the main criticism for the game, in most peoples opinions. But actually, not mine. I actually really enjoyed the almost always cheesy voice acting. It actually sometimes felt quite good! xD The player's voice is actually really bad♥♥♥♥♥in my opinion! Unfortunately, it is cheesy and can ruin the atmosphere, so that's a quite a con right there. I enjoy the way in which the developers thought of using old english such as "'Tis", "Mayhap" and "Pray". It really fits the medievel stlye of the game.Game world and lore:One of the most amazing things about this game is the sheer size of the world. It's massive and really engaging. The lore is also incredibly engaging, in fact, there's so much I can't share it all with you. So I'll put in a few words of what it features:GodsAncientsMedieval themesRoman-like themesFantasy themesLot's of different kinds of enemiesFaction relationshipsCivil war-like scenario (Skelden House vs The Karga Clan)Orc vs Humans scenarioNecromancersMages guild (The Society)And much much more.Pros: Engaging world and lore.Nice gameplay mechanics.Massive world.Amazing music.Can resurrect eveything if you feel bad about killing things(!)!Mixed:Voice Acting. The cheesy and bad voice acting gives the game some humour and does actually sometimes sound quite good, at least to me. The world's not supposed to be mega-humouress and it wasn't intentional, so it doesn't quite fit with the game, but it's still not awful. It could definitely be better though.Basic principles of graphics. Not too awful for the time this was released. (Well actually, they even updated the graphics at a later date to improve them as release graphics were awful).Cons:Render distance. Seriously... That is bull s**t on modern hardware - in fact, even for the time of release it was awful...Starts a little too slow with player character development.Too easy to earn trust with factions.Bugs... number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 21, 2015
												I didn't understand what people were trying to say in their reviews when they said that this game was flawed, but enjoyable. i get the concept of 'so bad they're good' movies, but thought the concept didn't apply to video games. This game changed my mind. I don't have any long-lasting great nostalgic love for this game, but I do like it, not joking. There are so many things wrong with this game, my first impression was awful - mostly due to the overly-invasive registration garbage, stiff combat, a glitchy map system and an undescriptive quest log. But the cheesy cornball acting and questing for loot kept me going. Don't get me wrong, this isn't a hidden masterpiece. This isn't a fulfilling RPG experience on-par with the Elder Scrolls - despite numerous quotes to the contrary - but if you don't take it too seriously you might have some fun riding through forests cutting down orcs for their pocket change.I do think this game is more worthy of play than it's successor, as TWII lost the charm of the original and somehow made the controls, map and quest log even worse.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
												Great game ! Right up there with elder scrolls. I like Two Worlds  better than oblivion and equal with morrowind. The graphics are a bit dated but not that bad - like xbox 360 era graphics. Its a little slow getting started but you level fast so the talent tree will have you growing more powerful in no time. im level 29 at the moment and there are still areas in the game i will not survive. I think the main story is good and i enjoy the side quests/stories as well. lots of reviews are complaining about the voice acting....its not that bad at all. ive definitely heard worse !   I highly recommend this game i got in in a package deal " Two Worlds collection" im glad i played this first before jumping right into the more modern Two Worlds 2. its really a great adventure worth playing. if you like elder scrolls type games you wont want to miss this. The only thing that had me frustrated at first is the registration.  If you have a PC that has onboard graphics and hgh powered video card it will probably auto run the game to the onboard if its decent ( i have HD 4600 which is impressive for onboard ) anyway when i tried to force my high powered video card to run the game, the game thought i was trying to register the same game code on a different computer and wouldnt allow me to log in. so make sure you force the correct video card to run the game before you register,

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 6, 2015
												Non-serious review:You can just ressurect whoever you want when your air magic skill is full and you own the resurrection spell.Even your resurrected enemies go friendly and help you in combat.I murdered an entire village for necromancers... I resurrected all of them. They don't care that I killed them, or even acknowledged that I resurrected them...Went back to the necromancers and killed all of the necromancers except for one, who for some reason chose not to fight me. Even though he witnessed me murder all of his brethren, he still welcomed me... Killed him... Resurrected them all... Pretty much all of them are scared s**tless of me now...10/10Would resurrect everything (and betray people) again.Serious review:To start of, this game is amazing. But, unfortunately, the cons mask the actual game. However, if you can get past those cons and ignore it, the game is actually one of the best RPGs I have played in a long time, and if the series was to come back with much better features and a more developed lore (the lore is pretty good though), it could actually rival the Elder Scrolls series. No joke.Note: The game starts of rather slowly and you're quite weak, but if you put the time and effort in you can become a tank. The best part is that even as a tank, you'll still find certain parts of the game difficult.Plot and basic story neccessary gameplay:The plot's quite simple. It's a lets save a damsel in distress kind of story, except the damsel is actually your kidnapped sister and you go on some crappy wild goose chase to find her. Despite it being crappy and starts with some rather unneccessary bits, it's still actually quite good. One thing I like about this game is the fact that you can't just go and hammer the main quest straight through right away. You will be forced to do side quests and kill some more basic enemies to become strong enough to fight the enemies you will encounter on your adventures (Tip: Save when fighting hard enemies (At the start and mid-fight when you've taken a substantial amount of the enemy's/enemies' health down) and use the jump back ability to avoid the enemies swings. Powerful enemies can kill you with just one damn hit). Anyway, so your sister's been kidnapped by some weird mysterious cult like group and you try to track her down. You then get sent on quests by this cult to obtain items they want in return for your sister. Your character also comes off as quite an ignorant fool to the cult as he does not believe in the legend of his ancestors and his family legacy. The two endings are quite anti-climatic, but still fairly interesting. Oh, by the way, there is 100% no problem with this unless your somebody who gives a damn about being able to change your characters gender, but you have to be a man unless playing multi-player. There's no problem with that for me as I don't care about my character's gender in a game.Gameplay:The game features a fairly basic combat system but I still found it fun. I can't really go into much detail, but sometimes, fights do seem quite action packed. There is also a basic but interesting skill system, a developed alchemy system, and a simple but helpful weapon and armour upgrade system. The roleplaying system is quite basic but fun as well. There is also a faction relations system which is too easy to earn trust with but is a nice touch nonetheless. The multiplayer mode is basically just parts of the map from the single-player game (there are several to choose from) but with different quests and characters and it's playable with friends. It's essentially a free MMO thrown in with the single-player game. Or you can choose an arena mode which is much different and much like any other arena deathmatch game. Magic is also featured as a key point of the game. Quite a few bugs are bundled in with this game to give you the "man-we-must-have-rushed-this-on-a-cheap-budget-but-hey-it's-still-quite-good" feeling. And as mentioned above in the non-serious review... You can resurrect everyone... Like literally everyone... That's god damn fun!Graphics:Well, it's very mixed. The graphics are certainly dated but do sometimes look fairly attractive. Rarely, but they can. The render distance is horrible though. Just ewww, devs. I feel incredibly short-sighted and by that I mean the short-sighted kind that can only see objects randomly appear when close enough. Y'know, the kind which doesn't exist. *shivers* Er... Just thinking about it gives me the chills!Music:Actually really suprisingly interesting and engaging. It usually fits the atmosphere but can sometimes take a while to fit in (for example, I may have peaceful music on when fighting an enemy as I had just been adventuring peacefully for a while). The main theme (the name escapes me, unfortunately) really matches the game and it's plot. It actually feels like the depth of the song goes quite deep. Look it up on YouTube. It's really good. The finale music at the end of the game is really quite thrilling and action packed.Voice Acting and voice related content:So this is the main criticism for the game, in most peoples opinions. But actually, not mine. I actually really enjoyed the almost always cheesy voice acting. It actually sometimes felt quite good! xD The player's voice is actually really bad♥♥♥♥♥in my opinion! Unfortunately, it is cheesy and can ruin the atmosphere, so that's a quite a con right there. I enjoy the way in which the developers thought of using old english such as "'Tis", "Mayhap" and "Pray". It really fits the medievel stlye of the game.Game world and lore:One of the most amazing things about this game is the sheer size of the world. It's massive and really engaging. The lore is also incredibly engaging, in fact, there's so much I can't share it all with you. So I'll put in a few words of what it features:GodsAncientsMedieval themesRoman-like themesFantasy themesLot's of different kinds of enemiesFaction relationshipsCivil war-like scenario (Skelden House vs The Karga Clan)Orc vs Humans scenarioNecromancersMages guild (The Society)And much much more.Pros: Engaging world and lore.Nice gameplay mechanics.Massive world.Amazing music.Can resurrect eveything if you feel bad about killing things(!)!Mixed:Voice Acting. The cheesy and bad voice acting gives the game some humour and does actually sometimes sound quite good, at least to me. The world's not supposed to be mega-humouress and it wasn't intentional, so it doesn't quite fit with the game, but it's still not awful. It could definitely be better though.Basic principles of graphics. Not too awful for the time this was released. (Well actually, they even updated the graphics at a later date to improve them as release graphics were awful).Cons:Render distance. Seriously... That is bull s**t on modern hardware - in fact, even for the time of release it was awful...Starts a little too slow with player character development.Too easy to earn trust with factions.Bugs... That s**t was completely unneccesary... You may not encounter them too often, but when you do... They're horrible.The game crashed on me once... I had to restart my entire PC. :(Overall judgementFor time of release (with original graphics (I've only seen these in images though)): 6For time of release (with improved graphics): 8Now: 7.5Give it a go when it goes dirt cheap on sale. I mean, I got it for £0.69 or something. One of the best purchases I have ever made. I did once play this game on the XBox 360 though.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
												Despite the universal negative criticisms, Two Worlds Epic Edition is actually a decent Action RPG. Fans of the Gothic series may find themselves at home in this expansive world.If you think a game relies heavily on appearances (graphics, animations, etc), then this will not be a game for you, as the game clearly shows its age, even with the graphics maxed out. But if you can enjoy a game simply based on the game itself, give it a try.There's a large variety of skills, weapons, and armor to really fit your playstyle. While there is no traditional blocking, you can dodge attacks by moving or hopping out of the way, making combat really focused on watching your enemy and taking advantages of their openings. And it can be VERY challenging.In fact, most enemies will likely overwhelm you by either brute strength or numbers. The key is to not get hit. Essentially, by dodging and maneuvering around attacks, a level one character could take down ANYTHING with enough time and skill. The longer fights can get very intense, especially in one-on-one combat.Suffice it to say, Two Worlds Epic Edition is not a bad game at all. That doesn't mean YOU have to like it, but I encourage you to give it a try. If even $10 seems like too much for you to spend to try out a game, I suggest waiting for a sale.Just like with Two Worlds II, I would suggest sticking to the multiplayer if the singleplayer story doesn't interest you that much. The multiplayer allows you to create your own character with a good variety of options (including races and gender) and gives you large maps in which to go and quest! Guaranteed hours of fun, even if you play it alone. (Yes, you can enter maps by yourself in multiplayer. Playing with other people is not required, but encouraged!)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 27, 2015
												Graphics:From a mere visual standpoint, this teeters on the better end of "average". It has common problems of its genre and time, such as touchy ragdoll physics, lackluster animations (outside of combat), foliage that appears and disappears with movement, props that frequently expose unfinished portions of themselves, and way too much bloom. Enemies also sometimes appear from thin air when I enter an area too quickly. Compounding this is an odd sort of strobe effect on movement animations, that would not look out of place in Quake, that can directly influence gameplay (especially horses, but I'll get to that later). On the flip side? The world is deceptively large, and allows for long-distance observation, by not resorting to permanent hazy filters or ridiculously short draw distance, as well as exploration, to every nook and cranny between the large mountains that make up the edges of the map. This will take the player to plenty of locales, such as mountain forests, jungles, and deserts, each of which feels atmospherically unique. Combining this with intense visual effects and minute texture detail, this is a game that can and will look stunning when it really wants to.Sound:Aside from the simple sound effects, this game's audio is original Deus Ex tier, in both good and bad ways. Bad, in that the voice acting is pretty forced, but still tries hard to have its special charm, while delivering dialogue of a similar caliber. Good, as in the music is a combination of regular RPG ambience and stuff that's good enough to listen to outside of the game. Of course, you won't hear it unless you go to the settings menu and crank it all the way up. It seems as though somebody thought it was so embarrassing that it deserved to be hidden by generic enemy grunts and the main character's quipping, which is a shame because the music's variation, subtle undertones, strong meters, and bizarre instrumentation make it an absolute treat to listen to even when not playing.Customization:Impressively deep, the game allows the player to toy with every aspect of his character, from looks to equipment. Armor not only includes variations by type, but variations within specific types, as well as an ability to combine identically-named equipment to produce stronger variations, and this is all on top of bonus statistics and resistances. Alchemy allows the player to brew potions and weapon upgrades from scratch. The magic system lets the player use spells that can be strengthened by adding more of the same type, using boosters, or using bonuses from other spells or pieces of equipment. This all congeals to create a character that uniquely fits the player's gameplay preferences, an experience I haven't had with this depth in a video game since Morrowind. Unfortunately, my feelings don't entirely extend to the skills list. While it is impressive to have so many skills, many of them are important parts for certain gameplay styles (the ability to silently kill enemies, for example), and some of these are locked at the beginning, requiring the player to conform to a different style until he comes across the NPC who will unlock said skill. The hotbars can also be a pain to set up.Combat:I found the combat to work fine in one-on-one situations, but the game rarely gives those out, instead focusing on battles against hordes of enemies which are often slowly beaten using a "one step forward, two steps backward" sort of approach that limits the depth that is readily available. Melee attacks are similar to those of the game "Enclave", putting animation in front of effectiveness, but here the problem is ameliorated slightly due to generally being directed at enemies even without specific directional commands, and still allowing movement during said attacks. This works to hamper the combat as well, though, as I sometimes find myself accidentally ttacking allies, or using the backstep when surrounded by enemies, which will launch me right back into them. Every other approach to combat seems to supplement the melee, as it can be challenging to get the range necessary to use bow exclusively, and magic is somewhat weak for the majority of the game. Towards the end of the game, where the difficulty takes a sharp increase, the clear lack of enemy scaling sets in, and many battles will become too easy, or too hard.Horses:Gave it its own section because of how weird they are in this game. Mounted combat works well because of the extra range given to weapons while on horseback. However, the horses themselves can be hard to control. They have a tendency to steer themselves, regardless of which direction I want to go. At first I thought it was just an elevation issue, but it's also happened over small props and pathways. The "strobe effect" I mentioned earlier takes away some control when the horse is moving at slow speeds. Though the horse is often faster, I find myself walking on foot most of the time, because I know I can go over terrain that the horse will not.Quests:I don't mind a little investigation, but when confronted with a locked, unpickable door, I would at least like to be pointed in the right direction to open it. While the main story offers a great deal of freedom, going so far as to tackle the objectives in any order I wish, the sidequests often required to complete these objectives (and even those that aren't required) can be hard to figure out. For most of the experience, I am left with far more questions than solutions.If I'm locked out of a faction stronghold because my reputation with them isn't high enough, can I at least be told where to find someone outside the stronghold who can increase my reputation? If I'm told to go into a cave as part of a quest, can I please open the door to get into said cave? If not, can I please be directed to someone who will give me the key? Is there a reason the NPC vital to this quest has not spawned yet?This is how the open, choice-driven quest system shoots itself in the leg. A distinct lack of explanation can make it tough to complete some of the objectives without an outside source.Factions: The faction system can barely be called as such. In short, it only provides small benefits that may not actually be reflective of the player's actions in the world.For example, during the Karga-Skelden section, I sided with Skelden, and had to improve my rep with them. One such required quest told me to intercept someone who was stealing documents. I was not given a location, a name, or anything else. I decided to check a guide, which told me that the NPC would only spawn if I started a certain quest for Karga. So, I go to their stronghold, and the guy at the gate tells me to get lost. Clearly, he would not let me in unless I killed him, or had increased my reputation with Karga. Out of utter indifference, I kill him, enter the Karga camp, and start the quest to spawn the NPC I need. I obtain the documents, kill the guy who had them, and keep going with Skelden's quests. Eventually, this led to Skelden wiping out the Karga stronghold completely, allowing me to walk into the deepest part of their base and take the item I needed. It was at this point that I checked my faction relations chart, and noticed that my reputation with Karga was 2/10. As far as I know, every faction relation starts at 0 and cannot go any lower.Really? 2/10? I directly caused the events that led to the elimination of Karga, and they still think I'm a 2/10 human being? Like, what did I do to deserve those points? The one quest they gave me, I betrayed them.For its flounderings in the major categories of combat, quests, and factions, I can understand why some people don't like it. Personally, I think that the depth, customization, and scale shines through, and even though there were some moments that infuriated me, there were more than a few moments at which I sat back and felt satisfied with what it did right. Good game.Also, taint.

												Although at first glance this game seems quite lame, it holds hours of fun. At the start of the game things go a tad slow, you're just another average joe, and the tutorial is sub par. However, once you gain a few levels, and discover the inner workings of the game it becomes one of the best RPG experiences I've encountered.Suggestions for your Enjoyment-Magic is very weak early game. Build up your sword arm-Alchemy is very useful, some ingrediants provide permenant bonuses (if it's a gem or mineral pair it with healing so you           don't get a magic dmg stone for your weapon -Equipment that is the same can be combined into each other to make one better one ( two longswords? Now you have 1 better long sword)

content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
												(I know I haven't got a lot of time at all on this game but I played it for a god awful amount of time on Xbox)"Oblivion on Steroids" - More like Oblivion after being on Meth for a long time, after all its teeth have fallen out. To me this game is so bad that it's great; the terrible dialog, the silly combat animations, the horribly hard to follow plot, they all make this so much fun. And even with all those bad points the game isn't actually too bad when you look at it little by little, it has a large variety of weapons and armour, some of which even look kind of cool. The environment of the game its self is actually a bit pretty on max settings and the map is quite large with a lot of places to explore, there are a lot of side quest separate from the main plot, and the magic system is interesting (Although it's way better on Two Worlds 2)If you're a serious player then this game probably isn't for you, if you like to play for the entertainment value of a game then I wholeheartedly recommend this. I also recommend trying out the sequel, which is of much higher quality than this and it closer to a genuine serious game than this is.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												Two Worlds is not the horrible game I was led to believe it to be. It's also not a good game in any respect. The game has some decent ideas, but in the end it fails on every front.The graphics are a mixed bag; environments look decent considering the year the game was released (it looks very similar to the environments found in Oblivion, to the point where it almost looks plagiarized), the character models and effects however are disastrous, looking like upcaled 5th gen models running at 10 fps. The sound fails in all respects. I can't think of a single track from the game. The only thing I can recall just a day after beating the game is the annoying low health sound.The story premise starts interesting enough, but plays out extremely tediously and dull. The ending is the most uneventful I've ever seen in a game.If you're a die-hard RPG player that has run out of other games to play during a dry spell, give this a try. Otherwise, stay far away and play another game for your RPG fix.

												Where to start? The controls for PC are poorly optimized (having played this on both 360 and PC). The combat system is more screwy than anyone should have to wrap their head around. The plot is atrocious, and the content of the game is repetative and generally junk. All this could even possibly be forgiven..... If... just if the creatures in the game ACTUALLY RESPAWNED. Yes. You heard it right. Nothing in this game respawns. Once an area is cleared of monsters, they are gone forever. Not that it really matters, because this is one of the ONLY open-world games where when you complete the main quest, the game simply ends. And not even in a satisfying manner. Seriously, avoid at all costs. The ONLY good thing to come from this game is the ridiculously good menu theme music. Which is the only reason I give this game a 2/10.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 1, 2016
												After reading most of the reviews i decided to give this a try and found out that it wasn't so bad as mentioned.  If you are a person who is picky about the gameplay, AI intelligence, etc... then i would admit that this would probably make you want to play another game rather than spend time playing it.  However, If you are just looking for a game to explore an open world type of RPG and can create your own adventures without playing a linear story, then i would definitely recommend this as i had a fun time myself just doing what i wanted. I must admit though, that the horse can be stubborn when going down certain hills or at certain edges of terrain sometimes and the game has crashed once or twice whilst i was in the middle of saving but it was one hell of an adventure.  At the end of it all, for me, i found out that i could summon two times the amount of any and every creature i wanted (at least 6 types of creatures at one time though there is a max limit) whilst i was against the last boss but i think you can do the same anywhere anytime as long as you unlocked that specific water magic spell.  Overall, this was worth it for me because i did what i wanted and not had to stick to the story line to get the relic stones (I rode all the way down to the bottom of the map at the beginning and slaughtered a few bandits, dead knights, beasts and orcs along the way).  I would recommend it for open world adventurers (who would just like to have fun whilst fighting unknown dangers) and first timers who are new to open world RPG games just so they can have a taste of what it's like.  Also, there's no harm being the bad guy in a game and going against the rules with power in your control every now and then.  :)

content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
												This is a Review for the PC Game Two Worlds The Epic Fail Edition50 Cons :1.♥♥♥♥♥♥Poor Animations.2.♥♥♥♥♥♥Poor Voice Acting.3. Horrible Dialogue.4. Horrible game storyline.5. Idiotic side quest storylines and downright illogical continuations.6. Lame movespeed with no sprinting.7. Mediocre character. Never felt like playing his role. Hes a jackass for all I care.8. Couldnt select female character for some reason. I thought this was an RPG.9. The towns at the beginning of the game have no women or children, they just have grown old men with lots of hair on chest.10. Horse whistle sounds like bird chirping. It is what a sparrow sounds like, not a human being's whistle.11. Horses move like cars, when they are running towards your whistle they slide towards you.12. Turning around a horse is like turning around a car only difference being you are either on full speed or you STOP completely and move around then press forward.13. Stiff horse animations get you stuck everywhere.14. Horse combat is almost impossible to do right.15. Sneaking is an active skill and not a character movement thing.16. Combat is ridiculous.17. Hit detection does not exist.18. Protagonist's sister is the most unattractive female in all of Tamriel. (Because I bet nobody remembers what the world in Two world's is called)19. More teleporters than in Portal 2. Even personal teleporters that are reusable and craftable via certain npcs.20. Huge loads of points to spend on skills on level up.21. Everything can be combined with everything and everything can be upgraded to the level of inifinity.22. Combine 10 pearls with 10 Diamonds and you are invincible.23. Way too many Armor and weapons that force you to change every once in 15 minutes.24. Horrible Enemy AI.25. Scripted Archers run away from you when you reach then but try to shoot you as soon as they are 5 metres away from you.26. Archers take exactly 15 seconds to shoot one arrow.27. Skeletons are mindless for real in this game and do nothing other than make you play dubstep in the background.28. VERY Unbalanced ENEMY and NPCs.29.♥♥♥♥♥♥Poor system of planting an auto target on everyone.30. Similar clothing and same dialogues for 50% of the population makes me send a fireball to an auto targetted npc then realise he can kill me in 3-4 hits and I barely scratch him. So I die and resurrect like nothing ever happenned.31. The game experiences 1 season per day.32. Herbs are so common I can make my own RPG game by collecting them and planting them in it.33. There are more wolves and boars in this game than any herbivore animal. I wonder how they survive in that kind of a food chain system.34. The devs made 4 plant types, 3 trees, 2 grass models and exactly 2 shrubs and copy pasted it on the whole map a billion times.35. Setting HDR to max gives lighting that makes no sense.36. Stutters out of nowhere.37. Magic is very underpowered early game.38. The character plays the character of a self righteous bad♥♥♥♥♥wannabe that thinks he is above all.39. Nonsensical terrain looping. Copy paste all over the big♥♥♥♥♥map.40. No such thing as a mountain. Just hills and big rocks.41. Automated lockpicking system based on probability.42. Overused and few enemy types with zero behavior differences.43. People use axes to chop the floor and shovels and sickles to chop trees. For some reason...44. Horses wont teleport with you, cause they cant enter the teleporter along with you on their back because of model size collision.45. Arrows fly everywhere except for the TARGET with no indication of wind speed and direction.46. Character can pickup stuff midway while riding the horse but needs superhuman reflexes to achieve that.47. Lurable enemies with HP/MP regenerating shrines right next to every fight.48. NPCs cant be killed, guards cant be killed.49. Bears are very stubborn creatures that dont even budge when you hit them with a sword, that is till they are dead ofcourse. Because you know, bears feel no pain.50. BORING.Can easily name 50 more but ... I got better things to do.Pros : 1. GREAT GAME START MAIN MENU THEME SONG! Definitely gets you in for some RPG MOOD and then ... well thank you very much.

Stiff horse animations get you stuck everywhere.14. Horse combat is almost impossible to do right.15. Sneaking is an active skill and not a character movement thing.16. Combat is ridiculous.17. Hit detection does not exist.18. Protagonist's sister is the most unattractive female in all of Tamriel. (Because I bet nobody remembers what the world in Two world's is called)19. More teleporters than in Portal 2. Even personal teleporters that are reusable and craftable via certain npcs.20. Huge loads of points to spend on skills on level up.21. Everything can be combined with everything and everything can be upgraded to the level of inifinity.22. Combine 10 pearls with 10 Diamonds and you are invincible.23. Way too many Armor and weapons that force you to change every once in 15 minutes.24. Horrible Enemy AI.25. Scripted Archers run away from you when you reach then but try to shoot you as soon as they are 5 metres away from you.26. Archers take exactly 15 seconds to shoot one arrow.27. Skeletons are mindless for real in this game and do nothing other than make you play dubstep in the background.28. VERY Unbalanced ENEMY and NPCs.29.♥♥♥♥♥♥Poor system of planting an auto target on everyone.30. Similar clothing and same dialogues for 50% of the population makes me send a fireball to an auto targetted npc then realise he can kill me in 3-4 hits and I barely scratch him. So I die and resurrect like nothing ever happenned.31. The game experiences 1 season per day.32. Herbs are so common I can make my own RPG game by collecting them and planting them in it.33. There are more wolves and boars in this game than any herbivore animal. I wonder how they survive in that kind of a food chain system.34. The devs made 4 plant types, 3 trees, 2 grass models and exactly 2 shrubs and copy pasted it on the whole map a billion times.35. Setting HDR to max gives lighting that makes no sense.36. Stutters out of nowhere.37. Magic is very underpowered early game.38. The character plays the character of a self righteous bad♥♥♥♥♥wannabe that thinks he is above all.39. Nonsensical terrain looping. Copy paste all over the big♥♥♥♥♥map.40. No such thing as a mountain. Just hills and big rocks.41. Automated lockpicking system based on probability.42. Overused and few enemy types with zero behavior differences.43. People use axes to chop the floor and shovels and sickles to chop trees. For some reason...44. Horses wont teleport with you, cause they cant enter the teleporter along with you on their back because of model size collision.45. Arrows fly everywhere except for the TARGET with no indication of wind speed and direction.46. Character can pickup stuff midway while riding the horse but needs superhuman reflexes to achieve that.47. Lurable enemies with HP/MP regenerating shrines right next to every fight.48. NPCs cant be killed, guards cant be killed.49. Bears are very stubborn creatures that dont even budge when you hit them with a sword, that is till they are dead ofcourse. Because you know, bears feel no pain.50. BORING.Can easily name 50 more but ... I got better things to do.Pros : 1. GREAT GAME START MAIN MENU THEME SONG! Definitely gets you in for some RPG MOOD and then ... well thank you very much.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												It reminds me a LOT of Gothic 3 in all the good and bad things about it. It has a huge open world, no monster respawning, even the leveling system and the effects of some spells just remind me of Gothic 3. But it just made the same mistakes as the creators of the third Gothic, it just somehow lacks in storytelling and I just cannot get immersed into its world, maybe it is just something that happens with such a huge world. Personally that was also the case for me with Oblivion and Skyrim.<beginning_of_a_personal_nostalgic_note>I really miss the days of playing Gothic 1 and 2, because they had relatively small worlds and a band of NPC friends (funny I still remember even some of their names after over 8 years - like Diego, Fester, Milten, Gorn).And it is not just because of the voice acting, let's be honest the voice acting in gothic 1 and 2 wasn't perfect.</end_of_personal_nostalgic_note>Yeah and as for the weapons it reminds me a bit of Borderlands. There is a ton of weapon and armor models with more or less randomly generated stats + enchantments, so the final effect is, that there is practicaly an infinite number of their variations. That turns most of the progress into that weapon-stat game, where you will never have the best possible weapon or armor, there is always something stronger that can be generated by the all-powerful RNG.Verdict:I think the "mixed" summary that it has as of the day I wrote this review fits it well. So if you liked Gothic 3 get it, you will not be dissapointed it is almost the same in terms of gameplay. So overall I recommend it on a (-50% or -75%) sale.

And with (limited) oline activations. Cancelled with every tiny change in the system. After 3 or 5 times you had to PHONE the support and beg for another activation.The Steam version still has key and online activation. I dont know, to which extend the DRM crap is still in it..Because underneath this it's actually a very nice open world RPG. Good story, Very big open world with lots of stuff to do and find. A good skill system. A interesting crafting system. And it doesn't even look too horrible today, given his age. Some animations are a bit strange and the voice acting isn't too great. Having said that: it looks better then morrwowind.It was always in the shadow of the elder scroll and gothic games. And sure has it's rough edges but not too much. You got to choose at game start, no flying swapping.PPS: Via registry editing full 21:9 support in 3440x1440. Hello Skyrim.

												So bad it is strangely addictive...I first played this game on the xbox years ago, then on the pc. I have more hours than my record shows but have still not completed this game. I am  huge fan of Skyrim, Fallout, those types of RPG. This game is nowhere near as good graphically, mechanically, or story-wise. If you are looking for a polished, immersive RPG, then avoid this.However, if you have a wry sense of humour, and this is on sale, it's worth it just to experience how awful the voice acting and dialogue are. The story is a bit random - got to find your sister who is being held hostage by somebody or other, and kill goblins and bears en route. The fighting is pure button mashing. But the loot system lets you combine item after item, making your armour and weapons really strong, so you can pretty much one-hit things eventually.So, ignore the bugs, put your tongue firmly in your cheek, and revel in the "Ah! It's raining!"

content:
Posted: July 31, 2016
												I like the game, but do not purchase the collection if you want to purchase the strategy guide (at least until Steam fixes whatever problem there is with the collection).I think the game is great, and there are so many ways to play it.I do suggest refraining from doing too much with regard to things that will gain you experience levels till you get trained in every skill (the basic training for each skill will cost you gold). There are a few things you will need to do at the beginning, like the starting quest, and the quests to get the teleporters working. After that, don't kill anything you don't absolutely have to (just pick locked containers for loot to sell for gold, and steal horses from enemies for storage - at least that's my starting strategy). Finding the trainers may mean sneaking past a lot of enemies and looking in a lot of places, but it's worth it.I like the scenery, the combat isn't too challenging (for someone who'd rather be looting and exploring than fighting), but you can get killed if overwhelmed (not a big deal, since you get revived at the nearest health shrine).The quests can have you doing a lot of running here and there, and there are several factions you can side with (all at once), try to keep that decision for as late in the game as you can, so you can accept as many quests from both sides as possible.My only disappointment is, you cannot side with the Orcs.PK

content:
Posted: October 30, 2016
 Two Worlds: Epic Edition Review === Rating: 3.5 / 10 - Greatness forsaken, and forever left unfinished ===GRAPHICS: 8 / 10Honestly, for being a game from 2007, graphics are very good. Textures are mostly detailed, there is AA, FOV, good particle effects, well done enemies... models of people are kinda deformed sometimes, but the game more than makes up, on this side at least, with very well done armors, weapons and environments.SOUND: 6 / 10Well, the sound design is average, no shame and no glory. The main theme music deserves a mention because it's very good, then the in-game ambience and sounds are average. GAMEPLAY: 3 / 10The gameplay part of this title is really flawed by major problems. I will just say this here and then focus on detail later in the review.LONGEVITY: 9 / 10If you are a completitionist, to find everything the huge world has to offer will take you a very long time. There are a myriad of quests and secret dungeons to discover, no doubt about this. === The Good - Very large world to explore, there are really a lot of dungeons and places to discover, cities to visit and stuff to loot in said places.- Great variety of weapons, armors, crafting materials and accessories, there are around 250 different sets of armor and something around 150 different weapons, which is not bad at all.- Complex and rewarding alchemy system: combine the elements you find from nature or defeated enemies to create custom potions with effects based on what you put in them. Even combine potions with each other to create more powerful ones.- Decent number of spells and character skills- Good variety of enemies: undeads, wild animals, constructs, demons, golems, dragons, and more- Cities are quite crowded and you can enter almost all buildings, plus there are many vendors and skill trainers around=== The Bad - Horse travel is crippled by major problems, and is the only way to explore undiscovered areas quickly. Horses have bugged pathfinding, will get stuck randomly, are very clunky and will stay where you left them in the world. The problem with this last thing is that the Call Horse command does not work if you are farther than around 50 metres from your horse.- The world may be huge but is really empty. Most of the time exploring, it will just feel like travelling in a demo map with some trees, rocks and some props. The world does not feel alive and linked together as it should be, but instead feels like dungeons and cities put inside a vast nothingess with no interest apart the occasional wild animal or alchemy herb. Very limited interactivity and dynamicity of environment in the overall game world.- NPCs in the cities are always the same 5-6 models, it will happen to see the same NPC models over and over very quicly, even groups of them being just plain clones. All NPCs will answer the same 3-4 default questions and have nothing characterizing them apart from few main quest characters, all the rest is just a bunch of generic placeholders just there to trade or give quests. Immersion and RP experience is really downgraded because of this.- Externally, cities are all the same, big dark brown stone walls, doesn't matter if the city is Nanic, Human or whatever other race. Zero characterization of racial buildings in this aspect.- Enemy AI is rudimental and will just follow the player to attack him, ranged enemies will run away if a melee player gets too close. enemies lack any semblance of coordination or group support actions such as ie. mages healing fighters and similar. Huge mobs of enemies can be carried around indefinitely. Enemies will just attack the player on sight without any role-playing interacion or eventual faction alliegances, there are allies by default and enemies by default, no grey in the middle, and that's it.- Zero role-playing decisions player-side. Each dialogue is scripted and apart from general questions about some characters or the world, there is no reallly matter of choice in anything, just accept or decline an assignment, with no depth in choices or branching of events during any quest.- Combat system is clunky and just underwhelming: melee characters will just have to swing a weapon until low on HP, drink all the potions they want and just keep spamming attacks until everyone is dead. Ranged classes can just run away from the enemy, then stop, aim, fire, and then run away again before the enemy can target them. Potions can be spammed so challenge is zero because as long as you have money to buy potions you are good.- Economy is broken: you can pick up all the stuff an enemy has on him, then when you are full of stuff go to a city and sell everything for massive amounts of money even from early game. You also can go and travel to a high level area, go to a random merchant, and buy crystals / potions / rings / anything with no level restriction of 20 levels ahead of you and just use them right there. Merchants will also havfe unlimited money and buy everything, always.- There is a skill to get bonus damage against enemies riding horses. But in the game there is no enemy ridiing a horse. There just isn't. I put this just to get you an idea of how half-finished this game really is.=== The Ugly - Alchemy is completely game breaking: ingredients can be combined to make potions, but also different potions with the SAME effects can be stacked. Example, you make 5 potions, all of them give you a Bonus to Strenght attribute, right, but all of them have a different name and a slight difference in the bonus, example: they give +10,+11,+12,+13 and +14 Strenght. Well you can drink ALL of them together and get ALL of the bonuses TOGETHER, for a total, in the example, of +60 Strenght, this applies to any potion you can imagine. Basically, when the game gets hard, just drink all the potions you have created and become a demi-god for a short time, kill anything, and done.- Weapon upgrading is aswell completely game breaking: you can stack an unlimite damount of upgrade crystals (which grant a % of bonus damage based on the element they are) on a weapon, so if you have like 50 upgrade crystals, which can be found easily or created with alchemy, you can put all of them on a weapon, getting a +10% damage bonus 50 TIMES. So that weapon will become just ridiculous.- Healing shrines ruin combat: in the world there are many, TOO many healing shrines, which will give the player a very high health regen over time. They are on many roads and even inside dungeons. fact is, you can make enemis follow you and stay inside a healing shrine to fight, so you will have health regen and be near invincible, but enemies will not have the bonuss and so your fight will be really easy. Same thing goes for Mana shrines if you are a mage, same principle but with mana, so unlimited power.- Inexplicable random stuttering inside cities or in crowded combats, even on recent computer system, this is a result of bad optimization on the overall game engine both graphical and coding-wise.- Main quest and side missions are just anonymous, uninvolving, poorly written and underwhelming, sketched, half finished, poorly refined.=== Conclusions Some aspects of Two Worlds are well done, almost too much well done, like the incredible number of weapons and armor, or the variety of enemies, or the principle upon the alchemy system is based,. But, as i explained, a lot of other aspects have been butchered with poor realization, badly thought out balance and gamaplay implementation, or just left there half finished.This is a game with GREAT potential, which has been released unfinished like a lot of today's Early Access games, because in the end this is an early access game, an alpha, a demonstration of the potential this game COULD achieve if it was finished fully.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2016
												After reading most of the reviews i decided to give this a try and found out that it wasn't so bad as mentioned.  If you are a person who is picky about the gameplay, AI intelligence, etc... then i would admit that this would probably make you want to play another game rather than spend time playing it.  However, If you are just looking for a game to explore an open world type of RPG and can create your own adventures without playing a linear story, then i would definitely recommend this as i had a fun time myself just doing what i wanted. I must admit though, that the horse can be stubborn when going down certain hills or at certain edges of terrain sometimes and the game has crashed once or twice whilst i was in the middle of saving but it was one hell of an adventure.  At the end of it all, for me, i found out that i could summon two times the amount of any and every creature i wanted (at least 6 types of creatures at one time though there is a max limit) whilst i was against the last boss but i think you can do the same anywhere anytime as long as you unlocked that specific water magic spell.  Overall, this was worth it for me because i did what i wanted and not had to stick to the story line to get the relic stones (I rode all the way down to the bottom of the map at the beginning and slaughtered a few bandits, dead knights, beasts and orcs along the way).  I would recommend it for open world adventurers (who would just like to have fun whilst fighting unknown dangers) and first timers who are new to open world RPG games just so they can have a taste of what it's like.  Also, there's no harm being the bad guy in a game and going against the rules with power in your control every now and then.  :)

content:
Posted: October 30, 2016
 Two Worlds: Epic Edition Review === Rating: 3.5 / 10 - Greatness forsaken, and forever left unfinished ===GRAPHICS: 8 / 10Honestly, for being a game from 2007, graphics are very good. Textures are mostly detailed, there is AA, FOV, good particle effects, well done enemies... models of people are kinda deformed sometimes, but the game more than makes up, on this side at least, with very well done armors, weapons and environments.SOUND: 6 / 10Well, the sound design is average, no shame and no glory. The main theme music deserves a mention because it's very good, then the in-game ambience and sounds are average. GAMEPLAY: 3 / 10The gameplay part of this title is really flawed by major problems. I will just say this here and then focus on detail later in the review.LONGEVITY: 9 / 10If you are a completitionist, to find everything the huge world has to offer will take you a very long time. There are a myriad of quests and secret dungeons to discover, no doubt about this. === The Good - Very large world to explore, there are really a lot of dungeons and places to discover, cities to visit and stuff to loot in said places.- Great variety of weapons, armors, crafting materials and accessories, there are around 250 different sets of armor and something around 150 different weapons, which is not bad at all.- Complex and rewarding alchemy system: combine the elements you find from nature or defeated enemies to create custom potions with effects based on what you put in them. Even combine potions with each other to create more powerful ones.- Decent number of spells and character skills- Good variety of enemies: undeads, wild animals, constructs, demons, golems, dragons, and more- Cities are quite crowded and you can enter almost all buildings, plus there are many vendors and skill trainers around=== The Bad - Horse travel is crippled by major problems, and is the only way to explore undiscovered areas quickly. Horses have bugged pathfinding, will get stuck randomly, are very clunky and will stay where you left them in the world. The problem with this last thing is that the Call Horse command does not work if you are farther than around 50 metres from your horse.- The world may be huge but is really empty. Most of the time exploring, it will just feel like travelling in a demo map with some trees, rocks and some props. The world does not feel alive and linked together as it should be, but instead feels like dungeons and cities put inside a vast nothingess with no interest apart the occasional wild animal or alchemy herb. Very limited interactivity and dynamicity of environment in the overall game world.- NPCs in the cities are always the same 5-6 models, it will happen to see the same NPC models over and over very quicly, even groups of them being just plain clones. All NPCs will answer the same 3-4 default questions and have nothing characterizing them apart from few main quest characters, all the rest is just a bunch of generic placeholders just there to trade or give quests. Immersion and RP experience is really downgraded because of this.- Externally, cities are all the same, big dark brown stone walls, doesn't matter if the city is Nanic, Human or whatever other race. Zero characterization of racial buildings in this aspect.- Enemy AI is rudimental and will just follow the player to attack him, ranged enemies will run away if a melee player gets too close. enemies lack any semblance of coordination or group support actions such as ie. mages healing fighters and similar. Huge mobs of enemies can be carried around indefinitely. Enemies will just attack the player on sight without any role-playing interacion or eventual faction alliegances, there are allies by default and enemies by default, no grey in the middle, and that's it.- Zero role-playing decisions player-side. Each dialogue is scripted and apart from general questions about some characters or the world, there is no reallly matter of choice in anything, just accept or decline an assignment, with no depth in choices or branching of events during any quest.- Combat system is clunky and just underwhelming: melee characters will just have to swing a weapon until low on HP, drink all the potions they want and just keep spamming attacks until everyone is dead. Ranged classes can just run away from the enemy, then stop, aim, fire, and then run away again before the enemy can target them. Potions can be spammed so challenge is zero because as long as you have money to buy potions you are good.- Economy is broken: you can pick up all the stuff an enemy has on him, then when you are full of stuff go to a city and sell everything for massive amounts of money even from early game. You also can go and travel to a high level area, go to a random merchant, and buy crystals / potions / rings / anything with no level restriction of 20 levels ahead of you and just use them right there. Merchants will also havfe unlimited money and buy everything, always.- There is a skill to get bonus damage against enemies riding horses. But in the game there is no enemy ridiing a horse. There just isn't. I put this just to get you an idea of how half-finished this game really is.=== The Ugly - Alchemy is completely game breaking: ingredients can be combined to make potions, but also different potions with the SAME effects can be stacked. Example, you make 5 potions, all of them give you a Bonus to Strenght attribute, right, but all of them have a different name and a slight difference in the bonus, example: they give +10,+11,+12,+13 and +14 Strenght. Well you can drink ALL of them together and get ALL of the bonuses TOGETHER, for a total, in the example, of +60 Strenght, this applies to any potion you can imagine. Basically, when the game gets hard, just drink all the potions you have created and become a demi-god for a short time, kill anything, and done.- Weapon upgrading is aswell completely game breaking: you can stack an unlimite damount of upgrade crystals (which grant a % of bonus damage based on the element they are) on a weapon, so if you have like 50 upgrade crystals, which can be found easily or created with alchemy, you can put all of them on a weapon, getting a +10% damage bonus 50 TIMES. So that weapon will become just ridiculous.- Healing shrines ruin combat: in the world there are many, TOO many healing shrines, which will give the player a very high health regen over time. They are on many roads and even inside dungeons. fact is, you can make enemis follow you and stay inside a healing shrine to fight, so you will have health regen and be near invincible, but enemies will not have the bonuss and so your fight will be really easy. Same thing goes for Mana shrines if you are a mage, same principle but with mana, so unlimited power.- Inexplicable random stuttering inside cities or in crowded combats, even on recent computer system, this is a result of bad optimization on the overall game engine both graphical and coding-wise.- Main quest and side missions are just anonymous, uninvolving, poorly written and underwhelming, sketched, half finished, poorly refined.=== Conclusions Some aspects of Two Worlds are well done, almost too much well done, like the incredible number of weapons and armor, or the variety of enemies, or the principle upon the alchemy system is based,. But, as i explained, a lot of other aspects have been butchered with poor realization, badly thought out balance and gamaplay implementation, or just left there half finished.This is a game with GREAT potential, which has been released unfinished like a lot of today's Early Access games, because in the end this is an early access game, an alpha, a demonstration of the potential this game COULD achieve if it was finished fully.

content:
Posted: February 23
												Two Worlds is easily one of my favorite games. The controls take some getting used to, but you can alter them to your preferences. The graphics are absolutely stunning, and if you are at a high enough altitude you can see most of the world layed out before you.  There's a gem system that's pretty much a rip off of Diablo II, which was one of my favorite aspects. All weopons, and armor can be upgraded just by finding duplicates of them. There are some pretty epic skills, particularly for the archer. There are also various biomes, and weather, and the map is much bigger than it looks.My favorite aspect of the game is just wandering around the woods. It's seriously beautiful.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 18
												The game is extremely fun I still enjoy it, I enjoyed it back on the xbox 360 when it was just Two Worlds, but if I'm going to be honest, I myself see no big changed between Two worlds (Original game) and Two worlds Epic edition ("Updated" game) the graphics If I'm being honest look exactly the same (The changes in my personal opinion are too minimal for me to notice)I run pretty good fps in the game (So I can't complain) but when out in the wilderness (Not in a city, which is where I expected an fps drop, I expected more of an fps drop in qudinar) but at random points I'll get the drop in the wilderness in an mainly unpopulated area (I get them sometimes in cave but I've only ever noticed one a play session) I expected it to be due to monsters but I thought if there's no fps drop in qudinar then how can monsters be that much of a problem unless there's more monsters in this chunk than npcs in qudinar)Gameplay, where do I start? I see no difference at all and that could because I've only played around 11 hours? but I would have hoped for the creatures in normal mode to be buffed (I see no buff at all they are the same old week creatures) I kind of wanted certain npcs (Such as guards) and all monsters (to level around one level behind you) to make the game feel more of a challenge because when you get to about 10k health and have weapons that do 2k+ damage it becomes easy to kill the enemies that are seen (orcs, groms, wolfs, gamma orcs etc) the only enemies I found even an inkling of a challenge with (which I defeated pretty easily due to jump back and potion spam) were ogres Most golems, Dragons and Giant Trachidis.Shop selling and buying, well let me say that I saw no problem with the pricing I thought it was as good as the old game, until It came to some of the swords, but I still think that using the shop could be made a lot easier (For bothing buying and selling) I always hated the fact that if I wanted to buy a gem but they were in stacks so I wanted to put both on a weapon but even if I bought two at the same time and hovered over a weapon one still goes into the inventory, I would have liked both to go on, but I can also see you wanted to use the gem on another weapon. buying potions... I don't know if it's just me but there always seemed to be that lag/latency when buying potions where they wouldn't go into your inventory till you bought another potion or another item, I also think it could have been made easier to buy things by having every weapon/potion/armorpiece in a pile rather than having to buy it one by one it's time consuming. Selling I always disliked selling in two worlds (For no good reason either just for me it felt slow and sluggish and I only ever did it if I needed the money or wanted the money) like selling it would have been so much easier to sell armor/weapons in stacks rather than one by one.The abilities feel far too over powered but on a trade off feel very inaccurate and even sometimes I feel like the hits take a couple seconds to register, which in most situations I felt like when doing it I could die a lot easier I guess that's sort of a trade off? You sacrifice accuracy for damage and sometimes even sacrifice your own life to take down a large enemy because the last hit decided not the register till he had hit you and took your last little bit of health off.I've gone pretty critical on the game for the main fact that It's meant to be a better version and in my person opinion it wasn't.I think combat for the most part (At lower levels) was pretty blanced you took a lot of damage but with the jump back ability it made one enemy fights pretty fair the only reason the fighting was a con was because of how it easy to kill the creatures that were seen the most (Aka wolves/Orcs/Groms/Bears) at a high level once I got past around 5k health and did around six hundred damage I was pretty golden as long as I remembered to jump backwards.Pricing, the pricing was a bit of a plus in my personal opinion it wasn't changed too much but it wasn't amped up by the thousands which is what i had feared upon purchase, but it was nice to see it stayed the same or at least quite close to the same.Horses, they were kind of a pro and a con as they helped me get around but it felt like even at the tiniest slope the horse would veer off course to a slope that seemed to be even bigger, the combat on a horse (Just forget about it) I don't even try to fight on a horse I find it's a lot easier to fight on the ground where I wouldn't fall off randomly because the horse died the aiming I just felt it to be off.All up I'm going to recommend the game for the main fact that it is pretty fun even though there are some aspects of it that could be improved to make the gameplay even more enjoyable and more satisfying.
